PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: First World Zone of Peace, Tibet
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Members of the Senate and the Honourable Speaker in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, urge the Australian Government to undertake all steps within its power in support of the First World Zone of Peace in Tibet, as proposed by His Holiness the Dalai Lama of Tibet.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are:
1. Opposed to the Government's decision to cut funding to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in real terms for the sixth year in succession;
2. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these funding cuts in terms of reductions in staff numbers and research capacity;

3. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these cuts on rural research in Queensland and on the long term economic well being of the rural sector, which makes a significant contribution to Australia's export income.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War and Violence Related Toys, Games and Video Games
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that
1. they are gravely concerned over the availability of war toys and other combat or violence related toys and games, including video games, in our country.
2. They believe there is sufficient scientific evidence to show that these kind of toys and games are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging to children, and socially undesirable.
That the Senate will take measures to end all trading in war and violence related toys, games, and video games, through either self-regulation by the traders in these products, or legislative action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) congratulates the Soviet Union on its historic announcement to reduce its excessive levels of conventional armaments, and encourages the Soviet Union to go beyond its proposed reductions until parity and symmetry in conventional armaments are reached with the conventional forces of the western democracies; and

(b) notes that, in nuclear armaments, the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces agreement is working satisfactorily and calls on the Soviet Union to stop avoiding a meeting and commence negotiations with the United States in the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks to bring these negotiations, which will result in significant reductions in strategic nuclear weapons, to a successful conclusion.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTH QUEENSLAND RAINFORESTS: WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) congratulates the Hawke Labor Government and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) for their success in having the north Queensland rainforests placed on the World Heritage List;
(b) notes with extreme satisfaction that the north Queensland rainforests will be conserved, not only at this stage, but also for future generations;

(c) calls on those shires and councils which were duped by the Queensland Government into opposing the listing, to gain a full understanding of the need for the World Heritage listing and to appraise themselves of the financial package made available by the Federal Government as compensation for those in north Queensland whose employment has been affected by the listing; and

(d) calls on the Queensland Government to set aside its belligerent attitude and cooperate with the Federal Government to ensure that maximum protection is given to this vital area of north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate urges the Federal Government to adopt the approaches advocated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and change the Government's policies to ensure that they-
(a) strengthen the family;
(b) restore Australians' control over their own lives;
(c) provide more incentive and choice;
(d) ensure a fair go for all; and
(e) build one Australia,
for the benefit of all Australians.

(b) notes the large petition from 10,667 concerned Australians lodged on 8 December 1988, which drew attention to the evidence from numerous scientific studies that war toys are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging and socially undesirable;

(c) acknowledges also the huge body of scientific evidence that links television violence with child aggression, in particular the 1987 study by Cupit of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal Children's Program Committee which found that there are 3 effects on children:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw business of the Senate notices of motion Nos. 1 and 2 standing in my name for the next day of sitting for the disallowance of Export Control (Dried Fruits) Orders (Amendment), and Export Control (Fees) Orders. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances at its meeting this morning considered correspondence from the Minister for Resources, Senator Peter Cook, on matters of concern to the Committee. The Minister advised that Export Control Orders No. 12 had indeed been properly made and was signed by him on 26 September 1988. The Minister also explained to the Committee's satisfaction the increase in the fee for quality assurance system services. The Committee thanks the Minister for his cooperation in these matters. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and its correspondence, for the information of honourable senators and others.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Summary of the Committee's Scrutiny
Export Control (Dried Fruits) Orders (Amendment) as contained in Export Control Orders No. 12 of 1988 and made under the Export Control (Orders) Regulations made under the Export Control Act 1982.
This Order makes a number of amendments dealing with such things as fruit colour and pesticide residues.

The Committee noted that its copy of the Orders was neither signed or dated and sought advice as to whether they were properly made. The Committee also raised concerns regarding the consistency of the Notes under the clauses.

The Minister for Resources, Senator the Hon. Peter Cook advised that the Orders were valid, being signed by him on 26 September 1988. The Committee accepted the Minister's undertaking that in future amendments greater effort would be made to ensure consistency between the Notes.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.

Export Control (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment), as contained in Export Control Orders No. 16 of 1988 and made under the Export Control (Orders) Regulations made under the Export Control Act 1982.
These Orders change a definition, increase some fees and decrease others.
The Committee's concerns related to the increase in the fee for Quality Assurance System services from $3000 to $5218 without explanation in the Explanatory Statement.
The Minister for Resources, Senator the Hon. Peter Cook explained the background to the fee increases to the satisfaction of the Committee.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in this matter.

Dear Senator Bob,

I refer to your letter of 18 November 1988 where you advised of the Committee's consideration of Export Control Orders No 16 of 1988, Export Control (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment) made under the Export Control (Orders) Regulations.

You advise that the Committee noted that Clause 3a of the Schedule increases the fee for Quality Assurance System services from $3000 to $5218, there being no explanation in the Explanatory Statement for the reasons for the large increase. You ask for my advice on this.

While the fee increase to $5218 in 1988/89 represents a large increase, the fees were not altered in 1987/88 owing to large scale developmental activity in inspection practices and procedures in the area of approved quality assurance.

This year the detailed examination of the effort expanded by each of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy's regional office support areas on individual commodity groups has resulted in some minor reallocations. In small commodity groups such as processed fruit and vegetables (where the total national effort is less than two man years) this slight variation has had the effect of raising charges significantly. It is even more pronounced for the processed fruits and vegetables commodity group as there are only 13 establishments registered under the export control legislation. In 1987/88 the total cost of providing this service was $83,000. This has risen to $128,000 in 1988/89.

Notwithstanding the increase in fees it is to be noted that the total industry recovery of $77,000 represents less than 0.1% of the total export earnings of the processed fruits and vegetables commodity group.
Thank you for this opportunity of being able to assist the Committee.
