I, MICHAEL JEROME YOUNG, Minister of State for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, having received a request dated 3 November 1987 from the Legal Aid Commission of NSW, for a statement of reasons for my decision of 9 October 1987 not to revoke the deportation order signed on 19 August 1986 in respect of (``the applicant''), make the following statement setting out my findings on material questions of fact, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based, and giving the reasons for my decision.
1. On 19 August 1986 the Ministerial delegate, Mr A. C. Harris, signed an order pursuant to section 12 of the Migration Act that the applicant be deported from Australia.

2. On 10 June 1987 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, constituted by Deputy President R. C. Jennings QC, decided to recommend to me that the deportation order in relation to the applicant be revoked.
3. In making my decision of 9 October 1987, I adopted the findings on material questions of fact made by Deputy President Jennings, as set out in his reasons for decision of 10 June 1987.
4. The Government's criminal deportation policy, tabled in Parliament on 4 May 1983, states at paragraph 4.

``It is the policy of the Australian Government that recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be overturned by the Minister only in exceptional circumstances and only when strong evidence can be produced to justify the decision. Furthermore it is the policy of the Government that, when the Minister decides to deport a person contrary to the recommendation of the Tribunal, the Minister will table in Parliament at the first opportunity a statement of his/her reasons for doing so.''

5. While I accept the findings of fact made by the Tribunal, in some important respects I did not accept the Tribunal's characterisation of the weight to be given to them in the exercise of my discretion. In particular, my view of the case differed from that of the Tribunal in relation to the Tribunal's findings as to the question of recidivism.

6. On the issue of recidivism the Tribunal commented that, given the nature of the applicant's offences: ``one might be excused for inferring that the risk of recidivism was significant and that the applicant may well have a serious problem involving the use of fire''. The Tribunal concluded, however, that ``the detailed sworn evidence tells a different story and advances substantial reasons for discounting the risks of recidivism''.
7. In concluding that the risk of recidivism should be discounted the Tribunal took into account the following factors:
the efforts made by the applicant to rehabilitate himself;
the strength of the applicant's commitment to his mother;
the applicant's resolve not to drink;
the fact the applicant will be released on licence;
the likely influence of the Release on Licence Board.

8. The Tribunal found that the applicant had made significant efforts to rehabilitate himself. In reaching this conclusion the Tribunal had before it material which had not been before my delegate when the deportation order was signed. This was reports of Senior Psychologist Helen Toner dated 21 February 1986 and 7 November 1986, probation and parole reports dated 3 June and 7 August 1986. I accepted that the applicant had made significant efforts to rehabilitate himself.
9. The Tribunal found that the applicant had a strong commitment to his mother and this was a factor motivating him to do well. I accepted this finding of fact.

10. The Tribunal found that the applicant had resolved not to drink and that this had been tested on day releases. I accepted that the applicant had resolved not to drink, I noted, however, that the criminal offences in respect of which the applicant was convicted in 1968 and 1983 both involved alcohol. Further, the applicant's resolution not to drink had not been tested outside the reasonably strict controls of the prison work program.

11. The Tribunal found that the fact that the applicant will be released on licence will act as a strong deterrent to breach of conditions of release. I accepted this finding of fact. I noted, however, that when the applicant was released in 1983 he was released on licence. He was, however, within a period of less than a year, charged with malicious damage to property.

12. The Tribunal found that the Release on Licence Board had available to it the services of skilled persons who are conscious of the need to provide continued support for persons released on licence. The Tribunal found also that the Release on Licence Board had not begun to function in 1983 when the applicant was previously released on licence. I accepted the above findings of fact. I noted, however, that there was no evidence that the Release on Licence Board would be able to provide anything more than general guidance to the applicant.

13. In view of my findings on the above matters I took the view that exceptional circumstances existed which justified me in departing from the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Although I agreed with the Tribunal in regard to its findings of fact, I took the view that the Tribunal gave excessive weight to the influence of the Release on Licence Board and the strength of the applicant's resolution not to drink when that had not been tested outside the reasonably strict controls of the prison work program. I took the view also that the Tribunal did not have sufficient regard to the fact that the applicant's second offence was committed while released on licence, the gravity of the applicant's offences and the interests of the Australian community which may be seriously harmed by allowing the applicant to remain a part of the community.
14. In making the above findings I had regard to:

(i) A submission from Mr Daszczyk, Entry Regulation Branch dated 15 August 1986 to Mr A. C. Harris, Deputy Secretary Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs recommending the deportation of the Applicant.
(ii) Decision of Deputy Secretary, Mr A. C. Harris, dated 19 August 1986 to deport the applicant.
(iii) Decision of Deputy President, R. C. Jennings Q.C. of the AAT, dated 10 June 1987 recommending that the deportation order in relation the applicant be revoked.

(iv) Submission to me from Mr R. Brown, Secretary, Department of Immigration, Local Government & Ethnic Affairs, dated 9 October 1987 recommending that I not accept the recommendation of the AAT that the deportation order be revoked.
(v) Representations dated 13 October 1987, by the Legal Aid Commission of NSW, for and on behalf of the applicant.
(vi) Submission to me by Mr A. E. Faubel, Director, Enforcement, Policy and Review Section dated 29 October 1987, recommending that I maintain my decision of 9 October 1987 to deport the applicant.
(MICK YOUNG)

CASE `B'

A 36 year old male who migrated to Australia in 1975. Convicted in Sydney in 1984 for supplying Indian hemp for which he was sentenced to 4 years imprisonment with a non-parole period of 3 years. He had prior convictions including, in 1982, supplying and possessing heroin (12 months imprisonment on each, non-parole period 6 months) and, in 1984, for possessing heroin (9 months imprisonment). He was separated with 2 children in the custody of his estranged wife in Queensland with whom he had no personal contact for more than 2 years. Minister's delegate signed a deportation order on 28 July 1986.

In recommending revocation of the deportation order on 16 June 1987, the AAT indicated that subject's circumstances were such that they would not normally make a sufficiently strong case to warrant reconsideration of the decision to deport. However, the AAT saw the fact that subject had provided valuable information to the police over some 5 years, that he had actively participated in the detection of crime and that his continuing services were considered to be very valuable because he had been responsible for much information leading to arrests for serious crime as the most important factor in the case, although there were other personal features of the case which weighed in favour of subject's continued residence in Australia.
The decision not to accept the AAT's recommendation is currently before the Federal Court.

I, Michael Jerome Young, Minister of State for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, having received a request dated 16 November 1987 from Messrs Low, Doherty & Stratford, Solicitors, for a Statement of Reasons for my decision of 9 October 1987 not to revoke the deportation order dated 28 July 1986 in respect of (``the Applicant''), make the following statement setting out my findings on material questions of fact, referring to the evidence of other material on which those findings were based, and giving the reasons for my decision.
1. On 28 July 1986 the Ministerial Delegate, Mr A. C. Harris, signed an order pursuant to section 12 of the Migration Act that the applicant be deported from Australia.

2. On 16 June 1987 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, constituted by Deputy President R. C. Jennings Q.C., decided to recommend to me that the deportation order in respect of the applicant be revoked.
3. In making my decision on 9 October 1987, I adopted the findings on material questions of fact made by Deputy President Jennings, as set out in his Reasons for Decision of 16 June 1987.
4. The Government's Criminal Deportation Policy tabled in Parliament on 4 May 1983, states at paragraph 4:

``It is the policy of the Australian Government that recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be overturned by the Minister only in exceptional circumstances and only when strong evidence can be produced to justify the decision. Furthermore it is the policy of the Government that, when the Minister decides to deport a person contrary to the recommendation of the Tribunal, the Minister will table in Parliament at the first opportunity a statement of his/her reasons for doing so.''

5. The Tribunal had before it material which had not been before my delegate when the deportation order was signed. This was the written or sworn oral evidence of three NSW Police officers indicating that the applicant had actively assisted in the detection of crime and that his continuing services were considered to be very valuable because he had been responsible for much information leading to arrests for serious crime. However, the Tribunal was of the view, the final application of which I did not accept, that this material raised a strong argument for revoking the deportation order.

6. The Tribunal found, and I accepted, that `the potential for a material contribution to the community interest fortified as it is by a commendable record of service, previously never revealed, is the most important factor in this case. There are other personal features to which reference has already been made and which weigh in favour of his continued residence in Australia'.

7. On the issue of recidivism the Tribunal concluded: `Having regard to the circumstances surrounding the offences for which he was convicted, I consider there is still room for giving the benefit of the doubt so far as the risk of recidivism is concerned. There are good reasons for qualified optimism.' Furthermore ` . . . I am satisfied that this applicant has now made such a commitment to assisting the police in their efforts against crime that he would find it extremely difficult to involve himself in the kind of activity he professes to have strong motivation to arrest'.

8. In addition to the considerations outlined in paragraphs 6 and 7 above, the Tribunal had regard to the other considerations that had been raised in the applicant's favour. The Tribunal was of the view, which I also accepted, that `although all (of these other considerations) have merit they would not, even if taken together, make a sufficiently strong case to warrant reconsideration of the deportation decision.'

9. I formed the view that the Tribunal gave determinative weight to the considerations outlined in paragraphs 6 and 7 above. I was not prepared to give the applicant the benefit of the doubt concerning his prospects of rehabilitation and formed the view that they would be significantly enhanced if he were to dissociate himself from the drug scene. There would be a correspondingly greater risk of him becoming actively involved with drugs if he maintains such contact. However, if the applicant opts to dissociate himself from drug associates, his services as an informer would be reduced if not terminated. For this reason I did not accept the Tribunal's view of the weight that should be given to these two considerations as factors against ordering the applicant's deportation.
10. In addition, I gave significant weight to the fact that the applicant has no real ties in Australia and that therefore deportation was unlikely to cause him undue hardship.

11. In view of the conclusions I reached in regard to this case as referred to above, I took the view that exceptional circumstances existed which justified me in departing from the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Although I would not disagree with the Tribunal in regard to its findings of fact, I took the view that the Tribunal wrongly gave determinative weight to the considerations outlined in paragraph 6 and 7 above and did not give sufficient weight to the applicant's lack of ties in Australia.

12. In making the above decision I had regard to a submission to me from Mr R Brown, Secretary, Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, together with the annexures thereto, viz:
(a) Submission to the Deputy Secretary from Mr Z. Daszczyk, Entry Regulation Branch, dated 9 July 1986, and annexures.
(b) Decision and Reasons of the AAT (Deputy President Jennings QC) dated 16 June 1987.
(c) Written statement by a NSW police officer dated 1 April 1987.
(d) Statement by NSW police officer, B. Meredith, undated.

CASE `C'

A 25 year old, single male who migrated to Australia in 1970 with his parents when 8 years of age. Convicted in Sydney in 1984 of conspiracy to import heroin (14 years imprisonment), conspiracy to supply heroin (3 years imprisonment) and possession of heroin (3 counts, 3 years imprisonment on each, all to be served concurrently, with a minimum term of 5 years imprisonment). He had prior convictions including one in 1978 for rape (8 years imprisonment) following which he was warned on 26 October 1982 of the possibility of deportation if he re-offended. His family ties with Australia are strong-all members of his immediate family are resident here and are anxious to play a part in his attempted rehabilitation. When ordering deportation on 19 August 1986, the Minister's delegate recognised inter alia that this was a particularly difficult case but the fact that subject had previously been given the benefit of any doubt on the chances, which were judged to be fairly strong, that he would commit further crimes against the community of some gravity, was seen to override the factors against deportation.

In recommending revocation of the deportation order, on 24 June 1987 the AAT found that subject was a problem. He had a very bad criminal record and there was a risk that he may offend again. However, the AAT also reluctantly concluded that subject had become Australia's problem in that he had arrived in Australia as a child with his family and, in the opinion of the AAT, sending him back to a country which was now alien to him and his family could not be justified. The AAT also commented that if subject seriously offended again `it is to be hoped that notwithstanding parole boards and non-parole periods he will be placed in prison for a long time without compunction and without any early release'.
The decision not to accept the AAT's recommendation is currently before the Federal Court.

Nature of Crime

6. The Tribunal found that the offence committed by the applicant did not involve ``hard'' drugs or dealing on a significantly large scale and accordingly the offence was not one which was included in the examples of serious offences given in paragraph 9 of the policy referred to above. While I accept this view I nevertheless considered the offence to be a serious one in view of the fact that the applicant was able to enter and was willing to enter commerce with dealers of prohibited drugs.
Recidivism

7. The Tribunal assessed the risk of recidivism by the applicant as ``low'' and categorised it as nothing other than an ever present risk. However in view of the applicant's prior criminal record and the warning which was given him on 9 June 1981 that should he re-offend he could be deported (which warning he apparently failed to heed) I considered the risk of recidivism to be serious.
Hardship to the Applicant

8. I accepted that the centre of the applicant's family life is in Australia. I also accepted that he has a stable and long-standing relationship with Miss M . However I gave weight to the fact that the applicant was willing and able to return to Lebanon in 1978 and 1980.
Contribution to the Australian Community

9. The Tribunal found that the applicant had been willing and able to engage in regular employment both before his conviction and after his release from prison. The Tribunal concluded that ``there is no reason to doubt that he will be capable of contributing to the community by earning his way in it''. While I accepted the Tribunal's findings I considered that this did not amount to an appreciable contribution to the community and was unlikely to amount to an appreciable contribution in the future.
Conclusion

10. In view of the conclusions I reached in regard to this case as referred to above, I took the view that exceptional circumstances existed which justified me in departing from the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Although I agreed with the Tribunal in regard to its findings of fact, I took the view that the Tribunal gave excessive weight to the hardship which would be suffered by the applicant and his family if he were deported, and did not have sufficient regard to the interests of the Australian community, which may be seriously harmed by allowing the applicant to remain a part of the community.
MICK YOUNG
17 August 1987
CASE `E'

A 30 year old male who migrated to Australia in 1985 aged 26 years (he was previously in Australia between April 1981 to December 1982 as a visitor). He was convicted in Sydney in 1985 on 2 counts of supplying heroin and sentenced to 18 months imprisonment with a non-parole period of 12 months. His family ties in Australia were strong-his parents, two siblings, fiancee and 3 year old son (by a previous relationship) were resident here. He was not aware of his son's surname nor address and therefore it has not been possible to ascertain the strength of the kinship bond. He has two brothers resident overseas. When ordering deportation on 7 October 1986 the Minister's delegate recognised that this was a difficult case but considered that he was active in the drug trade; the fact that the offences were committed a short time after arrival in Australia, his lack of contact with his son and, although hospitalised in August 1985 due to adverse consequences of drug use, he was soon after arrested on charges of using and supplying heroin-which would indicate that the risk of recidivism was high.

In recommending revocation of the deportation order on 13 April 1987 the AAT commented that the offence of supplying drugs was rightly categorised as serious, however following release from prison the subject had married his fiancee and had kept off drugs for some time. The AAT considered that hardship to the subject, his wife and family, if he was deported, outweighed the benefit to the community in his removal. Furthermore it was in the interests of the subject's natural son (whereabouts unknown) that he remain in Australia to meet his parental obligations.
The decision not to accept the AAT's recommendation is currently before the Federal Court.

CASE `F'

A 25 year old male who migrated to Australia aged 10 in 1974 with his parents. Convicted in Perth in 1982 of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment. He had prior convictions of a less serious nature including unlawful assault, damage to property and aggravated assault. Factors militating against deportation were his strong ties with his immediate family in Australia and his intention to marry his fiancee, an Australian citizen. On the other hand the gravity of his offence and the risk of his committing further offences were seen to override the hardship that deportation might impose on him and his family. The Minister's delegate signed a deportation order on 26 August 1985.

On 20 February 1987 the AAT indicated that due to the seriousness of the crime, the factors for and against deportation were closely balanced. However, in view of the presence in Australia of his close-knit and supportive family; the fact that prospects of rehabilitation were better in the Australian community by his employment and association with sports, particularly drag racing-the AAT recommended that the deportation order be revoked.

The subject subsequently applied to the Federal Court for a review of the deportation decision and of the decision of the then Minister not to revoke the deportation order as recommended by the AAT. On 24 March 1988 His Honour Mr Justice Forster dismissed the subject's application.
ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS (JUDICIAL REVIEW) ACT 1977
SECTION 13
STATEMENT OF REASONS

I, MICHAEL JEROME YOUNG, Minister of State for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, having received a request from the Legal Aid Commission of Western Australia for a statement of reasons for my decision of 22 June 1987 not to revoke the deportation order signed on 26 August 1985 in respect of (``the applicant''), make the following statement setting out my findings on material questions of fact, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based, and giving the reasons for my decision.
FINDINGS ON MATERIAL QUESTIONS OF FACT
1. On 26 August 1985 the then Ministerial delegate, Mr L. B. Woodward, signed an order pursuant to section 12 of the Migration Act that the applicant be deported from Australia.

2. On 20 February 1987 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, constituted by Deputy President R. D. Nicholson, decided to recommend to me that the deportation order in relation to the applicant be revoked.
3. In making my decision of 22 June 1987, I adopted the findings on material questions of fact made by Deputy President Nicholson, as set out in his reasons for decision of 20 February 1987.
EVIDENCE OR OTHER MATERIAL ON WHICH THE FINDINGS WERE BASED

In making the above findings I had regard to a submission to me from Mr A. C. Harris, Deputy Secretary, Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, dated 26 May 1987, together with the annexures thereto, viz:
(i) Submission to the Deputy Secretary from Mr Daszczyk, Compliance Branch, dated 18 May 1987;
(ii) Submission to Mr L. Woodward, then Deputy Secretary, dated 26 August 1985;
(iii) Submission to Mr Woodward from Mr R. A. Henderson, Director, Enforcement 3 Section dated 12 August 1985;
(iv) Summing up to jury of His Honour Judge Olney dated 6 August 1982;
(v) Prison report dated 21 March 1985;
(vi) Report of interview with applicant conducted 27 September 1983, with attached testimonials;
(vii) Report of interview with applicant's parents conducted 21 October 1983, with attached letter from applicant's mother;
(viii) Statement of reasons pursuant to section 28 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act signed by Mr Woodward on 8 November 1985;
(ix) Decision and reasons of the AAT (Deputy President R. D. Nicholson) dated 20 February 1987;
(x) Departmental case note on the AAT decision dated 10 March 1987.
REASONS FOR MY DECISION
The Government's criminal deportation policy, tabled in Parliament on 4 May 1983, states at paragraph 4

``It is the policy of the Australian Government that recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be overturned by the Minister only in exceptional circumstances and only when strong evidence can be produced to justify the decision. Furthermore it is the policy of the government that, when the Minister decides to deport a person contrary to the recommendation of the Tribunal, the Minister will table in Parliament at the first opportunity a statement of his/her reasons for doing so.''

While I accepted generally the findings of fact made by the Tribunal, in some important respects I did not accept the Tribunal's characterisation of those facts or the weight to be given to them in the exercise of my discretion. In particular, in terms of the factors examined by the Tribunal in its summation of the case at pages 24-35 of its reasons, my view of the case differed from the Tribunal's view in respect of the following factors:
Nature of Crime

The Tribunal found that ``the extreme seriousness of the offence committed by the applicant must weigh heavily in the administrative decision relating to his deportation. By its commission, the applicant may have placed himself among the class of persons whom Australia will not accept for entry.'' I took the view that the applicant had definitely placed himself within this class of persons. I took the view that, in exercising my discretion under section 12, I should make a choice on behalf of the Australian community to exclude from that community a person whose crime is so repugnant to the standards of that community that he should no longer be accepted as a part of it.
Recidivism

I endorse the view expressed by Davies J in Re Stone, and quoted by Deputy President Nicholson in this case, that ``even if the risk of recidivism is not high, the risk will strongly support deportation when recidivism, if it does occur, may cause great harm''. I took the view that, to justify a decision to revoke the deportation order in this case, the risk of recidivism would have to be shown by convincing evidence to be minimal. I noted the factors relied on by Counsel for the applicant as indicating that the risk of recidivism was low. On the question of recidivism, however, I took the view that the Tribunal's assessment that ``the applicant's crime of murder was a tragic and unusual product of grossly excessive intoxication, mistaken reaction to suspected aggression and youth'' was an inadequate description of the applicant's crime. As the evidence at the trial showed, the applicant committed a savage and sustained attack on a victim who, for a large part of the time, was unable to offer any resistance. In my view, the Tribunal placed undue emphasis on the ``unusual combination of factors and circumstances giving rise to the crime'' and not enough attention was paid to the violent propensities of the applicant.
Hardship to Australian Citizens

At the AAT hearing, the applicant's parents gave evidence that they were considering moving back to England if the applicant were deported; however they had reserved their decision pending the outcome of the AAT proceedings. The Tribunal found, and I accept, that great hardship would occur to the family, the parents of whom are Australian citizens, if they did decide to move to the United Kingdom. I took the view that the family's removal back to England was not a necessary result of my decision, but rather a decision for them to make. If the applicant were deported and his family remained in Australia, then both the applicant and his parents would still suffer considerable hardship; however the applicant is now of mature years and I did not regard this hardship as being of itself a compelling factor in favour of allowing the applicant to remain in Australia.
Hardship to Applicant

I noted the applicant's previous good work history and his apparent willingness to work in prison and to resume his working life upon release. I did not accept the Tribunal's conclusion as to the `unavailability of employment in England' although I accepted that the applicant may have difficulty in obtaining employment. However his previous good work history leads me to believe that he would indeed be able to obtain work in England. I accordingly gave less weight than did the Tribunal to the hardship which the applicant would suffer by reason of deportation.
Conclusion

In view of the conclusions I reached in regard to this case as referred to above, I took the view that exceptional circumstances existed which justified me in departing from the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Although I would not disagree with the Tribunal in regard to its findings of fact, I took the view that the Tribunal gave excessive weight to the hardship which would be suffered by the applicant and his family if he were deported, and did not have sufficient regard to the interests of the Australian community, which may be seriously harmed by allowing the applicant to remain a part of the community.
M. J. YOUNG

A 53 year old male who migrated to Australia in 1972 with his wife and four children. He was convicted in Melbourne in 1978 for murder and wounding with intent to murder and sentenced to life and 15 years imprisonment respectively, to be served concurrently. This case involved an AAT consideration of the merits of a criminal deportation. The Deputy President recommended revocation of the the deportation order and remitted the matter to the Minister for reconsideration.
FACTS

2 The applicant, a British citizen, born in 1962, migrated to Australia, from Scotland with his parents, brothers and sisters in 1977. In 1985 he committed three offences involving armed robbery of a drug dealer (not reported to the police), a massage parlour and at a pinball parlour respectively. He was convicted, on his own plea and sentenced to 6 1/2 years imprisonment in respect of the latter 2 offences. The robberies arose as the result of a social association formed with persons who frequented a street known as the `alleyway', where the applicant had in 1985 set up is own spray painting and panel beating business. These persons introduced the applicant to marijuana and amphetamines and persuaded him to commit the robberies. At the time of the offence the applicant had been drinking and taking these drugs. In the latter 2 offences the applicant had entered the premises and like the co-accused, he carried a weapon and wore a disguise.

3 The applicant had prior convictions including driving while disqualified when his blood alcohol level exceeded .05%, unlawful assault, possessing a firearm without a licence and handling stolen goods. All prior offences were committed under the influence of alcohol.

4 The applicant's fiancee told the Tribunal that she had left him because he had not given up drugs, as she had asked him to do. She indicated that she hoped the relationship would develop to the stage when they would marry.
THE DECISION

5 The Tribunal held that armed robbery was a very serious offence (even though no-one had been injured); the risk of recidivism was more than negligible because the applicant had an alcohol and drug problem and it was doubtful whether his fiancee or his family could influence him in the future, to give up these drugs; the Tribunal doubted whether the applicant would not re-offend although it considered that any future offences committed would not be of a serious, violent nature.

6 Against these factors the Tribunal weighed the hardship to the applicant and his family. The Tribunal held that the hardship which the applicant, his family and his fiancee would suffer if he were deported outweighed the other factors because he was still part of the family unit and because his surviving paternal grandparents in the UK would not be able to offer immediate assistance and accommodation.
CASE `J'

The applicant entered Australia as a visitor in 1972. He was granted permanent resident status in 1980. He was convicted of the cultivation and supply of cannabis in 1984 for which he was sentenced to 5 years imprisonment. He was released on parole after 21 months. The Ministerial delegate signed a deportation order in August 1986.

On 8 October 1987, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal recommended that the deportation order be revoked. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal concluded that the best interests of Australia required revocation notwithstanding the seriousness of the offence. The Tribunal noted that the applicant was a homeless exile whose illegal residence had been condoned for a period of 15 years and that the trial judge had expressed confidence that the applicant would not reoffend.

There was little information before the Tribunal as to the circumstances surrounding the commission of the crime and the applicant's conduct since his release from prison. The Tribunal considered that better information about the circumstances of the crime and the likelihood of recidivism could be obtained when the trial of his co-accused was completed.

The Tribunal recommended that the applicant's deportation be reconsidered after further inquiries had been made. Departmental attempts to locate the applicant for the purposes of updating his circumstances since his release from detention were unsuccessful.
In deciding not to follow the recommendation of the Tribunal the Minister noted:
(i) The applicant pleaded guilty to the charges of cultivation and supply of cannabis.
(ii) The Tribunal could have sought further information during the hearing, this was not done.
(iii) The applicant attended the hearing and gave vive voce evidence to the Tribunal.
(iv) The circumstances of the crime, insofar as could be ascertained were fully set out in the Trial Judge's sentencing remarks. These remarks were before the Tribunal.
The applicant departed Australia on 12 December 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, when the Privacy Bill was returned to us from the House of Representatives, I was pointing out the history of the legislation. Back in 1985 the Government had a sudden rush of blood to the head and that the only way to crack down on tax and social security cheats was to have an Australia Card. From that ensued a very prolonged parliamentary and public debate about the wisdom of presenting everybody with a national identification system complete with card with photograph magnetic strip on the back, talks about smart cards, computer chips and so on. In the long run, for a variety of reasons and more, I suspect through good luck than good management, that piece of legislation was defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government in the meantime, had introduced a large number of amendments to legislation provisions, various guidelines, directives, administrative changes and so on which recouped large amounts of the money that had been lost prior to that through fraud and so on in both the tax and social security areas. Originally it was predicted that about $1,000m annually-was being lost to revenue through that form of fraud, cheating and so on. By the end of 1987 some $800m of that $1,000m of lost revenue had been recouped, as I said, by a range of means. That left $200m outstanding in the area of tax and social security fraud-less than 30 cents per week per Australian. Nevertheless, the Government decided that it needed to make moves to recoup this sum and chose to do it by introducing legislation to extend the use of the tax file number system.

At the time most of us who had opposed the Australia Card legislation and who could see very little difference between the Government's tax file number legislation and its Australia Card legislation other than the fact that there was no provision for a plastic card, photographs and one thing or another assumed that those people in this place who had opposed the Australia Card legislation would also oppose the tax file number legislation. That, however, was not to be. History shows that the Opposition undertook some sort of deal with the Government, the details of which are still not particularly clear, in order to bring this legislation into being.

One of the trade-offs dealt with the requirement to quote the tax file number. The Opposition persuaded the Government to introduce a half-baked sort of voluntariness to this. Under the original piece of legislation it would have been a breach of the law not to quote a tax file number to employers, banks, building societies and an assortment of individuals in the community. With the Opposition amendment, supported by the Government, we discovered that it would no longer be a breach of the law not to quote the tax file number but that a simple penalty would apply. One could not be taken to court as a consequence of not quoting the tax file number but one would face a pecuniary penalty. That penalty was to have over half one's income deducted in tax from dollar one-50.25c in the dollar to be deducted by way of tax.

This amendment effectively gave to the very wealthy in the community a voluntariness with regard to quoting their tax file number but the rest of us had no choice. We quoted it whether we liked it or not or we faced losing over half our salary in that pecuniary penalty. In any event there was very little the Australian Democrats could do about it. The deal had been done between the Opposition and the Government, and that was that.

But the second part of the deal related to the introduction of privacy legislation. The Opposition said, `We will support this tax file number legislation provided the Government minimises the intrusion into the community of that piece of legislation. Therefore, we want privacy legislation introduced that will protect individuals from malicious or incompetent people misusing the information, releasing it when they should not, distorting it, taking it out of context, and so on'. The Government produced, at the Opposition's request, a privacy Bill. Privacy legislation is something that the Democrats have been seeking since my colleagues came into this chamber in 1978. Australia has never had privacy legislation, unlike a number of other countries, and it sorely needs it.

One of the areas that we all need protection from is the release of information about us from the private sector. This legislation does not cover that. It is a major flaw in the legislation. Senator Aulich, during the second reading debate, had a go at the Democrats for not raising the question of the private sector before. I suggest that the honourable senator look at our record; he will see that we introduced privacy legislation of our own. We have always argued that the private sector should be covered by privacy legislation. In any event an amendment we attempted to move in this regard was defeated by the Government and the Opposition on the grounds that they believed that the only threat to privacy in the community, apparently, is from the public sector, that is, from government departments and their agencies. I do not happen to share that belief, but that appears to be the attitude taken by the other parties in this place. So we lost that division.

However, there were a number of other very large loopholes in the privacy legislation that we and the Opposition set about closing. For example, we argued, would it not be right and proper that the information collected about individuals be required to be accurate? Would it not be appropriate that when information is sought and put into a file that it should be accurate? `Yes' said the Opposition. `No', said the Government, `it does not need to be accurate'. But we had the numbers on this side of the chamber and the amendment was passed. Then we said, `Wouldn't it be reasonable if people knew about the collection of the information and what was held on them?' The Opposition said it thought it was a good idea-at least it did at the time. The Government was not so enthusiastic but, again, we had the numbers on this side and a Democrat amendment relating to that was passed.

Then we said, `Shouldn't people know what the purposes for the collection of the information are?'. The Government had already included in the Bill that people should know what the main purpose was, but information is collected and used for a variety of purposes and, while one might be marginally more important than another-at least to the Government-the use of the information was not going to be limited to that. So we moved an amendment that said the individuals should be permitted the courtesy of knowing the purposes of the use of the information. The Government objected to that but the Opposition supported it, and that amendment went through. Then we said, `All right, the information has been collected; we have made it accurate; the subject knows what the information is: What about disclosure? What about storing the information? What about disposing of the information? What about amending the information? Isn't it reasonable to expect that those of us out here in the community, about whom information is being collected, should know to whom the Government is disclosing this information and why?'

Again, the Opposition thought that this was reasonable. It supported the amendment and it went through. It has changed its mind. All of a sudden apparently the Opposition does not see the need for information to be accurate. It does not see any need for people to know the purposes for which the information is being collected. The Opposition does not believe that individuals need to know why the information is being disclosed or to whom. The Opposition has decided, two weeks after supporting these amendments, that it is not essential for people to know why this is all being done. I find that extraordinary. Here is a privacy Bill with holes in it that one could drive a fleet of trucks through. It is useless; it will not protect anybody's privacy. For a start, people will not know what information is being collected on them. People will not know about the spread of the legislation. How will they determine whether the information is accurate? They are being given no access to any important information at all about data stored on them.

If that is not bad enough-namely, that the Opposition is reneging on its support of those amendments-something even more extraordinary is apparently about to happen. The Opposition is going to vote against its own amendments of two weeks ago. Senator Hill, for the Opposition, argued that the Bill was deficient in some ways. He argued that there was no capacity for an individual to commence an action for breach of privacy. He said:
We believe that, in actual fact, a civil action in particular might be the most effective deterrent on Government agencies.

The Opposition said that people should be given the opportunity, if they ever found out that somebody had misused, leaked, distorted or destroyed information about them, to take an action for breach of privacy in the civil courts where one can get damages. They should not just have to go to the Privacy Commissioner who may award compensation. Everybody should be given the normal right that they have in other areas to take action for damages.

The Opposition has now decided apparently that this is not necessary and that we do not need to offer people that recourse to law any more-something which I would have thought Western democracies held dear. The Government has returned these amendments to us. Why? It has not done so for terribly convincing reasons. If we look at the schedule that the Government has brought before us that indicates why it does not want these amendments passed, we find an extraordinary litany of reasons. One is that it would be burdensome for the agencies. We cannot have the agencies doing anything that would burden them! We cannot allow people to be protected if it will get in the way of the agencies doing whatever else they do! It would be impractical for the agencies, says the Government. It would be difficult for the agencies, says the Government, and it would not be appropriate for the agencies to have to do these things, says the Government. The Opposition apparently also believes that it is inappropriate to have a piece of privacy legislation that actually protects people if--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is now debating the message from the House of Representatives desiring that the Committee not insist upon the amendments to the Privacy Bill made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed. I do not intend to speak for long but I think I should put the position of the Opposition in its historical context, particularly in view of certain misrepresentations which I understand were made by someone on Canberra radio yesterday morning. Honourable senators will probably recall that when we considered the Government's Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill the Opposition set down a number of criteria which it said the Government would have to meet before the Opposition could support the Bill. One of the criteria relevant to this particular debate that we insisted on is that there be adequate privacy legislation introduced and passed by the Parliament to commence contemporaneously with the tax file number system.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may also recall that the Government produced for consideration by the Opposition a draft Bill which was provided, at that stage I think on a confidential basis, to the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown. The Opposition considered that draft Privacy Bill and found it to be fundamentally flawed, in our view, and requiring very significant alterations. There followed a series of meetings between Mr Brown on our side and I think Senator Tate on behalf of the Government, with the assistance of some of his departmental officials. The Opposition's concerns were put to the Government and they were virtually all acceded to.

It is important that I spend a moment to remind the Committee of how important were the requirements of the Opposition that were not included in the original Bill but which the Government, after negotiation, agreed to accept. The first flaw that we observed and required to be remedied concerned the duty of the Privacy Commissioner. The Bill provided that the Privacy Commissioner may issue guidelines on the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. If those guidelines were not issued there would have been no rules for the privacy of tax file number information. We regarded that as a major defect in the Bill. We put that to the Government and said the `may' should be altered to `shall', placing a specific obligation upon the Privacy Commissioner, and the Government accepted that. So the resolution of our first major concern was accepted.

Our second concern dealt with the guidelines for privacy. We were concerned that there were no actual guidelines or rules set down in the Bill for tax file number information. We said to the Government that before we could accept the Bill it must set out the terms and rules that the Government believed were adequate for maintaining the privacy of tax file number information. The Government responded by accepting that requirement of the Opposition. The Bill, as it presently stands before us, sets out the privacy guidelines in schedule 2. They are, of course, interim guidelines and will have effect until the Commissioner issues guidelines in due course under the terms of the legislation.

The third area that we raised which is of concern to us was the exemption from information privacy principles on the ground of public interest. We noted that the Bill allowed agencies to apply to the Privacy Commissioner for an exemption from following principles on the ground of public interest. We said that that should be permitted only if it was in a form that could be disallowable by the Parliament. In other words, there had to be a parliamentary supervision of agencies calling upon this exemption of public interest. That requirement, after negotiations, was also accepted by the Government.

The fourth area that we raised of concern dealt with complaints. We noted that the Bill provided for individuals to make complaints to the Privacy Commissioner against interferences but that no complaint could be made in the first six months of the operation of the Privacy Bill. That means that for the first six months agencies and tax file number recipients would be a law unto themselves. We said that this was unsatisfactory and that this limitation period should be removed. The Government's response was to accept our representations in that regard.

The fifth area of concern that we put to the Government dealt with the Privacy Commissioner's powers to enter premises. We were concerned that when it related to entry of government premises he could do so only upon arrangements with the particular government agency. That is obviously flawed. I would not want to suggest that whilst arrangements were being made information might in some way disappear or otherwise be dealt with; nevertheless, justice must not only be done but must be seen to be done. We said that that provision should be amended to give the Privacy Commissioner instant access to government agencies without any arrangement being made in advance. The Government's response again was to accept the Opposition's representations.

The sixth area of concern that we put to the Government-I am going through these because Senator Haines said that she was not aware of what the Opposition had been able to extract from the Government in this matter-dealt with reports to the Parliament. We noted the inadequacy of the report provisions within the Bill and made representations that at least the major activities undertaken by the Privacy Commissioner should be included within the report; the Government again accepted our representations in that regard.

The seventh area of concern to us that we raised with the Government was in relation to the commencement of the Acts. As I said, it was essential to us that both the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act and the Privacy Act commenced contemporaneously. We noted that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill was to come into operation when it received the royal assent, but that the Privacy Bill was not to come into operation until proclamation. Of course, there could therefore be a gap and that gap was unsatisfactory to us. The Government accepted our representation in that regard, so that both Bills now come into operation at the same time.

So there were seven critical matters on which we required the Government to take remedial action and in all cases it accepted our submissions. There was an eighth one which the Government refused and that related to our belief that there should be a civil action for breach of privacy. That is still our view. We believe that there should be a civil action. Whilst acknowledging that there is a capacity for action in statutory form within the Bill and it does allow for compensation, nevertheless, we are of the view that a civil action would give greater flexibility and would be a real deterrent for government agencies in breaching the privacy principles. We are still of that view. It is never too late. We still call upon the Government to accept our view in that regard and improve--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but what are you going to do when he won't?

—Senator Haines has spoken for ages. She should give me a chance. As I said, it is never too late. We still call upon the Government to improve this legislation further by accepting our view that a right of civil action for breach of privacy should be included within the legislation. Nevertheless, we made it public on 1 November 1988 that we regarded the Privacy Bill, in the form that had been agreed, with the seven alterations that the Government accepted, as being in a satisfactory form to be passed by the Parliament. That was our view. We made it public that we would support the Bill in that form. We said that we would, nevertheless, try to improve it even further in the Senate. But, as I have said, on 1 November 1988 we indicated that if we could get no further with the Government, we would nevertheless accept the Bill in that form.

SPEECH.PARA: We think privacy legislation in this country is important. It is long overdue. It is now time that it be passed. When the Bill was debated in this place we took the opportunity to call for two further significant improvements to the Bill-which went beyond the agreement we had reached with the Government, but nevertheless, if one believes that legislation can be further improved, one should make the effort. One of those improvements concerned appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). Under the Bill there was a right of appeal of the government agency when an order of compensation had been made but there was not a right for an individual to appeal to the AAT when an order of compensation had not been made. We were pleased that, in this place, the Government accepted our proposals to amend that provision. Therefore, we were able to extract from the Government one extra improvement to the Bill.

There was one final matter on which we also sought agreement of the Government in this place but which, I accept, was not put to the Government in our previous negotiations. That was our view that in the case of representative actions there should also be the capacity to award compensation. The Government has not been prepared to accept our view in that regard. We are still of the opinion that the Bill could be improved by inclusion of such a provision but, as I have indicated, we do not regard it as vital to the passing of the legislation.

When the legislation was before this chamber previously, we were prepared to accept a number of the Australian Democrats' amendments which were designed to strengthen further the privacy principles. Those we accepted on the last occasion we still believe would further improve this legislation. But, every time one reads a piece of proposed legislation, ways become apparent in which that proposed legislation can be further improved. We do not believe that that further strengthening of the principles, as we argued in this place on the last occasion, is critical to the passing of the Bill. We regard the Bill as being in a satisfactory form as it was at the time of introduction to this place, which was in the form that was agreed by the Opposition at the beginning of November 1988. I hope that that clarifies the position of the Opposition in this regard.

We are pleased that this Bill is to pass into law. We are pleased that it has been substantially altered in accordance with the representations we made to the Government. Certainly on this side of the chamber we see it as a vastly improved piece of proposed legislation as a result of the representations we made, which were accepted by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have ever heard such an extraordinary piece of rhetoric from anybody, including Senator Hill. Senator Hill has just got up here and pleaded with the Government to do something that the Opposition could do with its own vote shortly. He has just said, as he was reported in the newspapers this morning as saying, that he wants to make a final appeal to the Senate. In case you had not noticed it, Senator Hill, you are part of the Senate and your lot and our lot have the numbers in this place-on the rare occasions you are not voting with the Government and giving it the numbers.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is Senator Hill saying to the Government that he wants it to support Australian Democrats amendments which the Opposition supported two weeks ago and he wants the Government to support Opposition amendments which we supported two weeks ago, but the Opposition is not prepared to do it? I find it even more extraordinary that Senator Hill finished his plea by saying that he thinks the Bill is satisfactory anyway, even if it is not further amended. Somehow it is perfectly satisfactory to have a Bill that does not require the information collected to be accurate, and that does not require that the subjects about whom the information is collected know for what purposes the information is being collected! Somehow it is perfectly satisfactory to have a Bill that does not provide for any civil action for damages when somebody's privacy is breached. It is perfectly all right, apparently, to have a Bill that is drafted so that people do not have to be told what information about them is being disclosed and so that they have no control over that information. I find that astounding.

Senator Hill said in the first 10 minutes of his speech that the Opposition had got seven critical matters included in the Government's original draft as part of the deal the Opposition did with the Government to support the tax file number legislation. There are eight equally critical matters left that the Opposition supported two weeks ago and that the Government is opposing and returning to us with the request that we not press these amendments. If they were sufficiently important two weeks ago, what in God's name has happened between now and then that has made them not important? Why is it suddenly not important that information collected on Senator Hill and me and 16 million other Australians not be accurate?

It is bad enough that information will be collated. It is bad enough if that information is accurate. But if it is inaccurate, if people do not know what has been collected, if they do not know why it has been collected or what is going to happen to the information after it has been collected, that is appalling. The Opposition thought it was sufficiently appalling two weeks ago to support our amendments.

Yet Senator Hill gets up here today and says that he is making one last plea to the Senate-of which he is part-to support the amendments but that the Opposition is not going to do it itself; it expects the Government to do it. This is just about as bizarre as Mr Howard stating last week that when in government, or if in government, the Opposition will repeal the tertiary tax, when that legislation has not passed the Senate yet. If Liberal Party senators do not like it, they can oppose it here and save Mr Howard the trouble of repealing it if he ever gets back into government. It is absurd.

This chamber is a House of review, in case anybody else in here has forgotten that fact. It has long since stopped being a States House, despite what Opposition members choose to say when it suits their purpose. But it should still be a House of review. We are supposed to consider legislation on its merits. We are not supposed to say that if a Bill is a money Bill we will not touch it, but that we might repeal it when we get into government. We are not supposed to say `This Bill still has flaws, but please, Mr Government, will you do something about it because we do not feel able to?' No wonder the electorate does not want us to be paid anything. If a few more members of the public saw what happened in here they would probably share the Australian Labor Party's belief that we should get rid of the Senate. As far as I am concerned, the way this place behaves there is more reason than ever for a benevolent dictator-tempered with occasional assassinations.

I have not heard Senator Hill say why, when the Opposition was able to support amendments which improved the Bill two weeks ago, it cannot do so now. The right to sue for damages is an integral part of our legal system. Why should it not apply to people who have been harmed in some way because a piece of legislation that has gone through this place, with the support of the Opposition, has allowed the collation and collection of information that has perhaps been misused by someone and damaged somebody else? Senator Hill has not indicated why he does not think information should be accurate. He has not indicated why this week, as distinct from the week before last, he thinks it is no longer important that people know which information is being disclosed and to whom. Senator Hill has not told us today, on behalf of the Liberal Party, why the Opposition is voting against its own amendments; why people should not have knowledge of the information collected about them; and why, when he has it in his power to make sure that the legislation is as leak-proof as possible, he is standing up here pleading with the Government to do it. We have the numbers. If Senator Hill has the brains, he will use them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to be drawn further into this discussion but, after the rubbish that I have just heard, answers are required on a couple of matters. The first rubbish concerned Senator Haines's suggestion that, under the principles, inaccurate information could be held legitimately. I draw her attention to the provisions as they exist. Principle 3, which deals with the solicitation of personal information generally, requires that all information collected be relevant to the purpose, up to date and complete. If Senator Haines wants to add another word, she can do so. In the previous debate we were prepared to accept the addition of another word, but what does the wording mean as it stands? What is meant by the requirement that the information be up to date and complete? What does `complete' mean? It is quite misleading to say that that legitimises the keeping of inaccurate information.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Haines said that those about whom information is kept should be entitled to know the purposes. I draw her attention to principle 5, dealing with information relating to records kept by the record keeper. It states that if the record keeper has possession or control of a record that contains such information the main purposes for which that information is used must be given. There are good reasons to put it in those terms. We accepted that in the last debate. In many ways we would argue that the wording could be changed. If we had drafted this legislation we may have drafted the principles differently. But the person about whom information is kept is entitled, under these principles, to be made aware of the main purposes for which it is kept. Principle 11 sets out the limits on disclosure of personal information.

I suggest that Senator Haines read some of these principles before she contributes to the debate with such nonsense as we have heard this morning. Why are we not insisting on going further than what we regarded as satisfactory before? The reason is that we do not have the numbers in the other place and, if we did, the Bill would not become law. We believe that it is in the best interests of this nation that the Bill become law. We think it is long overdue, and we think it is about time the Australian Democrats supported it also. It would be in the best interests of the total Australian community to have adequate privacy legislation, and that is what this is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Hill that we amended a tax Bill yesterday and we do not have the numbers in the other place to make sure that the Government proceeds with that, either. We amend legislation all the time and we do not have the numbers in the House of Representatives. That does not stop us amending legislation. I remind Senator Hill of the comments that he made on information privacy principle No. 3 when we amended it on 22 November. After I moved an amendment to include the word `accurate' after `and is up to date and complete', Senator Tate pointed out that privacy principle 7 stated that certain information had to be relevant, up to date, complete and not misleading and that the world `accurate' was used in other places. He did not think that it was necessary, since information privacy principle 7 contained that word, that information privacy principle 3 should also contain it.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Senator Hill got to his feet. His opening words were:
Senator Tate has convinced me-

I thought, `Oh, blast, there goes that amendment. Senator Tate's erudition, rhetoric and positive charm oozing across the chamber have convinced Senator Hill not to support the Democrat amendment'. However, while I was thinking that, Senator Hill-of course, not aware that I was thinking it-kept on talking, which was quite appropriate. Had I been talking, it would have been rude of him, but I was only thinking. He finished his sentence with the words:

that `accurate' might as well be included in information privacy principle 3, because as he has already pointed out it is in principle 7, which is comforting, and that is in relation to alteration of records containing personal information and the obligation to ensure that deletions and additions are accurate.
He went on to say:
Therefore, one asks why `up-to-date, complete and accurate' was not included in principle 3, relating to the solicitation of personal information generally.
On 22 November Senator Hill said:
I can only presume that it was an oversight and it now looks as though we have the opportunity to correct that.

If it is rubbish for me today to suggest that information be accurate, why on 22 November did he consider it an oversight that needed to be corrected? As legislators, as people reviewing Government Bills and as people who have the capacity to improve where improvements are needed-notwithstanding that we will probably never run into a perfect Bill-we must ask ourselves what we are doing if we do not proceed down that road. If there is an oversight or a word that should be there is missing, surely it is our job to fix it up. It is not our job on this side to grovel around and ask the Government to do it when we know that the Government will not if it does not need to. If the Opposition is going to roll over and have its tummy tickled every time the Government woofs at it, of course the Government will not do anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends who is doing the tickling.
—Does it now? Obviously, when Senator Tate tickles it is all right.
—Eight improvements we got to the Bill.
—A minute ago you said that it was seven.
—No, we got another one here-the AAT, which is more than the Democrats did; they achieved nothing.
—I am glad you reminded me.
—Order! Conversation should be conducted through the Chair and not directly between honourable senators.

—Senator Hill was being very useful, Mr Chairman, but I take your wise words on board. Senator Hill pointed out that we did get one amendment through, which the Government supported. That amendment allows people to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), if they can afford to do so. It is rather like the amendment that the Opposition made to the tax file number legislation that said that if a person was wealthy enough he did not have to quote his number because he could wear the 52.5c in the dollar penalty. But the rest of the poor mugs out there do not have that choice. Not everybody can afford to appeal to the AAT when his privacy has been breached. It is an improvement, but it is not an improvement that will affect everybody. As that improvement was satisfactory, I maintain that the seven other amendments that were supported in this place on 22 November deserve the same support today, 8 December.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals cannot have changed their minds in such a short space of time! Then again, they can change their minds when they feel like it, I suppose. I guess I should not be surprised that it took them all of two weeks to do it. But it does not alter the fact that the Australian public deserve the best legislation that we can give them. That is what we are being paid to do. I say to Senator Hill: If we dig our heels in on these eight amendments I doubt very much that the Government will suffer the political backlash that would come from not proceeding with a piece of privacy legislation that actually protects privacy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is examining the schedule of amendments made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed. I would like to indicate publicly that a great deal of work has been done on this privacy legislation. The work of auditing what the Government was proposing has been achieved by a number of people, not least Senator Haines, Mr Neil Brown, the Opposition shadow Attorney-General, Senator Hill and others. They have worked strenuously to achieve a result which would give true protection to the privacy of individuals against the prying eye of a fairly all powerful government. I think that is extremely important and I believe the work that has been done in this area needs to be acknowledged broadly.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a look at the reasons that have been given by the Government for not agreeing to the Senate's amendments. I wonder whether the Government prepared these responses or whether a Minister prepared them, because they look very much like Public Service-ese--

TALK.START.PARA: —The bureaucracy at work.

—As Senator Haines has said, it is the bureaucracy at work. They are quite reminiscent of the return to order paper we received in the Senate the week before last which gave reasons for certain legislation that had passed both Houses not being proclaimed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer to some of the reasons set out by the House of Representatives for not agreeing to the Senate's amendments. Senate amendment No. 1 was to ensure that individuals from whom information was collected should be informed in writing of the purpose for which that information was collected. The response given by the Government is:
The proposed requirement that the individual be informed in writing would be burdensome for agencies and of limited benefit to some individuals.

The Government concedes, presumably, that it will be of benefit to many individuals. I would have thought that that was the reason the Senate adopted that amendment. I really believe that it is important for individuals not only to know generally the reasons for the collection of the information but also for these reasons to be given in writing.

In the Government's response to the second amendment again the Public Service jargon comes out. Honourable senators will recall that the second amendment deals with the need to ensure that the material collected is up to date, complete and accurate. The Government's response to the second amendment is:
There are practical difficulties in imposing an obligation on agencies to check the accuracy of personal information at the time of collection.
I acknowledge that the Government's response also states:
. . . Privacy Principles 7 and 8 provide important privacy safeguards for individuals by requiring record-keepers to correct inaccuracies before making any use of information in records.

Does the Government not know about hackers? Does the Government not know of the possibility of information being accessed prior to the inaccuracies being discovered? Would it not be better for the inaccuracies not to have occurred in the first place? Surely that is the reason for the amendments that the Senate made to this legislation.

I do not want to delay the Committee but I wish, finally, to turn to the next amendment. Senate amendment No. 3 provided that persons from whom the information is extracted should be informed of each purpose for which that information is used. The Government's response is simply:
Information privacy Principle 5 requires the record-keeper to provide information to enable any person to ascertain the main purposes for which that information is used.
The response continues:

Agencies may have a range of purposes for which personal information is used. It would be impractical to require agencies to set out all the possible purposes for which information held by an agency is used.

My question to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) is: Why would that be impractical? Surely the agencies know why they want that personal information. Surely they know how they want to use that information. Why should not the individuals involved be informed of the use to which that information will be put? I do not wish to delay the Committee but I really feel that at least that question should be answered. I reiterate, in looking at these Government responses, that it looks like the bureaucracy making the usual responses as to why it ought to have information and keep it to itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had my colleague Senator Harradine not spoken I would have made some of the points that he has made. I will not rehash them but I want to say that, just before we abandon all hope over this legislation, I think what we have heard today and what we have seen as the Government's response to the Senate's amendments is pure Yes, Minister. We have heard in one guise or another, either from the Government or from the Opposition, every one of the arguments that Sir Humphrey puts up or the Minister puts forward to justify not doing something: `There will be administrative difficulties'. `There are legal or constitutional problems'. `It is too expensive'. `Some questions remain unanswered'. `It is the right decision but the wrong time'. We will not get another time. Because of the deal that has been done between the Government and the Opposition, apparently this legislation will go through this place today with virtually limited, if not actually useless, privacy protection for 16 1/2 million Australians. Gentlemen, I hope you are proud of yourselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite proud of myself. I think Senator Hill and other honourable senators who will join in the vote which will be called on the amendments before the chamber also have reason to be pleased with the situation we are faced with. The formal motion before the chamber is:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee does not insist upon the Amendments made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

This signals that, after many years in gestation, the Parliament has now reached a position where privacy legislation is to be passed in a way which will bind Commonwealth agencies in respect of the many millions of items of information they hold with regard to the Australian people. Further, in relation to tax file number information, the legislation will bind not only the agencies of government but the private sector as well. When one looks at the full scope of what is achieved in this legislation, one can say that it is a cause for some satisfaction.
Senator Haines made a quite exaggerated claim that one could drive a fleet of trucks through this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several small trucks.

—I think it would have to be a small skateboard. Somebody as agile as Senator Haines on a little skateboard could possibly get through between a dot and a semicolon somewhere in this legislation. But it is quite absurd for her to say that a fleet of trucks could be driven through it.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation has been achieved after many hours of arduous negotiation. Let us also take some satisfaction from the point that the legislation, though sponsored by the Government, cannot properly be characterised as Government legislation any more. It is truly the result of very constructive dialogue between the Government and the Opposition; between the Government and the staff of Australian Democrat senators, who also had some part to play in bringing matters of concern to the attention of the Government, which in many ways were accommodated; and between the Government and others.

I believe this is one of those rare occasions on which the substance of a Bill is not the first thought or the first option of the Government but is a very considerable improvement on the Bill which the Government first presented to the Parliament. That is shown most dramatically and graphically in the case of the tax file number information. The Government had thought initially that the guidelines that should govern the security and the storage of information, as well as the way in which it is handled and disclosed, should be devised by the Privacy Commission after using an advisory committee and drawing on extensive consultations and discussions within the community, particularly with the private sector which will be bound by those guidelines. It became perfectly obvious that the better way to go was for the Parliament itself to set down guidelines, which it has done in schedule 2 under the heading `Interim guidelines concerning the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information'. I will read the first of those guidelines, which more or less governs the whole. Guideline 1.1 states:
The tax file number is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means.

The Bill then spells out, over a number of pages, that objective by giving practical, specific guidelines, directions and indications as to how that goal or objective should be achieved and safeguarded. This is a very striking illustration of the fact that this legislation has been amended in a very useful and practical way to achieve the safeguarding of privacy which is the concern of all honourable senators.

The Government did not prove obdurate or obstinate. We did not want to hug the original form, or even the amended form, of the legislation to our bosom as though it were sacrosanct. As has been commented on, the House of Representatives accepted the amendment requested by the Senate that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) be given an extended role under which complainants who allege a breach of the information privacy principles (IPP) and who do not receive the compensation that they desire from the Privacy Commissioner, have a right to go to that body.

Certain amendments have not been accepted. I think it is important, because of the rhetoric that has been engaged in, to emphasise particularly the point that Senator Hill made. He said that information held by government agencies ought to be accurate. Of course it ought to be accurate. Difficulties can arise in ensuring the accuracy of information at the time of collection. The Bill recognises the practical difficulties in engaging in a detective type process to ensure absolutely that at the time of collection all the information that is gathered is accurate.

The information privacy principles should be read together. One should not read them in isolation as though each one were segmented, completely separate and apart from the others. For example, principle 7.1 states:

A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall-it is mandatory-take such steps (if any), by way of making appropriate corrections, deletions and additions as are, in the circumstances, reasonable to ensure that the record:
(a) is accurate; and

(b) is, having regard to the purpose for which the information was collected or is to be used and to any purpose that is directly related to that purpose, relevant, up to date, complete and not misleading.
A very strict statutory obligation is placed on the record collector in that way. Information privacy principle 8 requires:
