A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall not use that information without taking such steps (if any) as are, in the circumstances, reasonable to ensure that, having regard to the purpose for which the information is proposed to be used, the information is accurate, up to date and complete.

I think one has an indication of the need to ensure that information held within the bureaucracy which is the basis on which decisions are made is accurate. The fear, misgiving or problem that Senator Haines spoke of should be put to rest.

Other matters have been the subject of comment by Senator Haines. For example, she alleged during the debate that according to the Government and the Opposition it is perfectly all right that persons not know to whom information is disclosed. That must be a reference to information privacy principle 11 which imposes some limitations in respect of the knowledge which a person is required to have of information being disclosed to another agency. What is that exception? Section 1 (e) of principle 11 states:
the disclosure is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the protection of the public revenue.

It is believed that, in those situations, the disclosure should not require the prior consent of the person concerned. The disclosure is noted on the file and that notation is available to the Privacy Commissioner who has the ability to audit all files at any time in any agency. Therefore, the privacy commissioner can check whether this particular exception is being abused.

One will recall, for example, that Mr Ian Temby, the former Director of Public Prosecutions, when speaking earlier this year about the need for exchanges of information by agencies in order to combat fraud on the Commonwealth, said this:

Accepting that there is a need to safeguard the handling of information which may be private, confidential and sensitive nevertheless it becomes an absurdity when fraud on the Commonwealth is facilitated by the enforced lack of communication between agencies.

I believe there are occasions when the Australian Federal Police become aware, for example in an investigation of a drug importer, that a person is obviously deriving income from nefarious and illegal activities. In such cases it is quite proper that the Federal Police should transfer to the Australian Taxation Office the information that they hold in order that the public revenue be safeguarded quite apart from the responsibilities of the Federal Police in relation to the crime of importing drugs. Most people out in the community would see it as a very essential part of the exchange between government agencies that the opportunity, as in that instance to ensure that the public revenue is safeguarded, be taken. It would be absurd to require that the Federal Police inform the suspect, the target of its investigations, that in fact it wishes to transfer certain information to the Tax Office in relation to non-disclosure of revenues.

In so far as this particular matter has been raised as a matter of concern, there are very valid reasons for the exception being made. The appointment of the Privacy Commissioner-I think this is important; I place a lot of faith, as we must, in the person to be appointed as Privacy Commissioner-was agreed to in Cabinet yesterday. Of course, once the Governor-General is properly notified and makes the necessary arrangements in Executive Council, that appointment will be announced. The person concerned is the most important linchpin to the success of this legislation. If that person is of the view that this particular provision has been abused or is subject to some sort of corruption and contamination which takes it beyond what we in the Committee understood to be its scope of operation, I would hope and expect that the Privacy Commissioner in his report to the Parliament would make that abundantly clear and we would naturally be galvanised into action to safeguard privacy or to prevent the abuse which he disclosed.

As to the right to sue in the civil courts, it needs to be emphasised that we believe that-Senator Haines has spoken about the expense, for example, of going to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; I can assure her that it is even more expensive to go to court to enforce a particular right as she would be aware-this mode of operation which has been chosen under this legislation, whereby an approach can be made to the Privacy Commissioner, is more accessible, more attractive to people, less intimidating and will allow the Commissioner to undertake all the work that is necessary to find out the truth of the allegation about a perceived or alleged breach of the privacy principles. This would allow him to try to conciliate in the situation to bring about a remedying of the practice or an alteration of the mode of action of the agency such as is leading to that breach of privacy.

It is important to recall that access to the courts is not, in a sense, entirely excluded. Indeed, if one suspects that a breach of the privacy principles is occurring or one is aware that a breach is occurring, of course one can approach the Federal Court of Australia to get an injunction to prevent that breach. That ability to approach the courts in order to secure an injunction to prevent the breach from occurring or recurring is an important remedy. It will help, as I say, to give a multi- tiered approach, if you like. It will involve the courts. But the primary concern of people to get the Privacy Commissioner to remedy the situation in relation to their loss of a safeguard of their privacy is well provided for in the Bill.

We have legislation before us which represents a very fair-but not completely perfect-culmination of many weeks, many months and many years of endeavour by many people on all sides of the Parliament to give to the Australian people, finally, a statutory right to insist that their privacy be recognised and that safeguards be erected in so far as government agencies hold much information concerning them. In relation to tax file number information, that right has been extended to embrace the private sector in so far as it holds such information.

I wish to say finally that I appreciate very much the support that has been given by officials from the Department and by my private secretary, Dr Jim Gracie, in relation to the very arduous negotiations that have taken place which have produced this Bill which I believe deserves the support of the Committee, and therefore the motion which has been put also deserves the support of the Committee.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Walsh's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have now turned to a matter of great importance in the defence and veterans' community, namely, the long-awaited Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill is based on a proposal which came from the Opposition, so inevitably we feel obliged to support it. We welcome the fact that it has finally reached the Senate. It embraces our policy of privatisation by formalising the sale of the home loans portfolio to Westpac Banking Corporation. We in the Opposition believe that the transfer of responsibility to Westpac brings significant advantages for service men and women in particular. Of course, it also brings benefits to veterans. The first thing we welcome is the elimination of the 10-month waiting period. Mr Deputy President, as a former Navy man you would know only too well that the 10-month waiting period has been far too long. It has been government-induced and it has been held at that figure by successive governments. In some cases it is half a posting for a serviceman and on some occasions it is almost the entire time that a serviceman spends in one area. The elimination of that 10-month waiting period has brought very real financial benefit to service men and women because it has meant that they will no longer be reliant on expensive bridging finance. That is a matter which should be applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: We also welcome the fact that service men and women, if they choose, can go to a one-stop shop. They can get one mortgage from Westpac, which will mean that there is only one lot of establishment fees, and there is no need to go onto a second mortgage with high interest rates in order to meet the cost of financing a home. The Government continues to subsidise the first $25,000 of the interest payments on the loan. The remainder of the loan will be on first mortgage rates rather than second mortgage rates. That is a considerable improvement, in the opinion of the Opposition. I shall have more to say later about the amount of $25,000. This means that there may not need to be any second mortgage rate-in many cases there will not need to be-and there will be no establishment charges.

We also welcome the fact that the concept of portability has now been introduced to the scheme. This is something which we in the Opposition have long urged. We are very glad to see that the Government has taken this element and introduced it into the scheme. This full portability will apply to all loans granted after 9 December last year. It is something that recognises the lifestyle service men and women are forced to live, moving constantly around the country, and it is a benefit which suits that lifestyle. It was a nonsense to have a non-portable loan for those who have to move constantly, often at a moment's notice. It was a very real disincentive for servicemen to stay in the Services. When wives long for a home and their only way of achieving that is to get a once-off defence service home loan, then obviously the serviceman feels in many cases that to care for his wife properly he has to leave the Services and achieve that goal of a defence service home loan. That will no longer be necessary because the loan can be taken up, the house can be sold and the loan can be taken with the serviceman to a new home. That is a major step forward, in our opinion, in improving the conditions of service for defence personnel, and we all recognise how badly those conditions of service need to be improved.

The Bill will help veterans who applied for loans after 9 December 1987. This is one area where we feel that veterans and servicemen who obtained their loans prior to 9 December 1987 are being unfairly treated. This new benefit which is being introduced will not apply to any loans granted prior to that time. It seems discriminatory, it seems quite unfair, and we urge the Government to reconsider this. I hope that it does not cause further disaffection in the Australian Defence Force because obviously, with morale problems being the way they are, we cannot afford any further disaffection there. But also I would have thought that if the Government had much understanding of the needs of retired people and the need to recognise changing lifestyles, it would have enabled older defence service home borrowers to move out of family homes which they had purchased years ago on a defence service home loan and move into smaller retirement housing by making the loan portable so that they could take the loan with them. I urge the Government to look at this. It seems to me it is a minimal cost but a major benefit to those veterans who are in that position.

The Opposition is not disputing the advantages of the Bill but we do believe it is important to remember that there are some major long term problems which have still not been resolved. In that context it is worth while looking at the recommendations of the Cross report on Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force, which was tabled in the Parliament only three or four weeks ago, which addressed a number of matters which affect Defence Force personnel and the enormous wastage that we are suffering. The Cross report said that for the loan to be a valued condition of service its worth needed to be increased and indexed to inflation and that it was currently widely seen as either inadequate or, worse, in terms of wastage, scarcely worth having.

I was at the Army Tattoo on Monday night, which was washed out. I talked to some of the soldiers and non-commissioned officers who were receiving awards at a function at the Tattoo ground. Some of them were saying to me that they were not going to stay around in the forces, that they were concerned about the way things were going in the defence forces, and that the attraction that once was the defence service home loan was no longer good enough to keep them. That is very sad, because successive governments have recognised that the defence service home loan has been a condition of service which in the past-when it was more valuable-was a very real incentive to stay in the forces, to acquire the six years service which would entitle personnel to a loan. That has lost its attraction for the current service men and women.

The amount of the loan was last increased in 1980, when it went up to $25,000. At that time it represented 55 per cent of the median purchase price of a home. But in the last eight years, as we all know only too well, the consumer price index (CPI) has risen 73 per cent. Now that loan is worth only $14,500 in real terms. In that time housing prices have escalated dramatically, and I just draw your attention, Mr Deputy President, to the percentage price escalation in the mainland capital cities. Sydney has gone up 119.5 per cent; Melbourne has gone up 145.1 per cent; Brisbane, 93.3 per cent; Adelaide, 118 per cent; Canberra, 131.3 per cent; and Perth, 62.5 per cent. So what was 55 per cent of the purchase price is now 27 per cent. That is what the loan is deemed to cover now. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), in debate in the House of Representatives, has said:
It has been rightly pointed out that one cannot buy a tent for $25,000 these days.

As the Minister has so clearly recognised the correctness of that statement, I should have thought that she would have been more effective in persuading her Government to increase the amount of the loan. As I have said already, the servicemen are leaving the forces so that they can buy a home, and the Cross report, on page 314, said:
A worthwhile home loan is seen by the Services as a significant retention incentive . . . some members separate in order to use their DFRDB commutation as a deposit on a home . . .

That is the problem-their salaries have dropped by comparison with the cost of living, and they have difficulties being two income families. Therefore, raising a deposit is extremely difficult unless they leave the forces and cash in their Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme (DFRDB) entitlements. If this were changed, we could see our way to encouraging people to stay in the forces and not need to leave in order to get that deposit.

The Cross report was also very clear about the post-1985 people. We have a situation now where the Government is refusing to extend the benefits of this scheme to people who enlisted after May 1985. I find that quite unacceptable. The Cross report says:
As far as post-May 1985 personnel are concerned, some degree of dissatisfaction will persist until the uncertainty over their position is resolved.

The Bill simply ignores the need for increasing the amount of the loan, but the exclusion of the post-1985 enlistees has been a conscious Government decision and is referred to specifically in the legislation. The Government has been saying for some time that it intends to come up with a new scheme for the people who enlisted after May 1985, but the constant failure to come up with the specifics of a scheme has left these people wondering and very unsettled. There is no evidence yet of an alternative scheme for enlistees to pin their hopes on. When we have so much wastage from the Defence Force and when some of the causes have been so clearly pinned down to conditions of service matters, it seems incomprehensible that the Government has not moved faster to try to give the details of a new benefit for these post-1985 people. The Minister has alluded to the fact that they have to spend six years in the Services before they become entitled, but she does not seem to recognise the fact that these people have now served about 3 1/2 years, and all that time there has been nothing positive and concrete given to them. She clearly does not recognise what an unsettling effect that has.

The distinction in the Services of having two lots of service personnel serving side by side, one lot who are serving their six years and becoming entitled to a loan, and the others who at this stage are not entitled and apparently will not be entitled to a loan, is very bad for morale. It simply has to be dealt with; we cannot go on any longer the way the Government has been coasting on this matter. My colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Tim Fischer, tried to impose a legally binding timetable in relation to the scheme for new enlistees by moving a scalpel sunset clause in the lower House. He was thwarted because of the extraordinary construction of the Bill. I refer honourable senators to schedule 1-6.1, 6.2 and 6.3. Westpac is given the power of veto in this legislation over any parliamentary amendment, which allows Westpac to opt out of the agreement. We find that an extraordinary way to do business and it is most unsatisfactory for the Parliament to feel restricted in what it can do to the legislation without totally disrupting all the benefits which we want to flow on quickly to veterans and defence personnel.

In the Committee of the Whole, I intend to move the same amendment that Mr Fischer moved in the House of Representatives. The point needs to be made, and made over and over again, that that problem is a serious one and needs addressing. We must see that people who enlisted after May 1985 become entitled to a meaningful defence service home loan, and preferably they should be treated on exactly the same basis as the colleagues beside whom they serve. The sunset clause will in no way impact on the existing specific agreement with Westpac. It merely says that if the Government has not honoured the promise which it has made to these post-May 1985 enlistees by 14 May 1991, the enlistees will become entitled to this existing defence service home loans scheme as a new category requiring a new additional agreement with Westpac or, alternatively perhaps, with somebody else. The amendment seeks only to protect those who have been left out in the cold by the Government. It does not interfere in any way with the Government's stated aims of providing a new scheme. The Opposition believes that, if the Government is so confident that it will formulate a new scheme in time, it should not be at all worried about accepting our scalpel sunset clause. In fact, we believe that our amendment is very responsible because it acknowledges Westpac's right to negotiate changes to the original agreement in the event of the scalpel being activated.

The coalition accepts Westpac's escape option in the event of substantial alteration of the agreement, although it is not happy about that arrangement. But this Bill, under the terms of schedule 1, is constructed so as to cause anything, even amendments neutral to the agreement with Westpac, to be referred back to Westpac under the escape mechanism.

The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in the debate in the House of Representatives said that our amendment could give a free kick to Westpac. But our view is that the Government's negotiations should have included from the very beginning the post-1985 enlistees and that the Government was very defective in not including them in the original terms to be negotiated with the successful tenderer. We believe that the taxpayer would have got a better offer from the successful tenderer if the group of service people and veterans who were entitled had been wider and had not been finite, as is the case when only people who enlisted up to May 1985 are eligible. We believe also that it would have extended a benefit to those post-May 1985 people. Westpac would have benefited by having a larger pool, a continuing pool, of people coming to it for defence service loans. We seriously believe that the taxpayer would have been considerably better off because the sum paid to the Government by Westpac in buying the rights to the scheme could have been much larger. But even this routine amendment expressing the will of the Parliament and the unanimous will of Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the Cross Committee, theoretically triggers that escape mechanism. It is clear that the parliamentary right to amend the Bill has been severely reduced.

We do not intend to block the Bill because we are acutely aware of the fact that it is already well past the nominal starting date, which is 1 December. I draw attention to a most unfortunate occurrence; that is, that the Department of Veterans' Affairs saw fit to jump the gun and distribute correspondence from the Department and Westpac alerting people to the new scheme. This has been an unfortunate exercise on the part of both the Department and the bank and has led to a poor reaction from many people. I know that a number of my colleagues have had very concerned constituents. It has not been a good start for the Bill. It deserves a better start than the Department and Westpac have given it. I have spoken to Westpac along those lines and expressed my concerns.

Too many people have been waiting too long for the benefits contained in this Bill. Honourable senators will recall the several years of uncertainty as to the changes the Government was intending to make. Back in Senator Gietzelt's time as Minister for Veterans' Affairs we had a couple of unsuccessful attempts to privatise the defence service home loans scheme, and we had the debacle in the Budget last year when the $10,000 grant was proposed and met with such strong and justified resistance. The Opposition does not want the Bill delayed, and nor do many of the people who are waiting for a loan. But we remind the Government that it has serious shortcomings. The amount is too little, the portability is too restricted and the post-1985 people are not provided for. We remind the Government that two of these were the subject of the Cross report recommendations.
I also remind the Senate that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel gave a guarantee on 24 November in the House of Representatives, which I read into the record:

I am not sure at this stage whether exactly the same benefit as that given to the pre-1985s is the best for them, but I can give a guarantee that a form of home ownership will be offered to them and that it will be a very generous benefit . . . honourable members can be sure that those people will be looked after.
Later she said:
. . . I reiterate that guarantee.

I find it somewhat qualified and I am concerned at that. The Minister may not have intended to qualify it but it does not sound to me that there is certainty that these people will be included in this scheme. I am very reluctant to see two schemes operating side by side. The Minister's efforts in this area will be monitored very closely.
The Opposition believes that the best way to deal with the concerns I have outlined in my speech are by way of a second reading amendment. I move:
At end of motion, add ``but the Senate notes that:
(a) there has been a long delay in introducing the proposed legislation to establish a new Defence Service Home Loans Scheme;

(b) without some kind of adjustment, the arrangements entered into by the Commonwealth Government with Westpac are an attempt to deny the Senate its constitutional right to make certain amendments to the proposed legislation;
(c) the proposed new Scheme should not be further delayed, but should be improved as follows:
(i) the amount of the loan should be increased to reflect the current cost of housing;
(ii) holders of loans granted prior to December 1987 should enjoy a right to portability;
(iii) Defence Force personnel who enlisted since May 1985 should be included in the proposed Scheme; and
(iv) a review of the Scheme should be provided for after the first 2 years of operation''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill I urge honourable senators not to lose sight of the dual objectives of the defence service home loans scheme. On the one hand, it is a recognition of the efforts of past and present service personnel; on the other it is, or was, an incentive for civilians to join our forces. It is not the intention of the Australian Democrats to obstruct the passage of this Bill. In principle we support it but we have some serious comment to make about the manner in which it has been brought before the Senate and about its serious deficiencies, to which we will address ourselves in committee stage amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in his second reading speech outlined the Government's rationale behind the decision to sell the assets of the Defence Service Homes Corporation to the Westpac Banking Corporation. Sadly, the Bill does not stand up to the scrutiny in these terms and appears to be of greater benefit to the Government and Westpac than to present and past defence personnel. That is not to say that it is not a relative improvement over the circumstances in which borrowers now find themselves. The Bill will be somewhat of a windfall for the Government as Westpac will pay a premium of $100m for its involvement in the scheme. In addition, the Government will save $11.5m per annum through retrenchment or reassignment of the 360 Defence Service Homes Corporation staff.

Among the apparent benefits to eligible persons outlined by the Minister in his second reading speech are the removal of the 10-month waiting period for concessional loans and the opportunity to borrow in excess of $25,000 at a first mortgage interest rate without incurring additional establishment charges. The Australian Democrats advocate that on closer examination of these supposed benefits it is revealed that they are inaccurate or at best dubious grounds on which to base support for the legislation before us. The Australian Democrats, of course, welcome the removal of the 10-month waiting period. However, to suggest, as the Government has suggested, that this will save borrowers thousands of dollars in bridging finance is a spurious argument. A modicum of planning would ensure that would-be borrowers availed themselves of the $25,000 concessional loan well before entering the real estate market in search of a home, thereby negating the need for any bridging finance.

As for the ability to borrow money in excess of the $25,000 concessional loan at first mortgage interest rates, the Government is pulling the wool over service personnel's eyes on two counts. Firstly, the simple fact is that if the concessional loan were raised to more realistic levels which reflected the rise in property values around Australia, as outlined earlier by Senator Newman, many eligible persons would not need additional mortgages, or at least would need only a very small second mortgage.

As it stands, the concessional loan will be a useful contribution to the major loan provided by Westpac at market rates. This raises the second and more deceitful point with respect to the alleged benefits, namely that home buyers will be able to borrow in excess of $25,000 at first mortgage interest rates. Following deregulation in April 1986, banks have ceased to offer so-called cocktail home loans consisting of first home loans at a subsidised rate and additional top-up loans at a more expensive interest rate. All current home loans are at a market rate, currently 14.5 per cent interest per annum, and banks, including Westpac, generally only make a distinction between owner-occupied in commercial properties to charge varying rates of interest. Therefore, there is no advantage for eligible defence service home buyers to borrow additional money in excess of $25,000 with Westpac or any other bank under the proposed scheme compared with previous arrangements other than saving two sets of loan establishment charges. However, given that these are of a one-off nature and of an average of $800 to $900 they do not constitute a compelling argument for the transfer from the present format. The Australian Democrats have no objection to the proposed transfer to Westpac provided the new scheme ensures a significant improvement in benefits to recipients of defence service home loans.

This brings me to a matter of even greater concern and that is the manner in which the Bill has been drafted and introduced. It is rare for a Bill to be passed through both Houses of this Parliament without amendments as various parties and community organisations seek to make changes which will optimise its benefits to their interest groups. However, this normal process has been denied under the present Bill-or there has been an attempt to deny it. For those honourable senators who may not have had the time to study the Bill in detail, I point out that we have before us an unprecedented piece of legislation to which, in effect, no major amendments can be made.

The manner in which the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill has been drafted is such that should any amendments be passed which are unacceptable to Westpac, Westpac can withdraw from the agreement altogether. This is legislation by decree. It makes a mockery of the normal parliamentary process through quashing any amendments that might otherwise arise from debate on the matter. To add insult to injury, the Government has gone one step further. Through this piece of extraordinary legislative drafting not only has it effectively stifled debate on the Bill or amendment to the Bill but also it has pre-empted any decisions that Parliament may have reached by sending out letters to the current holders of concessional loans informing them of a likely transfer before it has even been debated in both Houses. One wonders whether an improvement in the provision of service to veterans is a priority of this Government, or whether it is more concerned with cutting costs through the retrenchment and deployment of 360 Defence Service Homes Corporation staff as part of a larger strategy to absorb the function of the Department of Veterans' Affairs among generic State and Commonwealth agencies. We have made a reference to what we believe to be that intention in earlier questions and statements in the appropriations debate.

We suggest that the manner in which this legislation has been introduced into this chamber and the manner in which the public notification has been made is utterly presumptuous. For the Government to place before the Senate a Bill which it says it cannot amend is without precedent and should be totally unacceptable to honourable senators.

I also wonder whether the Government is aware of an extraordinary irony that may arise should the scheme be transferred to a private banking corporation such as Westpac. I am referring to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 18 August 1988 which noted that the most cost effective funding method for Westpac to take over the Defence Service Homes Corporation would be `to tap the secondary mortgage market and to effectively convert the loans into marketable securities'. Should such a scenario unfold it would lead to large parcels of Defence Force home mortgages going to Japanese investors. Thus the Government may find itself in the embarrassing position of having facilitated a process whereby the guarantors of loans to Australian veterans are the very members of nations which our service personnel fought against during World War II. It is of no substance or consequence 40 years after the event, but it is an interesting irony to note.

I move on to a number of proposed Democrat amendments and requests for amendments which will significantly improve the scheme for eligible home buyers in spite of the limitations which have been imposed upon us. The Democrats reject the suggestion that under any circumstances this House of review does not have the right of amendment. It is interesting to draw a comparison between these amendments which we will move at the committee stage and which we circulated yesterday with the proposed amendments that have just been circulated as a second reading motion amendment proposed by the Opposition. We will develop more this coincidence and the relative attitudes of the Democrats to the process of amendment and that which may reveal to be the case with the Opposition's strategy in relation to a second reading motion amendment.

I refer now to the foreshadowed Democrat amendments. Firstly, as stated earlier, in view of current real estate values and of the recommendation by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the Cross Committee, to significantly increase concessional loans, the Australian Democrats will introduce an amendment to increase the loan for eligible home buyers to $45,000. The second of our proposed amendments seeks to remove a further anomaly which exists simply because defence personnel do not apply at the right time, and that is the portability of concessional loans. Currently, only those personnel who obtain a loan after December 1987 enjoy portability. Given that employment in the forces frequently entails transfers to other interstate and intrastate locations, often at short notice, defence personnel may be forced to sell their homes at regular intervals. Portability, therefore, is essential. The Democrats will move an amendment which seeks to extend portability of concessional loans to those who borrowed prior to December 1987. Thirdly, under present regulations certain World War II ex-service women who undertook home service but did not serve in overseas postings are ineligible for defence service home loans. While the number of women who would be eligible or who, in view of their age, would wish to seek such a loan may be small, the Democrats wish to rectify this anomaly to ensure such loans are provided to defence personnel irrespective of their sex.

In addition to these amendments the Democrats will also seek a number of assurances from the Government in the following areas. Firstly, we seek an assurance from the Government that it will review its decision to exclude persons whose first service in the Defence Force began after 14 May 1985-in other words, the post-1985ers, to whom Senator Newman referred earlier, who are not embraced by the provisions of this Bill. We have the assurance from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, that she will address this anomaly in the very near future. Clearly, this decision will do little to stem the flow of personnel who leave the forces. Nor will it provide an incentive to those contemplating joining them unless the anomaly is rectified promptly.

The Democrats will also seek an undertaking from the Government to facilitate the establishment of an agency which would provide a range of real estate services, for want of a better term, to Defence Force personnel. This unit would specifically enable defence home owners to sell, lease, exchange or let their homes more readily, perhaps to other service personnel, should the need arise. Such a scheme would be particularly meritorious when one considers the frequency with which personnel are transferred, often at short notice, and when one acknowledges that a wife and family are often left while the husband goes off early to take up a posting with the difficult task of finding a new lessee or, alternatively, selling the home. The Democrats believe that such a facility would be of great merit.

Finally, the Democrats seek an assurance from the Government that the new scheme will be reviewed after two years by an independent committee to ensure that service personnel are in no way deleteriously affected by the new arrangements. If the Westpac Banking Corporation sees fit to withdraw from the agreement as a result of any amendments passed in this chamber, one may well ask whose needs are really serviced by this Bill. If Westpac is truly committed to providing a service to the defence forces, it should welcome the implementation of any recommendations made by the Cross Committee and the Senate. The community should welcome Westpac's willingness to adopt and maintain such a service to the mutual advantage, it would seem, of all parties. Therefore, I advise that in essence the Australian Democrats support the intent of this Bill but we believe that it is inadequate and we will attempt to rectify those inadequacies in committee stage amendments. Above all, we abhor the manner in which this Bill was brought before the Senate and its drafting in a deliberate attempt to deprive the chamber of its entitled process of review and constructive amendment of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill, or the Westpac Bill as it is more commonly known in defence and veterans' circles throughout Australia. It is heartening to see that the Government is embarking upon a program of adopting coalition policy. It is privatising a significant government operation. I hope that the Government will continue to implement our policies. Some improvement would perhaps then be seen in the way military personnel and retired service men and women are treated in this country instead of the slaphappy attitudes experienced these days.

SPEECH.PARA: The defence service home loans scheme was first established in 1918 to assist those who served overseas during World War I to re-establish themselves in civilian life. Eligibility for benefits was extended to include those who served or were appointed or enlisted to serve overseas in World War II and later conflicts. In order to attract and retain regular service men and women in an all-volunteer Defence Force, in 1973 the benefits were extended to members of the Defence Force who completed the required qualifying service, currently six years.

On 14 May 1985, in one of this Government's regular May economic statements, it announced that it would privatise the defence service home loans scheme. Today, after 3 1/2 years, it has finally reached an agreement with the Westpac Banking Corporation. This Bill provides for the new scheme and enacts the agreement, schedule 1, on the basis of a $25,000 loan scheme at a blended rate of 6.85 per cent. The delay of 10 months in processing applications is also effectively eliminated for eligible veterans and peacetime service personnel. While I commend the Government for finally trying to get something right by improving conditions for our service personnel, I want to raise some inconsistencies in this treatment. I wish to point out that the specific exclusion--
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity this afternoon to make some comments about the Australian scholastic aptitude test and its use especially in Queensland, the State that I represent. More particularly, I wish to outline to students and parents that errors which occurred in this particular test this year are far less likely to occur again. The Australian scholastic aptitude test, or ASAT as it is normally called, was developed by the Australian Council for Educational Research, or ACER, for the Board of Secondary School Studies in Queensland, the accrediting agency in the Australian Capital Territory and the Secondary Education Authority of Western Australia. It is used in Queensland to help determine students' tertiary entrance scores. The TE score, as the tertiary entrance score is called in Queensland, is of extreme importance to students who are about to complete their secondary schooling or who have just completed their year 12. The score is critical for those who wish to enter a tertiary institution and for those who aim to enter a particular faculty or school at a post-secondary educational institution.

SPEECH.PARA: With demand for tertiary places being so strong, students aim to achieve as high a TE score as possible. It is not surprising that students approach the completion of their ASAT papers with a great deal of concern, so it is possible to understand statements during the year when, as students were completing their ASAT papers, an error was discovered. A demand was made to set that test aside and require students to sit a further test about six weeks later. The editorial in the Brisbane Sun of Friday 26 August this year well reflected the anger of many year 12 students and their parents. That editorial stated, under a heading of `Kids pay for adult foul-up':

As if it isn't tough enough for Queensland's year 12 students already. The fact that they have to sit for the Australian Scholastic Aptitude (ASAP) Test in the first place as part of their quest for a tertiary education is hard.
But now they have to do it again because some people who should have known better fouled up. It's not good enough to just say sorry and add that no student would be disadvantaged.
The fact is, it was someone's fault and everyone who has to do the test a second time has to be disadvantaged.
In case the oldies have forgotten, there's something about getting psyched up for a test which almost certainly will have a bearing on the rest of your life.
To have to line up and do it all again must be very draining at a time when our teenagers need all their energies for their other studies.
In the first place, the Australian Council for Educational Research in Melbourne, controlled locally by the Board of Secondary School Studies, should be given a quick kick where it hurts.
Then the Minister should find out who in Queensland was supposed to check the test and deliver a swift kick there, too.
If someone had taken time to have a quick look at the test it surely would have been noticed that not one of the three answers given in the multiple-choice question was correct.
Let's face it, if one of the 28,000 students who did the test didn't read the question properly and made a similar blue it could have cost him or her dearly in the long run.

Queensland year 12 students duly presented themselves for the second sitting of the ASAT test and one can just imagine their horror when they read in the next morning's newspaper that there were further printing errors in that test as well. The Queensland Board of Secondary School Studies executive officer stated that the errors were not such that a third test was required, but this was little comfort for the 30,000 or so students who had completed the test for the second time. By now they would have lost faith in the testing process and no doubt many would be worrying about the effect of all of this bungling on the TE scores. I was sufficiently concerned at about this stage to issue a press statement criticising those involved in the preparation of the test. Amongst many other things, I stated:
. . . the Federal Government annually pays about $550,000 to the Australian Council for Educational Research (ACER), the body which compiles the ASAT test.
If the errors on either occasion have their source in the ACER, the Federal Government's contribution to that body must be seriously questioned. . . .
If the errors occurred in Queensland, a giant administrative shake up is necessary.
. . . the Queensland and Federal Governments should immediately investigate the circumstances surrounding the errors and announce to the public what remedial action will be taken.

I am sure that my views were identical to those of many students and parents in Queensland. After my comments were drawn to the attention of the Director of ACER, Dr Barry McGaw, he was good enough to write to me about what he termed `the difficulties that were experienced with the Australian scholastic aptitude test in Queensland this year'. Dr McGaw indicated to me that ASAT test drafts are first trialed in New Zealand. To me, this seems to be a excellent procedure. It allows data to be obtained from the testing of a group to which the final version would not be administered. On the basis of analysis of data collected in New Zealand an Australian scholastic aptitude test is created. This test is subject to scrutiny by the agencies who have commissioned it. Some changes may be made at this meeting. It appears that it is during this process, when changes were made to the draft test, that errors occurred. It is not necessary to dwell on what did occur this year but I am pleased to be able to report that Dr McGaw has indicated to me that the ACER's procedures in this critical area have been reviewed and some significant changes have been made. I quote Dr McGaw's letter. He stated, amongst other things:

In particular, we have proposed that any changes to items suggested at that final meeting be made during the meeting, be checked by the participants and be formally approved. When the final form of the test is then prepared, we will have two external experts take the full test. We will also send it to the three commissioning agencies for them to check and authorise prior to the production of the film from which printing is undertaken. These extra checks will make the timeline tighter but we believe they are now necessary and justified.

I am satisfied that ACER has now taken every reasonable step to ensure that errors such as those which plagued the ASAT this year will not occur in the future. Students who sit for the ASAT next year, and in following years, have every reason to be certain that they will not be confused by errors in their test papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obliged to advise the Senate of a very serious allegation of corruption which has been made to me by three constituents and which is the subject of two affidavits and other relevant documents which convince me that there is substance in the allegations that I am about to outline.

SPEECH.PARA: It is alleged that senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank have in the past colluded in a corrupt practice by which businesses receiving funds from the Bank have been deliberately manipulated into bankruptcy and then acquired by other predetermined parties. It is further alleged by these constituents that these allegations have for several years been known to the Australian Federal Police and that the victims of these practices claim that the Federal Police have failed in their duties in these matters. I have a copy of the statement of claim filed in the Supreme Court of New South Wales on Thursday, 1 December, which began an action by one of the constituents in relation to these matters. I am advised also, through discussions that I have had with members of the staff of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), that these matters are currently the subject of an investigation by the Federal Police and that this current investigation is as a result of a referral by the Commonwealth Bank itself in April of this year.

I am just briefly advising the Senate of these very serious allegations. I feel obliged to do so by virtue of their being brought to me by a number of constituents. I am convinced that there is sufficient substance in the allegations for the matters to be brought before the Senate and to become the subject of questions to the Minister in order to seek his response. I would anticipate that I will probably return to this matter of public interest on a later occasion.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill, and I guess that is not surprising as in fact we have demanded a National Crime Authority (NCA) office in South Australia for some time-a demand that was at first rejected strenuously by the State Government in South Australia, and it was not the subject of much enthusiasm from the Hawke Federal Government either. Clearly this Bill is so structured as to enable the appointment of an extra member of the Authority to take up a specific reference, and that specific reference is related to South Australia. We are therefore pleased that finally the Government of South Australia and the Commonwealth Government came to the conclusion that the appointment of a new member of the Authority and the setting up of an office in South Australia was necessary and was the most appropriate response to the worrying elevation of organised crime and official corruption that has become apparent in South Australia. I do not know whether the levels of organised crime and official corruption have become higher or whether it has simply over a period of time become more widely appreciated by the people of South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to a rather sorry story of camouflage and cover-up by the South Australian Government in an attempt to sweep under the carpet the situation developing in South Australia rather than face its responsibilities as a Government to counter effectively organised crime and to root out the official corruption that is necessary for organised crime to exist. That brings me back to a speech I made in the Senate some months ago which I guess started the development of the process that has led to this Bill. My comments in relation to South Australia were really simply incidental to the principal purpose of the speech, which was to respond to the evaluation of the NCA by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which has responsibility for monitoring the Authority.

Honourable senators will recall that the Committee was established under the National Crime Authority Act because of the special coercive powers that had been given to the new Authority and the belief that if such powers were to be given then there had also, on the other side of the ledger, to be greater safeguards than we would normally associate with law enforcement bodies. So this unique monitoring committee was established, a committee that is unique to the law enforcement process in Australia. That Committee, as I indicated a moment ago, reported to the Parliament on its initial evaluation of the NCA's operations.

As the Senate will be aware, there have been some criticisms of the way in which the NCA has operated and there have been some highly publicised acquittals that have raised questions about the competence and methodology of the NCA. I was saying in that speech that the performance of the NCA had to be judged against difficulties that it was encountering in its operations, and I made specific reference to the fact that the liaison officer who had been appointed for Queensland to liaise with the National Crime Authority on behalf of the State police force had been found to be corrupt and, at that time, the police liaison officer appointed by South Australia was before the courts. The case against him has since been dismissed but, putting the matter in its context at that time, I was saying that the NCA's performance must be judged against these extraordinary difficulties that it was encountering in its operations. I referred to the level of police corruption in Queensland that was becoming apparent from the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into possible illegal activities and Associated Police Misconduct, and I referred to levels of police corruption that have been well known for a long time in New South Wales. I said that, regrettably, South Australia was not exempt from this picture. As I work in the eastern States, I can read newspaper reports of criminal cases proceeding in South Australia that are subject to suppression orders in that State. In South Australian newspapers names, charges and circumstances are suppressed. Therefore, because these things were on the public record in the eastern States, there was reason at that time to be concerned about what was happening in South Australia.

I was aware that the then head of the drug squad in South Australia was before the courts, the person who had been selected by the police to head up `Operation Noah', to call upon South Australians to come forward with information that could bring to justice those who were committing offences associated with drugs. I was aware that the allegation being made against him, the head of the drug squad in South Australia, was that he was selling drugs out of police headquarters. Exhibits from previous cases were taken with such confidence that he would not be apprehended that the exhibit numbers were not even being removed from the drugs before they were sold. I believed that anyone who had that information had to be concerned with what was going on in South Australia. How could the system be so faulty that the head of the drug squad could be engaging in this illegal activity with such great confidence that there was no chance of him being apprehended?

I remind the Senate of the circumstances in which he was apprehended. It was out of a reference given to the National Crime Authority into drug matters, and out of that reference the NCA had staked out a marijuana plantation. Lo and behold, they found the head of the South Australian Drug Squad visiting the plantation.

I said at the time in this Parliament, without being able to relate those circumstances in detail-that would have prejudiced the case in South Australia and been in breach of the South Australian suppression order-that I was concerned about what was happening in relation to organised crime in South Australia and I was concerned that the police at the highest levels were not making sufficient effort to counter it. Those comments seemed to me to be moderate and reasonable in the circumstances. I was therefore stunned by the reaction of the State Government, to the effect that how dare I suggest that there could be this organised crime or official corruption in South Australia. The State Government was totally aware of all the matters of which I was aware-those that were on the public record in the eastern States and, furthermore, other information with which the NCA was keeping it up to date. Yet the Government still came out publicly and said, `How dare you say these things are happening in South Australia. What you are doing is defaming the whole of the South Australian Police Force'. As if that was not bad enough, the Police Commissioner then got brought into it to give an unprecedented press conference, to bucket me, to say how dare I suggest that there are problems in the South Australian Police Force, even when the Police Commissioner knew that the head of his own drug squad was before the courts. One of the most sorry aspects of this whole matter is the way in which the South Australian Government was prepared to use the head of the Police Force in South Australia in that way.

Then, of course, the editorials came in, with the Adelaide Advertiser and the Adelaide News asking, `How can Hill make these suggestions about South Australia, the finest police force in the world? What right has he got to damn the whole of the police force?' Of course none of the editorial writers had bothered to read the speech that I had made in the Senate in which I indicated that I believed the South Australian problem was an isolated one and, furthermore, that the vast majority of South Australian police are excellent officers doing a wonderful job in difficult circumstances, underpaid and under-rewarded. Did anybody bother about that sort of detail? No. What the State Government had to do was deflect the criticism rather than face up to it, which is what it should have done. It was not prepared to do so.

So there I am being bucketed by the State Government and bucketed by the Police Commissioner, both of whom had all the information I had. But they knew that my arm was tied behind my back, and unless I was going to be totally irresponsible I would not be able to come back and justify what I had said because I was not going to prejudice cases that were before the court and I was not going to break confidences arising from information given to the NCA monitoring committee of which I was a member. I must say that being treated in that way by a State Government in order for it to camouflage and cover up its inadequacies in this area has been the most enlightening experience that I have had in my 7 1/2 years in this business.

From there, Madam Deputy President, unfortunately the position did not improve. These matters started to become public, and the Moyes case became public after his conviction-and he pleaded guilty; he admitted what was going on in police headquarters. What associates he had in the corrupt enterprise has never been established. The police line is that he had none. Is that really tenable; is it believable that he could be so confident as to engage in this corrupt business and no-one else in the police force knew anything about it? When that came onto the public record the State Government reluctantly acknowledged that it had a problem and that it had to do something. What was its answer? It said that it would set up an anti-corruption body within the South Australian Police Force. It knew that that would be ineffective. It would be ineffective because police officers simply would not come forward to give information to a body that was within their own police force. So it sought to provide an ineffective answer to this problem.

Then, of course, the pattern continued. More information became public, and the Government realised that it had to do something else. The Channel 10 program, Page 1, detailed how the drug squad in South Australia for years had been engaging in illegal activity itself. That allegation was never properly answered; never even properly denied. Nothing happened as a result of that program, but public concern rose. Newspapers were starting to become interested in the level of corruption and the level of organised crime in South Australia.

Then the Adelaide Advertiser interviewed a protected witness of the NCA, referred to as Mr X, who gave detailed revelations of criminal activity in South Australia and the names of those who had been associated with it. The Advertiser gives the information to the police. The police say, `This is wonderful new information. Thank you for being so helpful'. But the police have always been properly advised by the NCA; kept informed. That is what we are led to believe. But anyway, the police responded to the new information. The Advertiser stories brought greater public expressions of concern and the State Government realised that it had to do more than provide an internal anti-corruption office, especially since calls were starting to be made for public inquiries. A member of the State Parliament was starting to call for the setting up of a permanent public anti-corruption body-the worst thing that could possibly happen for the State Government.

I was saying all along that that was not the way to go. If the problem in South Australia was isolated pockets of corruption, a major permanent public anti-corruption body, or royal commission, was not the way to go. It might have been in different circumstances in other places, but in public inquiries the innocent get hurt as well as the guilty and there was not enough evidence on the table for me to come forward-which I could have, and some would have said it would have been a good political angle-and say there should be this public inquiry. I said there should be an NCA office set up in South Australia because it could get the correct focus. The focus would be on organised crime and out of that organised crime would come evidence of the official corruption which, as I said a moment ago, allows all corruption to exist and unfortunately to flourish. So an NCA office would have set the right focus. It had the skilled personnel; it had the experience of three or four years' operation, particularly in the eastern States, in which time expertise had been built up; it would operate in private so that no damage would be done to innocent reputations; and it would be independent of the South Australian Police Force so it would enable people to come forward with confidence. It seemed to me in all the circumstances that that was the right response to this particular problem.

For months the South Australian Government said `We won't do it'. But then, because of the community pressures that were being built up, it finally said, `Okay. We will do it'. In fact, it came out and said, `This is the perfect answer to the problem'. Astonishing! But even then it was not prepared to go the whole way and make it workable, because it intended to provide a downgraded version. It would not have been headed up by a new member of the Authority at all; it would in effect have been a branch office. That would have been ineffective because unless there was a person heading it up of sufficient stature to give confidence to those who had information within the community and who, with good reason, were scared to come forward and give that information, they simply would not come forward; the NCA would not get the information it needed, and it would prove ineffective. Ultimately, when we pressed this on the Government, it said, `Okay, we will appoint a new member of the Authority' and we therefore come to this Bill appointing a new member of the Authority and giving that member a specific reference to deal with the South Australian problem. The terms of reference were made public, ultimately, by the South Australian Government. Senator Tate actually took the correct position when--

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual.

—Nobody has heard any criticism from me of Senator Tate in this exercise, but the Senate will hear a lot of the South Australian Government and the Police Minister. They provided terms of reference. But then we find out, not from Senator Tate but from Dr Hopgood, that stated in the material that supports the terms of reference are the names of 56 individuals-56 principal targets.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say-and I have known a bit about this business over the last six months-that I was stunned to hear that. It indicated to me that the problem was much more widespread, much more complex, and a much greater problem than I ever envisaged existed. I had talked about isolated pockets of corruption, because that is all I knew of. But it now seems, on the basis of the information that the Government has put forward, that the problem is much greater. If the State Government knew all along that that was the extent of the problem, as it must have because it would have been kept properly informed by the NCA, why did it not act? Why did it continually push this matter under the carpet? When we said, in the last few days, that we are now worried by the extent of this problem in South Australia if there are 56 principal targets, Dr Hopgood's response is, `Don't take any notice of that. That doesn't really mean much; it is all pub talk'. I can tell you, Madam Deputy President, that the NCA would not agree to the inclusion of those names in that reference if there was not evidence sufficient to warrant further investigation. They are not simply names about whom allegations have been made. People are not listed as principal targets in NCA investigations into organised crime or official corruption unless there is sufficient evidence to warrant further investigation to see whether that evidence is such that these people can be brought before the courts. So the problem in South Australia is much more extensive and deep-rooted than ever I imagined.

I am concerned still about a number of things. I am pleased that this matter has gone as far as it has today, but I am concerned about the composition of that list of names. Who determined that list? Senator Tate said in this place, `I had no part to do with it', and then we find from Dr Hopgood that it was a list determined by Justice Stewart, head of the NCA, the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and Dr Hopgood, the State Police Minister. What role have the Federal Attorney-General and the State Police Minister in determining the composition of the list of principal targets? Is there a political input? One becomes suspicious because we are told by the State Government that all of those about whom serious accusations are made in the Mr X tapes are included in the investigation. But then we are told, `No ex-politicians are included', and yet we know that ex-politicians were included in the Mr X tapes. What is going on? We do not know. We still do not know the extent of the investigation; we do not know how widespread the Government knows the corruption is. We have not been brought into the Government's confidence in that regard. We now do not know whether an NCA office is a sufficient response if the problem is much greater than we ever envisaged.

We experienced this same veil of secrecy with the State Government in relation to a request by the NCA monitoring committee for the balance of the last NCA report on the problems in South Australia. As the Senate may be aware, the State Government put down in the Parliament only the last chapter of that report. But in that chapter allegations were made by the NCA about law enforcement bodies in South Australia, and whether they had been doing their job properly. The monitoring committee has a responsibility to ensure, if the NCA is to make such statements, that they are well-founded, that they are justified. The monitoring committee cannot do that without putting that statement in the context of the balance of the report. So the Committee on the National Crime Authority-a committee that comprises members of both sides of this Parliament and both chambers-then wrote to the State Attorney-General, saying, `We would appreciate the balance of this report, obviously with the names of people excised. We are not interested in operational detail like that but we are interested in being able to determine whether the NCA is doing its job properly'. What happens? The State Government, through Mr Sumner, confers with the Federal Attorney-General and says `No, we are not going to provide you with that material'. In other words, they were not going to provide us with the material that is necessary for our monitoring committee to do its job properly. Why is that matter being covered up? I do not know. I know that the Federal Attorney-General has been given a copy of the report with the consent of Mr Sumner. Why not the committee of the Parliament that has the responsibility to monitor the performance of the NCA? I do not know.

There are other matters that I am concerned about in relation to this new body. I am concerned not only about the fact that the 56 names have been determined by a political process, but also about the fact that the operation is going to be totally funded by State Government. This is the only instance to my knowledge-the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) might correct me when he speaks-where a State government has been solely providing the funding. As honourable senators would know, under this Bill when the reference ceases the new member of the Authority ceases to exist, and the reference will cease when the funding ceases. So the State Government has still got control of this reference, and it shoud not have in view of its record in relation to this matter. The Commonwealth should be playing a role also. So that is another concern that I have. I am concerned as to whether the funding will be maintained. I look forward to learning who has been appointed to be the member of the Authority to take on this task, because that is going to be critically important. As Senator Tate has had an input into that, I know that it will not be some political crony-unless, of course, the State Government in South Australia has determined who it will be.

So a number of problems will continue to exist after this Bill is passed. Until we have before us the full picture of organised crime and official corruption in South Australia, until the State Government comes clean and faces up to its responsibility in this area rather than trying to avoid the political odium that flows from its totally unsatisfactory performance in this area, we will not know what is the total and correct response to this particular problem. I welcome the fact that the Government has finally been drawn to this position. I welcome the fact that a new member of the Authority will be appointed and that there will be a permanent office in South Australia that will have the capacity at least to take steps towards countering the scourge of organised crime and official corruption in my State. I only regret that it has been such a difficult and tortuous path to get to this stage. I certainly commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it amendments to the National Crime Authority Act which will enable the National Crime Authority to establish an office in South Australia-not merely a branch office but an office which will be headed by a member of the Authority; that is, a person with all the powers and functions which are bestowed on Mr Justice Stewart and the other two members of the National Crime Authority at the moment. I think that indicates a very real desire on the part of both the South Australian Government and this Government, in so far as it is facilitating the passage of this legislation, to investigate the very serious allegations of corruption and of organised criminal activity and, embracing that, drug trafficking, that have been made in relation to events and persons in South Australia. The fact is that it was only a couple of weeks ago, on 24 November, that the intergovernmental committee of the National Crime Authority, meeting in Queensland, decided that this reference was warranted, and it did so on the basis of a report from the South Australian Government, which naturally acted on the advice of its Commissioner of Police, that the South Australian law enforcement authorities were unable by the use of ordinary police methods to get to the heart of the corruption and the illegal activity, the organised criminal activity including drug trafficking, which was alleged to be occurring in South Australia on a scale which it was beyond their abilities to cope with even with the best will in the world. I certainly assume on the part of the Commissioner an honest and best will to combat corruption and organised criminal activity in South Australia, but particularly where the corruption involves police officers there are all the dangers of the undermining of our way of life and, indeed, of our confidence in the democratic processes themselves. If the police forces, the law enforcement authorities on whom ordinary citizens citizens rely for an impartial enforcement of the laws passed by our parliaments, cannot be relied upon we are in great strife.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is in relation to that recognition by the inter-governmental committee of the National Crime Authority that this Bill is brought before the chamber, to enable this office to be set up. It will be set up and there are certain targets who have been nominated, but I think it is important to emphasise that certainly I do not know the names of the targets. Senator Hill says that Dr Hopgood has indicated that there are some 56 of them. I do not know the number but that may well be the case. The names of course-and I think some reassurance is required-are as agreed to by the National Crime Authority and the relevant Minister in South Australia. But I do not think one should emphasise the term `agreement' as if it were the case that the National Crime Authority would somehow be restricted or beholden to the view of the South Australian Government as to who might appear on that list. It is inconceivable to me and I am sure to all honourable senators in this chamber that Mr Justice Stewart would accept a proposition that a member of the National Crime Authority be given a term of reference with the scope of the investigation already being predetermined, as it were, by a narrowly drawn range of targets being circumscribed so that they were the only persons in respect of whom the special coercive powers conferred on the Authority could be brought into play in order to gather the admissible evidence which one hopes will be the result of the investigations undertaken.

That brings me to the point that Senator Hill raised concerning who will be the member of the Authority to undertake this particular reference. I cannot disclose the name of that person because the matter will finally go, on passage of this legislation, to the Executive Council and the Governor-General next Wednesday. It will only be after then that the name can properly be disclosed. I can assure Senator Hill that the person concerned will be of sufficient eminence and of sufficient experience to enable him to conclude that the investigation will be under expert supervision, and because of the nature of the experience of the person concerned this new member should focus, as is required in the legislation, on the compiling of admissible evidence. We do not want yet another investigation which does not lead to properly founded cases in the courts; we want cases which, if they get to the courts, one hopes will succeed if the prosecution can prove the elements of the various offences beyond reasonable doubt.

The funding to be undertaken by the State Government was a matter which Senator Hill mentioned as though once again this could be used as a lever to enable the State Government to sabotage the investigation should it get too close to the bone, perhaps. I think that is the inference. I believe once again that Senator Hill has painted a very unrealistic scenario. The fact is that the State Government has undertaken to establish the office and to provide for all its operating costs. That will be a considerable expenditure. I think just between now and the end of this financial year expenditure will total $1.4m, and therefore over the full succeeding financial year it will be around $2.8m to $3m. So it is a very considerable amount of money that is being put to this task by the State Government.

I believe, by the way, that this problem warrants very considerable money being put into it. Members of the public might not fully realise that when the National Crime Authority does establish an operation under a term of reference and with certain targets in mind the office or team which it establishes include not only policemen seconded from various police forces throughout Australia but also lawyers, accountants, special investigators, intelligence analysts, surveillance officers and administrative and other support staff. So the full team will be there in South Australia undertaking this investigation and it is quite unreal to suggest, if there were any attempt to withdraw funds because the South Australian Government thought that the matter had reached a certain point where further investigation should not be undertaken, that Mr Justice Stewart would not inform the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority on this frustration of a term of reference, that he would not inform the inter-governmental committee consisting of all Attorneys from around Australia of this fact. Indeed, I believe he would inform the Parliament of this fact as under the Statute, as I recall, he is entitled so to do in his annual report. So I believe that those particular fears are unfounded and Senator Hill's misgivings will not be realised.

Since we need to get through another Bill I will not linger on the National Crime Authority Bill. It is extremely important legislation. The task to be undertaken by the National Crime Authority is particularly suited to its mode of operation-to, as Senator Hill said, the proper secrecy-with which it operates and to the very considerable powers with which it is vested. I am pleased that the Parliament is now reaching the point where it will enable his home State, about which I know he has a very genuine concern as to the integrity of its law enforcement capability and as to the presence of organised crime, and the people of South Australia to be well served by this National Crime Authority office, established under this legislation at the request of the South Australia Government. I now table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the revision?

—Senator Hill will recall that in the House of Representatives a matter was taken out of the law and justice omnibus Bill and placed in this Bill for ease of comprehension for those who wish to deal with National Crime Authority matters in one bundle.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. It is an omnibus Bill dealing with a number of amendments to a number of different pieces of legislation that relate to the Attorney-General's portfolio. It seeks to amend the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act to provide for term appointments. That seems to us to be a sound improvement to that Act, offering greater flexibility in the staffing of the Tribunal, so obviously that has our support. It seeks to amend the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, again to give greater flexibility in administration in that it will give the Commissioner, not the Minister, power to determine the number of officers in the various rank levels of the Australian Federal Police. No doubt that will relate to funding restraints, but it seems to us to be a worthwhile improvement in the Federal Police legislation. The Bill also seeks to incorporate the various merit principles in promotion in the same way as they apply to public servants, and although I have expressed some concern on a previous occasion that merit principles do not actually refer to merit at all, but rather prohibit patronage or discrimination on various specified grounds, nevertheless it is a system as a whole that has the support of the Australian Federal Police Association and when put in terms of new pay scales that have just been announced and greater flexibility in promotions, as I mentioned, it seems as a whole to be an improvement to the legislative base for the Australian Federal Police. I will come back to the Federal police briefly in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also seeks to amend the Customs Act. We are prepared to support that amendment; nevertheless I want to express a reservation: it is an amendment that will specifically abrogate the self-incrimination privilege in respect of a statement furnished to the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy pursuant to a court order.
