Certainly there are restrictions in the Bill as to what might then be done with evidence that is provided in this way; nevertheless any loss of traditional civil liberties is something to be approached cautiously. We find that in this amendment to the Customs Act there is a further loss of the basic right against self-incrimination. We are prepared to accept it in this instance but we do so with some reservation. It is always a matter of trying to find the right balance between what information is necessary for law enforcement bodies such as the Australian Customs Service to carry out their function effectively and what is necessary to maintain basic civil liberties. Unfortunately we seem to be continually taking away those civil liberties in the cause of more effective law enforcement and we should remind ourselves that there is always a loss. It is important that we should go cautiously down this path and maintain the correct balance. I make special mention of that because it occurs again in another instance in this particular Bill.

The Bill provides amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act which we support. It also provides amendments to the Family Law Act of 1975. It puts the Northern Territory in the same position as a State in relation to particular matters and also it provides that a lawyer appointed by the court as a separate representative for a child in proceedings concerning the child's welfare is able to seek an order that the custodian of the child produce that child for a psychiatric or psychological report. I do not think it is restricted to a lawyer but the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) might like to address that; the second reading speech would suggest that it is. We can, I guess, imagine circumstances in which providing such a capacity is in the best interests of the child, nevertheless we intend to monitor that provision. There are some aspects of it that make us feel a little uncomfortable and we will be looking, in due course, at how often and in what circumstances that power is exercised. Around Australia there has been some criticism in recent years, particularly of State community welfare organisations and the role that they have played in relation to children vis-a-vis the parents of those children. We, being naturally cautious people, will look to see how in practice this provision operates.

The Bill also provides amendments to the Law Officers Act which appear to us to be sound; they relate to properly remunerating and offering proper security to the Solicitor-General. They appear to be an improvement in the legislation. The Bill also provides amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act of 1987, an Act that was passed not long ago. It is a bit of a pity that it was not got right in the first instance; nevertheless we will support the amendment. Lastly, the Bill includes amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, and it is in relation to that Act that we also see another abrogation of the right not to give self-incriminating evidence. Again I express the caution that I mentioned a few moments ago. As a whole we see these amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act as being in the best interests of effective law enforcement; that is, they further improve the capacity to put pressure upon the assets that have arisen out of illegal activity rather than simply upon the individual. It is a tool in the hands of government and law enforcement officers that has proven worth while in the last few years. Improving efficiency and capacity in the area is worth while but, as I said, again we express a reservation when doing so requires abrogation of a basic right not to self-incriminate.

I want to make a couple of other comments on the part of this package that deals with more effectively law enforcement because we on this side of the chamber are concerned about what is happening in relation to federal crime and the capacity of our law enforcement bodies to combat such crime properly. We read in the press, for example, that the Minister has before him a report which has not been made public and which is being referred to as the Whyte report. It finds that the Federal Government's anti-crime policy is `uncoordinated, fragmented and lacking in vision'. I would have thought that in the context of legislation to improve Federal law enforcement the Parliament would be better informed if it had access to that report, and I would like to see it. I call upon the Minister to table that report.

The report further goes on to criticise important bodies that have been built up in the law enforcement area. It criticises, apparently, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI). According to a press report, it casts grave doubts on the future of the ABCI, which was established in 1981. The ABCI was an attempt to coordinate police intelligence from around Australia, and all of us who take an interest in this subject know that one of the great difficulties has been bringing police intelligence into a central form that can be utilised in the national good, rather than simply being restrained within State boundaries. It is one of the reasons the National Crime Authority was set up. If there are now reports coming out of the Federal Government saying that that body is not functioning in the way it was designed to function, we should be advised as to what is going on in order that we can see legislation such as this in its correct context. Apparently the report went on to criticise the Australian Police Ministers Council. Again that Council is an attempt to coordinate police work around the country.

So what is going on in this regard? I would be pleased if the Minister, when he brings law enforcement legislation such as this before us, could bring us properly into the picture. I do not want to dwell on it but we understand from press reports that the Whyte report reaches a conclusion that there has been no comprehensive attempt to estimate the dimensions, character, structure, trends or impact on Australian society of criminal activity. That would be most worrying if that were the case.

That draws us back to previous reports in this area that the Government has not been prepared to make public. The paper entitled `The cost of efficient policing', prepared by the former Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Major-General Grey, and submitted to the then Special Minister of State in February 1985, and more importantly the paper entitled `Fraud on the Commonwealth', prepared jointly by the Department of the Special Minister of State and the Australian Federal Police at the request of the then Special Minister of State and submitted to him on 29 November 1985, have never been made public. What we do know is that the latter paper puts the cost of fraud on the Commonwealth at $4 billion-a figure that was denied, as a matter of interest, at the time of the last election.

I am pleased to say-and I always give Senator Tate credit when it is deserved-that at a recent State committee inquiry Senator Tate was prepared to give at least an assessment of those two papers, and that is now on the public record. Who made the assessment, of course, we do not know. It may have come out of the Minister's office. It says that we should not take that $4 billion too seriously, yet it is prepared to accept the accuracy of a number of the other findings in the report on fraud on the Commonwealth. Whoever made the assessment cannot have it both ways and say to us, `Take no notice of the $4 billion figure because more work needs to be done', yet say that in other ways the report is correct. For example it is apparently correct we see from the assessment, that we are failures in administration and coordination between the agencies. In fact, it says the relationship between the Australian Federal Police and other agencies has been allowed to develop in a `haphazard and uncoordinated way'. It seems to be similar wording to that which we now understand is contained within the Whyte report.

So, again, what is going on? We would like to be brought into the confidence of the Government because, after all, it is our responsibility as a Parliament to act if the Commonwealth is failing to meet its law enforcement responsibility. It is particularly worrying to me that whilst on the one hand the Government says, `Don't take any notice of the $4 billion fraud', it then goes on to say, `We don't think it is worth while finding out whether that is correct or not'. How can we develop the best mechanisms to meet a law enforcement problem if we are not prepared to analyse the nature or the extent of the problem. It seems to me on the basis of the little that we have before us that the Government has abrogated its responsibility in this area, and I look forward to the Government's response to the matters that I have put before the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is pleased that the Opposition, and I take it the Australian Democrats and Independents, supports the passage of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. It is omnibus legislation which covers a very wide range of matters within the Attorney-General's portfolio and I thank Senator Hill for his indication of support for the various elements and items within it. I think the only real question he asked was whether separate representatives provided for the representation of children's interests in Family Court matters need to be lawyers. I am advised that whilst the Family Law Act itself does not so require, invariably that is the case. I am not in a position, in the absence of the statute before me, to confirm that absolutely.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the more general matters that have been raised, I believe that the Federal law enforcement agencies, pre-eminently amongst them the Australian Federal Police but also various joint agencies such as the National Crime Authority and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, are in very good order indeed. I believe that morale in the Australian Federal Police is at an all-time high. I certainly hope to confirm that at Christmas drinks with the Australian Federal Police Association later this afternoon, if I am allowed a quick pair with the indulgence of the chamber. It is a most rare event for me to so indulge but I believe that, having been through a rough patch with the Australian Federal Police Association early in the winter recess, we have now reached a situation where, as I could perhaps explain at greater length if I had more time, the relations between the Minister, the Department, the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Federal Police Association are at an all-time high. Everybody knows that this Government has taken steps in the right direction, first of all with the appointment of Commissioner McAulay, with the various efforts that have been made in the industrial relations field, and in trying to target and focus the operations of the Federal Police in a way which gives to those entering the force in particular a fascinating career path which will enable them to get great job satisfaction out of combating organised crime, drug trafficking and major fraud against the Commonwealth. Because of all these things I believe that the Federal Police are now in a very good position to wage that particular battle which the community demands that the Federal law enforcement agency wages.

As to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, it may be that I can further elaborate on this. I do not have the exact papers before me to which Senator Hill referred, but I made it quite clear at a meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council on 25 November, once again in Queensland, that the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence certainly has my support. I know Senator Archer has always had a great interest in the operations of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. He is present in the chamber. In so far as the so-called Whyte report-that is an over-personalisation and dramatisation of what is an internal document, still in draft form and produced by officers-is said to have suggested that the Australian Federal Police absorb the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, which is the real purport of that paragraph in the article to which Senator Hill referred, I have made it abundantly clear to the Australian Police Ministers Council that that is just not in the mind of the Government at all. So Senator Hill should not believe everything he reads. I believe that the Federal law enforcement agencies are in a good position to wage the war that is required.

I believe that in relation to fraud against the Commonwealth the various preliminary reports to which Senator Hill referred led to the setting up of a major exercise including, I think at the highest level, representatives from all relevant Commonwealth departments to come up with a strategy for combating fraud against the Commonwealth. I can tell Senator Hill and other honourable senators that that strategy is now already beginning to bear great fruit in the various agencies as they devise strategies and precautionary methods of preventing fraud against the Commonwealth arising, which must be the main in-principle aim, but then detecting it and effectively dealing with it should it unfortunately occur. So I believe that we are in good shape as far as the Federal fight against crime is concerned. I am pleased that the chamber is supporting the passage of this legislation. I also table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill. Once again it has to do with the excision of certain National Crime Authority matters into another Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 is the second such amendment Bill to have come forward this year. It amends eight separate Acts with approximately 60 individual amendments or alterations. The Acts so affected are the Navigation Act 1912, the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987, the Airlines Equipment Act 1958, the Civil Aviation Act 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986, the Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981, the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 and the Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Act 1986. The previous amending Bill amended five Acts-the Navigation Act 1912, the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952, The Federal Airports Corporation Act 1988, the Shipping Registration Act 1981 and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The Navigation Act amendments on this occasion give the Minister more powers and reduce recourse to the courts of marine inquiry for some of the matters referred to, passing them over to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal instead. The Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 amendments increase the size of eligible ships from 12 metres to 60 metres and separate cargo and passenger vessels by the creation of another section under `Definitions'. These are the main issues dealt with. There are about 50 other changes relating to errors, to the English used, to definition alterations, to commencement dates and so on. The number of alterations is quite horrifying and I expect that there should be less need for alteration than appears to be the case. Having said that, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Leader of the Government in the Senate has given me a few ideas over lunch, I address my first question to him in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's very cautious endorsement of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs when Mr Hawke said:

QUESTION.PARA: You have it quite clearly from me that it is my firm belief on all the information available to me that Mr Hand has not misled the Parliament.

On what information has Mr Hawke based his obviously erroneous conclusion that Mr Hand did not mislead the Parliament? When did the Prime Minister come to that conclusion? Will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the information included all material tabled in the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to give precise answers on times and so on. I am personally aware that the Prime Minister has discussed this issue with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on a variety of occasions. I do not want to be precise about dates, but it has been discussed on a variety of occasions and certainly after the information brought before the Senate by Senator Bolkus and after subsequent documents were tabled.
—Are you saying that he had the information up to the point of Bolkus or beyond?

—Up to the point of Senator Bolkus's statement, and beyond. The burden of Senator Chaney's question was: When the Prime Minister made a judgment about these matters, was that information before him? The short answer to that question is yes.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I understand the Minister's inability to give a precise answer because presumably he was not necessarily present at all times. But, in light of the importance that the Opposition places on the matter of misleading the Parliament, I ask the Minister to consider the specific questions I have asked, to consult with the Prime Minister, and then to let us have a considered reply to those questions.
—I am certainly prepared to do that. I take it that the burden of Senator Chaney's supplementary question is directed to times in relation to documents.
—The specific questions that I asked, of which I will give you a copy.
—Yes, sure.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND WET TROPICS: WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of progress at the World Heritage Committee meeting in Brasilia? Has the Commonwealth Government's nomination of the wet tropics of Queensland been accepted in full for inscription on the World Heritage List? Has the Minister any suggestions for how the Queensland Government should now proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —We have all been very fortunate today to have several missives from our colleagues in Brazil come back to Australia. I am informed of the following: I am delighted to advise the Senate that the World Heritage Committee, meeting in Brasilia, today decided to inscribe the wet tropics of Queensland on the World Heritage List. The decision recognises the wet tropics as one of the most valuable tropical rainforests in the world. Mr Jim Thorsell, head of the evaluation team which examined the nomination, told the Committee in his official presentation that it was one of the best five nominations he had ever seen.

ANSWER.PARA: The World Heritage protection for the wet tropics is yet another milestone in the Hawke Government's impressive record on environmental protection. In deciding to inscribe the wet tropics on the World Heritage List, the World Heritage Committee clearly rejected the Queensland Government's position. The decision was unanimous; not one country took up the Queensland Government's case. The Queensland Government has had ample opportunity to put its case. Dr Thorsell's international evaluation team visited the wet tropics in April 1988 and discussed the nomination with the Queensland Premier, Ministers and officials. The State has ceaselessly lobbied World Heritage member countries and led expensive delegations to the June meeting of the World Heritage Bureau in Paris and the current Committee meeting in Brasilia. Millions of dollars that could have helped north Queenslanders have already been wasted by the Queensland Government. Surely even Queensland should now accept reality. It should put aside its differences with the Commonwealth and cooperate in the disbursement of the Commonwealth's $75m package for north Queensland. It should come to the table and discuss the future management arrangements and drop its unconstructive and expensive High Court of Australia challenge. To put it another way, we have been to the funeral, now let us have a reading of the will. World Heritage listing has brought international attention and better protection and management of the Great Barrier Reef. There is no reason why two governments cannot come together and similarly cooperate on arrangements for the rainforests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Did the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs meet with senior officials of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), including Mr Pat Dodson, in Adelaide in the week ending Friday, 18 November? Did the commissioners of the ADC hold a special meeting to discuss the privilege matter under consideration by the Senate? Did the Minister, his Department or the ADC authorise the expenditure of more than $3,500 for an aircraft charter to transport ADC commissioner, Pat Dodson, from Adelaide to Alice Springs? What were the special reasons for this exorbitant expenditure when Alice Springs is serviced with adequate daily air services? Finally, is it true that the eight hand-picked commissioners of the ADC have applied to the Minister for special allowances above and beyond the entitlements determined by the Remuneration Tribunal? If so, has Mr Hand made a decision and is it consistent with the attitude being adopted by the Prime Minister to the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal?
—In short, I have no idea and I will refer the questions in all their multiplicity to the Minister.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the reports that a future Liberal Government will reinstate tax deductability for entertainment expenses. Is the Government contemplating reinstatement of this deduction and what would be its cost to revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November last the West Australian newspaper reported a speech given by the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Elliott, to a business dinner in Bunbury in Western Australia and stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Business lunches as a tax deduction will make a comeback under the next Federal Liberal Government . . .

Mr Elliott added that the Liberal scheme would allow for genuine expenses associated with the earning of income to be deductable but it would aim to eliminate rorts. Of course, that is a bit of cloud-cuckoo-land stuff because, short of sending an officer from the Australian Taxation Office to every business lunch to make sure the conversation does not stray too far away from business matters, it is impossible to reinstate deductability and eliminate rorts. The only practical way of eliminating what had grown into a giant rort is to deny the deduction.
Mr Elliott's statement contradicts the statement made by Mr Howard and Mr Peacock on 10 May when they said, in the statement on `The Shape of the Coalition Tax Policy':

Whilst the Opposition recognises that many entertainment expenses are directly involved in earning assessable income, the priorities are such that we can no longer commit ourselves to a restoration of entertainment expenses as a tax deduction.
It raises the question, of course, of who is speaking for the Liberal Party-Mr Howard and Mr Peacock or Mr Elliott?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard and Mr Peacock; you can be assured of that.

—Then, I think Senator Chaney should check with Mr Elliott and ask him whether he is going to repudiate what he said in Western Australia on 14 November. If I may say so, the undertaking by Mr Elliott that the Liberal Government would restore the free tax deductable business lunch-or the rort as it degenerated into-is at considerable variance with the soft images of families and picket fences which the Liberal Party tried to convey last Sunday. The Government is not contemplating bringing back that rort. But, if we did, the likely cost of doing so would be about $400m a year. We would rather put that kind of money into enhancing the family allowance supplement, as we plan to do in the next year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and relates to alleged corrupt practices in the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Federal Police. I preface my question by advising the Senate that it is based on two affidavits and other relevant documents in my possession which convince me that there is reason to take seriously the allegations to which I now refer. I therefore ask the Minister: Is he aware that it has been alleged by several parties that senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank have in the past colluded in a corrupt practice by which businesses receiving funds from the Bank are deliberately manipulated into bankruptcy and that their businesses are then acquired by other predetermined parties? Is the Minister aware that it is further alleged that these allegations have, for several years, been known to the Federal Police and that the victims of these practices claim that the Federal Police has failed in its duties in these matters? Is the Minister aware that these matters are the subject of statements of claim filed in the Supreme Court of New South Wales last Thursday, 1 December? Is it a fact that these matters are currently the subject of an investigation by the Federal Police as a result of a referral by the Commonwealth Bank itself in April of this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had some chance to consult with the Australian Federal Police, who inform me that it is currently investigating allegations that a senior officer of the Commonwealth Bank provided confidential information to individuals concerning outstanding debts by certain companies. It is alleged that those companies were then approached and offered funds which would enable them to continue trading and repay their debts. They would be converted to public companies and the majority shareholding would be controlled by the individuals who proposed the scheme. It is further alleged that the companies were unable to repay their debts and were stripped of their assets.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also been further informed by the Federal Police that these allegations were first reported to it in April 1988 and that it has been undertaking an investigation since that time. The Australian Federal Police has advised that the matter was not referred to it for investigation by the Commonwealth Bank but from another source. The Australian Federal Police has further advised that it is aware of one document relating to these matters which was lodged by a plaintiff within the Supreme Court in March 1988. However, it has no knowledge of other documents registered last Friday in the Supreme Court of New South Wales.

Finally, the allegations which have been referred to the Federal Police have not included references to corrupt practices in the Federal Police. Senator McLean has raised these matters both at Question Time and in the preceding matter of public interest debate, and allegations of corruption within the Federal Police are matters which I take extremely seriously. I do not take them seriously because affidavits have been made but because Senator McLean has brought them into this chamber. I do not mean either that merely because they have been publicly aired I take them seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean?

—I mean that Senator McLean having drawn these matters to my attention and as I have a great respect for him, I intend personally to take up with the Commissioner of Police, Mr McAulay, the matter of an allegation of corruption within the Federal Police. I can assure Senator McLean that I will give my personal attention to that element of his question.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to reports emanating from Iran that the Government there has embarked on a deliberate policy of executing people whose only crime has been to hold different views from the Government position? Having regard to the Australian Government's stand on human rights, will the Minister undertake to express our concern at these savage developments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of reports that a large number of Iranians have been executed in recent weeks in what appears to be a major drive against opponents of the Government. It seems that those reported to have been killed include members of the mujahedeen, the pro-Moscow Tudeh or communist party, and even clerical leaders. It has proved very difficult, as has sometimes been the case in the past, to obtain accurate information about allegations of serious human rights abuses in Iran but, nonetheless, these reports at their face value are certainly a great cause of concern to the Government. Our embassy in Tehran is monitoring the situation as carefully as it is possible to do, even given the limits on access to reliable sources.

ANSWER.PARA: We have as a government expressed our concerns about human rights abuses to Iranian officials on many occasions. Mr Hayden raised the matter with senior Ministers during his visit in August. Australia was one of the co-sponsors of a recent United Nations resolution adopted by the Third Committee of the General Assembly on 30 November, just a few days ago, condemning the human rights situation in Iran and calling on Iran to allow the United Nations special representative to visit in order to investigate further conditions there. If any further information comes to hand on this matter over the next few days, I will advise the Senate and take whatever action is appropriate and possible for the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to a letter I have received, as presumably have other honourable senators, from the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations inviting me to participate in the activities of the national prices network. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the national prices network is a Government initiative? If so, how is it coordinated and funded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I should say that I have not been made aware of any letter that Senator Patterson may have received from the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations relating to the national prices network. It should be said from the outset that the national prices network is a body which is drawn up and directed by representatives of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, together with representatives of pensioner organisations. It does receive some funding from government; in fact, in recent months it has received a degree of funding to enable it to organise better its computer structures as well as its personnel structures.

ANSWER.PARA: In essence, however, it is drawn up from a wide range of volunteer organisations throughout the country. At the latest count there were 75 or 76 actual price watch committees throughout Australia, with a volunteer involvement of about 600 or 700 people. Each of those committees conducts a monthly survey of prices in its immediate district. The surveys of prices are then compiled monthly and figures drawn from the prices are available both on a national and a regional basis. In a place such as Newcastle the price watch committee can monthly come up with a select basket of prices for that region and consumers are then able to compare prices available to them from one supermarket to the other in that region. The Government believes that the price watch network is a very important and effective tool in ensuring that consumers have relevant and adequate information on the cheapest place to shop at the most appropriate time, and that is before they actually go shopping.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to assume the the Minister's answer to my question as to whether the national prices network is government-initiated is no?

—I could go into the actual network and its history, but suffice it to say that it was brought together quite substantially after the Prime Minister's speech on the occasion of the Ruby Hutchison Memorial Address on 8 March 1987. Up until that date a number of price watch committees were operating on a volunteer and uncoordinated basis in many ways throughout Australia. Because of the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister in that speech the Government, particularly through the work of George Gear, a Federal member from Western Australia, who is doing quite an effective job in this area--
—An outstanding job.

—An outstanding job. The Government, through the efforts of people such as George Gear and other back bench members of Parliament, has taken the initiative in ensuring that the program has been developed substantially.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Local Government in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of rumours that affirmative action legislation is to be extended shortly to cover companies employing fewer than 100 people? Does the Government intend to amend legislation in this way?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. To what extent are you prepared to allow questions to be predicated on the basis `Is the Minister aware of rumours?'? If the dorothy dixers cannot be written better than this, it makes an absolute farce of Question Time. One might as well ask, `Is the Minister aware of rumours that the moon is made of blue cheese?'
—Rumours should be laid to rest, Senator.

—Given what the Minister has done to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, I doubt whether that rumour could be laid to rest. Mr President, unless you are prepared to impose some discipline on these organised questions, Question Time will be reduced to a total nonsense if `Is the Minister aware of rumours' is the basis of a question.

—When the question was being asked I was about to rule it out of order but then it specifically went into an area of the Minister's portfolio. For that reason I will allow it, but I make the point that it certainly could have been written better.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not refer to the rumours, as they seem to have so upset Senator Puplick. No form of amendment to the affirmative action legislation is being considered. The affirmative action legislation was implemented in the time of my predecessor, Senator Susan Ryan, who did a great deal of work in consulting extensively with the public and companies. The legislation in its present form is in an excellent condition. That is best indicated by the fact that when reports for the first year were prepared and presented to the Minister responsible, about a month ago, they showed that there had been 99 per cent compliance with the affirmative action legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, you will probably recall the dire predictions that were made by a number of Opposition members when Senator Susan Ryan was taking the affirmative action legislation through the Parliament. It was criticised on the basis that companies would not comply with the legislation, that they would ignore it. Yet the Government's commitment to equal employment opportunity has been well and truly vindicated by the responsible way companies have responded. That augurs well for the second stage of the legislation's implementation, to come into effect next year.

I do not know whether Senator Puplick will regard this as a rumour, and I have not yet had an opportunity to read the Future Directions document, but I have heard it said that the Affirmative Action Agency would be maintained by Mr Howard in the unlikely event he were to be in a position to make such a decision. His contribution to Human Rights Week was to announce that, if in government, he would dismantle the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission-not a particularly appropriate way for a responsible Opposition Leader to begin Human Rights Week. Mr Howard has indicated that the Opposition is committed to equal opportunities for women. He maintains that equal opportunities are available to women in education and the workplace and that the treatment of women in Australia should be fair and equitable at all times.

I am pleased that Mr Howard has given that commitment. But how he would ensure that those principles were implemented if he were in a position to live up to his promise to dismantle the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is beyond me. In answer to Senator Zakharov's question, the affirmative action legislation will not be amended. It would not be appropriate to apply the legislation to companies employing less than 100 people. We believe that the larger companies have the resources and the opportunity to set an example in this regard. Whether or not it was a rumour, I can assure Senator Zakharov that there is no move to change the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. It relates to queries which have been raised by a number of Tasmanians who have contacted my electorate office and to similar queries which have been raised in the Tasmanian Parliament by the State Liberal Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr John Beswick, MHA. Can the Minister please advise the method by which the prices action groups which make up the national prices network conduct their surveys? Who collects the data for these surveys? Do they receive any training? Are they paid for their work?

—As I have already indicated, the network of price watch committees throughout Australia is essentially a volunteer network. The surveys are conducted monthly by volunteers. As I said in answer to a previous question, the price watch committees form part of the national prices network, which was established on 30 April 1987. The network consists of volunteers who are not paid. A staffing arrangement has been provided for through government grants. Grants were made in June 1987 and June 1988 to ensure the provision of a coordinator for the network.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Are the surveys carried out by the prices action groups similar to those surveys conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for consumer price index purposes?

—I should make two points clear. Firstly, the basket which is surveyed every month has been drawn up with the cooperation and advice of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The basket has been scientifically assessed and compiled by the national prices network. Secondly, and most importantly, the national prices network gives consumers, at the most appropriate time, information which allows them to exercise to the greatest extent a degree of choice. They can have information as to which supermarket in their immediate region provides the best choice for them in terms of prices. That is extremely important. If anybody is concerned about competition and ensuring that consumers derive benefits from competition, he would have to agree that the national prices network is an effective mechanism for achieving that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister's announcement this week on the steel plan highlighted the dramatic turnaround in the steel division of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) over the last five years. Can the Minister indicate how other companies in the Australian steel industry have responded to the steel plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of companies which are integral to the Australian steel industry, such as Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, Palmer Tube Mills Ltd, Comsteel and some others, were in the province, as it were, of the steel plan. In terms of bounty assistance, investment and a whole range of activities associated with the Steel Industry Authority, those companies were beneficiaries of and participants in the steel plan. I will make some brief, practical comments about that. For example, of the $144m which the Government spent on the steel industry over the life of the plan, $82m went to 23 different non-BHP companies. As I have said, one of the best examples was Tubemakers. The Tubemakers plant at Newcastle reduced its work force during the life of the plan from 2,400 to 700 without a strike and without retrenchments. At the same time, it doubled, and in some areas trebled, productivity and invested over $80m in the latest plant and equipment. It is rapidly becoming a world leader in pipe and tube technology. At the same time, with the Steel Industry Authority, it developed plant level agreements which should be a model for the rest of the steel industry.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of other smaller firms and tube makers were involved in the steel plan, some of them highly entrepreneurial. They included Bunge Industrial Steels Pty Ltd, which exports most of its output of quenched and tempered steel to the United States; Palmer Tube Mills, which grew rapidly in the local market in spite of some difficulties from time to time with BHP and is now growing even more rapidly in the United States; and Smorgons, the Melbourne mini-mill which has captured a sizeable share of the Australian rod and bar market and is currently in a stage of further capacity expansion. All these firms emerged from the period of the steel plan leaner, more efficient and better placed to benefit from the booming domestic market. Present indications are for a very promising world steel market in the next year or so. There were other firms involved but I have mentioned some of the key ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs of the disruption of a meeting of the Ultimo-Glebe branch of the Liberal Party of Australia two nights ago by a band of right wing extremists from the National Action Alliance, which I think is Mr Saleem's group. I am reminded that the Ultimo-Glebe branch is a very good one. A major target of their anger was Liberal legislative councillor Helen Sham-Ho--
—A very good parliamentarian.

—I accept the interjection. I remind the Minister that the subject of the meeting was multiculturalism. I ask the Minister: First, what does the Government intend to do to deal with attempts by any extremist group to prevent sensible discussion of multiculturalism in Australia, including discussion within Liberal Party branches? Secondly, what remedies can the Government offer in this area and what protection was open to Helen Sham-Ho or to the other guests who went to the dinner to hear her speak about an important subject? Thirdly, can the Minister confirm that he stated in his response this morning to the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies that the Government remains committed to immigration policies that are non-discriminatory with respect to ethnic origin, race, sex or religion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that I speak on behalf of all honourable senators when I express the outrage we felt at the treatment of Mrs Sham-Ho. Anything that we can do at the Federal level to assist in that regard we will. The protection of speakers at public meetings in New South Wales is the responsibility of the State Government at this stage. Given that State Government's commitment to multiculturalism, obviously it will provide the necessary degree of protection in future. It is true that one would be more likely to have to seek protection in certain areas of Australia because of extremist groups. I think it is provided in South Australia. I have not availed myself of it yet, but it is provided to Ministers going to South Australia. Sometimes there is a problem in Western Australia, where similar activities have broken out, and now these extremists are active in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: We all have a responsibility to condemn political extremism. I feel comfortable in doing that because all my life I have condemned political extremism, either of the extreme Left or the extreme Right, especially when it manifests itself in violence and threats. Mrs Sham-Ho was treated shamefully at that meeting, and I believe that every protection possible should be accorded to her.

I am not sure that any remedy other than strict enforcement of the law will have an effect on extremists. One could outlaw racism in this country, and that is obviously under consideration by various State governments and at the Federal level. My only concern with that is whether it is more likely to encourage extremists in this country who will then distort any such legislation. We in this chamber will not be the victims; other people in the community may be.

As to the honourable senators final point, I reiterate that this Government's attitude is that its future immigration programs will not be based on discrimination on the basis of ethnic origin or race. That is a view that the Prime Minister has stated and it is a view that I share. If it turns out not to be a popular view in the electorate, we will bear the consequences.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIRPORTS: TRANSFER TO FEDERAL AIRPORTS CORPORATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation. There have been unfortunate delays in the transfer of a package of airports from the Federal Government to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). The airports which I am particularly concerned about are Alice Springs and Darwin.
—You are better off keeping them where they are than transferring them to the FAC.

—I am delighted to receive that interjection in respect of the use that I will make of it in the Northern Territory as far as the Opposition is concerned. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the reasons for these unfortunate delays and advise on the progress of the transfers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The transfer of these airports to the FAC is taking longer than was originally anticipated. We very much regret that delay but it has been caused by a number of quite complex issues which are taking additional time to resolve. They are essentially threefold. The first is the need to finalise an agreed valuation which provides an appropriate basis for future FAC pricing and investment decisions. I understand that that matter is very close to settlement. Secondly, there is a need to determine appropriate tenure arrangements on the joint user aerodromes which are shared with the Department of Defence. That has taken much longer to resolve for reasons which even Senator MacGibbon may be deeply appreciative of. The problem is that when we have a shared facility, as is Darwin Airport, we have to deal with the defence interests involved. Given the significance and importance of that from the national security point of view, it is important to get the tenure arrangements right, and that has taken some time.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, there is a need in due course to amend the Federal Airports Corporation Act to permit the FAC to operate Federal airports under leasehold from the Commonwealth and to develop arrangements, again, for joint operations on aerodromes shared with Defence. That is the other side of the coin which I have just mentioned. The FAC, for its part, has to establish the necessary management arrangements to accommodate a significant increase in the number of airports under its control, but that is something for which arrangements, I understand, are well in hand. It is now expected that the transfers will take place in the early part of 1989. There need be no concern whatsoever about the fact that the transfers will take place. The problem has just been one of timing, for the reasons I hope I have sufficiently and clearly indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Will service cadets studying at universities under the undergraduate scheme and service personnel required by the Australian Defence Force to undertake tertiary studies next year have to pay $1,800 per year for full time study in order to help the Services meet their needs for appropriately trained manpower? Will this also be the case for those scientists required by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation to obtain higher degrees? Could it be fairly said that the equity of this demand beggars the imagination? Is it also true to say that, where defence personnel refuse these studies because they are not prepared to meet the costs themselves, service capabilities will be eroded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can give the Graham Richardson memorial answer, I will put the question on notice and get an answer as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister also get an explanation as to why a decision has been taken not to tell applicants for cadetships under the undergraduate scheme that, although sponsored by the Government, they will have to pay their own higher education contribution tax?
—You cannot ask a supplementary question about a non-answer.
—It is supplementary to the inadequate answer.

—It is supplementary to the inadequate answer. It goes exactly to the point of my question concerning the undergraduate scheme. Is the Government so desperate for specialist personnel that it has been reduced to deception?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —When supplementary questions came into vogue in this chamber, it was expected not that they would be typed or written out in advance but that they would follow up on the answer. It is especially galling, when an honourable senator has spent a lot of time on an ingenious ambush at a supplementary stage, not to be able to read it out. I will also put the ambush supplementary question on notice. If the answer to the original question does not satisfy Senator Newman we may even trigger a supplementary answer into action, or we may not. It is probably even money as to whether Senator Newman will get an answer to the second question.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, is in regard to the Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Is the Minister aware of the obstructive position taken by the Western Australian Police Union, backed up by recent public criticisms of the Muirhead Royal Commission, made by the Western Australian Minister for Police? Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Minister for Police has allotted taxpayers' money to challenging the very letters patent which his own State Government, along with the Commonwealth, agreed to as terms of reference for the Commission? Does the Minister acknowledge that the deliberate obstruction of the inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody constitutes an inappropriate use of taxpayers' money? Will the Minister guarantee to all Australians that the Commission will receive the full support of the Commonwealth Government to continue to carry out its responsibilities in Western Australia to, as stated in the terms of reference, `inquire into the conduct of coronial, police and other inquiries and any other things that were not done but ought to have been done' in relation to black deaths in custody in Western Australia since 1 January 1980?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of certain reports that the Western Australian Government, in the guise of the Minister for Police in that jurisdiction, has decided to support in financial terms the efforts by the police union-I just cannot recall its exact title-to challenge the exercise of powers by the member of the Royal Commission who has been allocated certain tasks by Mr Justice Muirhead in relation to the Aboriginal deaths in custody which have occurred in Western Australia. I regard it as a matter of regret that the Western Australian Government has reached a point where it has decided to support an attempt to frustrate the inquiries which have been undertaken, as the honourable senator has said, in accordance with the very references which both the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments have agreed should be the subject of the Royal Commission's inquiries.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, I think we ought not to anticipate events over the next few weeks because, as I understand it, Mr Justice Muirhead will be presenting to governments an interim report by the end of this year which will indicate certain preliminary findings as to the steps which might be taken to prevent the further occurrence of these tragic deaths in custody. I think a great cause of frustration, perhaps in the general community and even amongst honourable senators, is the fact that, at one stage, the Royal Commission looked as though it would go on for a very long time without any indication coming from its deliberations to this point as to what practical steps might be taken to prevent the recurrence of these deaths in custody. In so far as the Commission, through its various inquiries, has come to any conclusions which might be of use, I believe that governments need to be made aware of them as soon as possible. I believe that the Western Australian Government is anxious that those deaths in custody do not occur at the rate at which, tragically, they have occurred over recent years. I believe also from certain press reports-I have not been able to confirm this-that Mr Justice Muirhead intends to bring down findings in respect of certain cases which have already been the subject of inquiry within the Commission.

In short, I believe that, upon the receipt of the interim report from Mr Justice Muirhead, governments will be in a much better position to decide whether the sort of action being contemplated by the Western Australian Minister for Police is justified. I would hope that the interim report, carefully considered by governments, will enable the Commission to have the confidence of all participating jurisdictions so that the tragic deaths which have occurred, having been properly examined, can be finally regarded as having been inquired into in a way which satisfies in particular the families but also the general community and that the lessons learnt from those experiences can be applied to prevent the recurrence of these tragedies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: Is it a fact that the former principal private secretary, industrial, of the Minister for Defence has set himself up as a consultant in defence procurement and defence industrial contracts in Western Australia? Is it a fact that an increasing number of defence contracts are going to Western Australia as part of Mr Beazley's pork-barrelling of defence expenditure to the west? Are any restraints imposed by this Government on former employees with inside knowledge exploiting that knowledge to their personal financial advantage when they leave government employment? If there are no restraints, will this Government follow the lead set by the United Kingdom and the United States of America to legislate against such practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no direct knowledge of the individual that Senator MacGibbon may be referring to. I will refer that part of Senator MacGibbon's question that goes directly to the individual and his-I assume it is a he although it could be a she-activities to Mr Beazley to get a response. The honourable senator raised a couple of other general questions about the propriety of people working for government, then going off into some private sphere and using that training and knowledge and profiting from it. If it occurs it would not be limited only to defence; it would occur in areas such as communications and right across the board. One of the reasons governments have this difficulty-I think most Ministers acknowledge it-is that many employees who are working in the Public Service are not paid the market rate; therefore, they are quite tempted to leave. Some retire early and become journalists and later senators. There is a whole range of people. It impacts especially on areas such as communications, Treasury and defence where the training that we give makes them very well suited to the purposes of other people to use in terms of evaluation projects or lobbying.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the honourable senator's general accusation that Mr Beazley is sending defence projects to Western Australia to pork barrel, I will also refer that to Mr Beazley. I very much doubt that that is the case. He has taken a very stringent attitude to these sorts of matters to make sure that contracts in this country go to the best place. I would have to say that it did not enthuse everyone in New South Wales when he sent the submarine contract to South Australia. Whenever he makes a decision about a frigate there will be people who whinge. But the one thing I am sure of with Mr Beazley is that he will send those contracts to the people who deserve them, to the people who provide the best and cheapest service and who give the best all round delivery, and not on a pork-barrelling basis.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHRISTMAS ISLAND CASINO: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to remarks made by the Minister during debate on 23 November on the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 referring to Christmas Island, in which the Minister said that the proposal was subjected to an environmental impact assessment. I also refer the Minister to page 2633 of the Hansard of 12 May 1987 in which then Senator Ryan, representing the Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment, stated that an environmental impact statement would not be required on the proposal. I ask the Minister: In the case of commercial developments in or near environmentally sensitive areas, such as Christmas Island, is it the custom of the Government to allow development proponents to supply their own assessment of the environmental impact of their proposals? What independent assessments of the environmental and socioeconomic impact of the Christmas Island hotel-casino proposal has the Government commissioned, received or carried out? Is it a fact that the Government waived the requirement for an environmental impact statement for the Christmas Island hotel-casino development proposal? If an environmental impact statement or equivalent document has been prepared for the proposal will the Minister table this document? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to assert that there is nothing really contradictory in the statements of Senator Ryan and Senator Richardson. The processes of environmental impact assessment, in accordance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, were fully satisfied in the case of the Christmas Island casino. After the proponent was designated, the Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment required sufficient information to determine whether an environmental impact statement was necessary. Following extensive consultations between the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Department of Territories and the proponent, the Department secured the proponent's agreement to a series of environmental protection measures which address the potential impacts of the proposal on the island's natural and socioeconomic environment. These undertakings have also been incorporated in the agreement between the Commonwealth and Christmas Island Casino Resort Pty Ltd. On the basis of these undertakings and the Department's assessment, the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment concluded that an environmental impact statement would not be required for the proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to the honourable senator's specific question: firstly, in accordance with the procedures under the Act, the proponent is responsible for preparing the environmental assessment documentation. The Department, on behalf of the Minister, provides guidance and an audit of these documents. Secondly-and this follows from what I have just said-the Government does not normally commission independent assessments of specific impacts except, of course, where it is the proponent. However, in this case, the then Department of Arts Heritage and Environment had before it information from the Department of Territories and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to assist in examining the environmental issues associated with the proponent's project. The then Department of Territories identified two main areas of concern: firstly, the potential effect of the increased visitor numbers on the national park and other sensitive natural areas; and, secondly, the potential effects on the island's social and economic structure arising from the shift to a tourism based economy, changes in the type and availability of employment and other associated changes in island administration.

The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service also expressed concern on the first of these matters. On the basis of this advice and on its own assessment, the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment concluded that the most effective way to protect the island's natural and social environment would be to secure the proponent's agreement to a series of broad environmental protection measures. These measures were documented, referred to the developer and his agreement obtained. Thirdly, as a result of an agreement to those environmental protection measures and in accordance with the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, the Minister then determined that an environmental impact statement was not necessary for achieving the object of the impact of proposals Act. Fourthly, the honourable senator asked whether I would table the environmental impact statement or the equivalent document. The relevant document which I have referred to is the environment protection undertakings that the developer has agreed to. I table the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs follows the questions asked by Senator Patterson and Senator Calvert and the Minister's somewhat confusing answer about the extent of Government involvement in pricewatch. I ask the Minister: What Government funds are involved in supporting pricewatch? To whom are such funds paid and by which Department? Can the Minister tell us what paid full time or part time employees are involved in pricewatch? I note, incidentally, that the Minister in his previous answer said that money was paid to the better organised personnel structures involved. Can the Minister tell us where those employees are located? Can he also tell me where the computers, which were also referred to in his answer, are located?

—I will very gladly answer Senator Chaney's question. Given the degree of detail that is involved, I will obviously not be able to provide the answer in detail now. I will provide it to him as soon as I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's incapacity to answer in detail. Therefore, I ask him on a more general basis whether any of the personnel or computers are located in offices which are associated with the Australian Labor Party, the Government or Government members or senators?

—My understanding is that it needs to be checked out. In terms of any persons who might be paid by the Government, my understanding is-and I need to check this out completely-that to perform this function that person is not working out of a Government office or a Government backbencher's office. In order to give Senator Chaney a full answer on that and the actual number of computers and their actual location, I will need to take the question on notice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WEST COAST OF SOUTH AUSTRALIA: DROUGHT ASSISTANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen the front page story in the Port Lincoln Times of Tuesday 29 November 1988 reporting the South Australian Opposition Leaders's call for immediate government aid, not only for drought stricken farmers but for small business as well? Can the Minister say whether the Government will provide any increase in assistance to South Australia's west coast?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article; indeed, I have a copy of it with me. It is pretty clear that it is a call, in short, from Mr Olsen for the Government to extend cheap finance to every small business on the west coast because he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Predominantly, small business income is related to farming.

Incidentally, this view has been seriously challenged by the University of New South Wales in some recent research which has shown that in the Riverina-I have forgotten precisely what town it was-during the rural slump of the early 1980s small businesses were doing better than they had done before. Of course, anecdotal evidence of that type has been around for a long time. I recall that in a Western Australian country town during the agricultural slump of the early 1970s one local businessman was reported as saying that his trade had gone up since the slump because the farmers could not afford to do their shopping in Perth any more and they were doing it in the local country town. Leaving that aside, Mr Olsen continued:
The drought affected season has meant turnover has dropped with people buying less, only the essentials.

I understand that Mr Olsen himself was once a small businessman from those sorts of areas. The natural disaster relief arrangements do not provide for this kind of assistance to small business. As I understand it, the South Australian Government has the good sense to address more fundamental problems than that, particularly securing a suitable restructuring of agriculture through the rural adjustment scheme (RAS).

Earlier this year the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia was saying that this was not enough and that as South Australia's carry-on loan budget had been exhausted, there was a need for an immediate injection of at least $1m from the Commonwealth into South Australia. Whether Mr Olsen is aware of that promise by his Federal counterpart-that is, the additional $1m for the Eyre Peninsula-I do not know.

Last Thursday, in response to a challenge from the Treasurer and me, Mr Peacock and Dr Hewson issued a list, incomplete though it was, clarifying their position on a number of expenditure promises from which they had dumped a huge amount-over $12 billion in total-of commitments that had been given by various people purporting to speak for the Opposition, most spectacularly of all by Mr Sinclair and Mr White in the defence area. Among those commitments was a reference to $1.8m for the RAS on South Australia's west coast. They put out a document in which they said:
the call for $1 million to be provided for these purposes was made last financial year and is no longer relevant.

Or, as Ronald Ziegler used to say, it is `inoperative'. If Mr Olsen really believes this assistance is necessary I suggest that he commence by talking to his Federal counterparts, who explicitly walked away from the commitment which they had previously made to do just that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to a debate which took place in the Queensland Parliament on 9 November 1988 about the mining of limestone in central Queensland. During that debate, the Labor member for Windsor, Mr Patrick Comben, claimed that Queensland Cement and Lime Co. Ltd had made donations to the National Party in 1974 and 1976. To support his claim Mr Comben said, and I quote from the Queensland Parliament Hansard transcript of his speech--
—What is the question?
—I have to give the background. The question is coming. Mr Comben said:

QUESTION.PARA: Our information comes from a taxation department officer who handled the files . . . I have no way of checking for myself--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is simply that the honourable senator is not asking a question. He is making a speech. I suggest you direct him to ask the question.
—Order! There have been a number of very long questions today. The honourable senator is giving background information. I will pull him up if he goes on too long.
—Thank you, Mr President. I continue:

QUESTION.PARA: Our information comes from a taxation department officer who handled the files . . . I have no way of checking for myself the veracity of the allegations, but I do state that my informant is an honest man who is willing to speak, who is prepared to front any inquiry or commission and who has impressed me with his recall of the files and returns.
I will be very brief, but in relation to the fact that the company has not allowed access to the files, he goes on to say:
. . . by Friday of this week, I intend to advise the Fitzgerald inquiry . . .
My source obviously faces certain problems under the secrecy provisions of the Australian taxation legislation and as a result he cannot at this stage be named.

I ask the Minister: In view of the great concerns in this country in respect of privacy provisions in the tax file number legislation, does he agree that the information this officer has given Mr Comben clearly breaches the secrecy of the Income Tax Act? Will the Minister initiate an immediate investigation to identify the officer of the Australian Taxation Office concerned? This is a task which should be easy as Mr Comben obviously knows his identity. Will the Minister assure this chamber that charges will be laid against this officer under the secrecy provisions of the income tax legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Just say yes, yes, yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters wants me immediately to get up in this chamber and say, `Yes, yes, yes, I will ensure that certain charges will be laid against a person'. I would certainly not be discharging my responsibilities as Minister for Justice if on the basis of a question hurled across the chamber-I take it in good faith from Senator Parer-the honourable senator got a response from me that a person was to be charged. That is absolutely absurd. I do not intend to act in that fashion.
—It was about initiating an investigation.

—Senator Walters does not know anything about these sorts of matters. There are proprieties to be observed. Apparently an assertion has been made in the Queensland Parliament, of course under privilege, in a way which could not be fairly contested, that a taxation officer has disclosed certain information which was available to him in his capacity as a taxation officer. If that were the case, clearly it would amount to a very serious breach of the secrecy provisions of the taxation Act, I think specifically section 16. On the face of what has been said, such a disclosure has been made. But I am in no way able to judge whether in fact what the member of the Queensland Parliament said transpired between him and a taxation officer was indeed the case.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a matter of great concern in this chamber. In fact, only prior to lunch the chamber passed the privacy legislation which includes very specific guidelines and provisions which are designed to safeguard the privacy of individuals, particularly in regard to tax file number information. I know it is the concern of the chamber, indeed of the Parliament and of course the Government, that those secrecy provisions in relation to tax file number information be adhered to as stringently as is possible. In so far as Senator Parer has raised a particular matter, I will obviously take it on notice and make such inquiries as are appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November this year Senator Teague asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations about the International Labour Organisation. Senator Teague is not noted in this chamber for his interest in the affairs of the International Labour Organisation. If I might say so, the point of the question was directed to retrieving the Liberal Party of Australia from some embarrassment about its leadership problems.
—Just give us the answer.

—I made those remarks in order to identify the question for Senator Teague's benefit and also to explain that in so far as that part of the question related to the future use of the Australian Prime Minister, I am not answering that. I am answering the question about the International Labour Organisation. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

On 25 November 1988, Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, a question without notice regarding reports that consideration is being given to changing International Labour Organisation (ILO) rules in respect of the Director-General's term of office. Senator Teague asked what will be the attitude of the Australian Government representatives at the ILO to such changes, are they being actively sought by the Australian Government and who was responsible for initiating the move to change the rules. In my reply, I undertook to refer the matter to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

``The term office of the Director-General of the ILO expires on 26 February 1989. In accordance with previous practice the tripartite ILO Governing Body considered a report prepared by its officers at its June 1988 meeting on the necessary measures in anticipation of this expiry.
The Government Body decided to:

(a) amend the Staff Regulations, reducing the period of appointment from ten to five years. The ten year provision has not applied since 1948 and is considered obsolete and inappropriate. This brings the period of appointment of the ILO Director- General into line with the Appointments of the heads of a number of United Nations agencies.

(b) adopt a requirement that to be elected a candidate should receive the votes of more than one-half of the members of the Governing Body entitled to vote. This requirement was introduced in light of the Governing Body's expectation that for the first time there will be more than two candidates standing for the position of Director-General. The Standing Orders of the Governing Body did not set down specific conditions and, according to accepted practice, the Director-General could be elected by a simple majority of votes cast (abstentions excluded). The Governing Body took the view that it is essential for the Director-General to enjoy the broadest possible support within the Governing Body in order to fully carry out the important functions of the position. The previous practice did not seem to provide an adequate guarantee in this respect. The Governing Body adopted this change by consensus. The changes were not sought by the Australian Government.
The election of the Director-General will be held on 13 February 1989. The Governing Body will meet in private sitting in order to proceed to take a vote by secret ballot.''
