ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone asked me a question yesterday as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs about an article by Father Frank Brennan in the Catholic Leader of 4 December 1988 concerning the Yarrabah Aboriginal community in north Queensland. Honourable senators will recall that most of the matters were directed actually to the responsibilities of Senator Richardson. I am advised that the allegations raised by Senator Stone about Senator Richardson's dealings with the Yarrabah Aboriginal community are totally false.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by Senator Richardson's office that the Yarrabah Aboriginal community has been, in fact, extensively consulted by the Federal Government about the World Heritage nomination of the wet tropics of Queensland. Senator Richardson met with the Chairman of the Yarrabah Community Council in Cairns in September 1987 and with the entire Council in Canberra in October 1988. He has written not once but three times to the Council Chairman.

In addition, officers of the Federal Government's Cairns rainforest unit have visited Yarrabah to discuss World Heritage listing on four occasions. Another three meetings have been held in Cairns. These matters and others have been set out by Senator Richardson in a detailed three-page response to the article in question. I table the letter and seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard. The original of the letter is in Brazil.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE
ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND
TERRITORIES
7 December 1988
The Editor
The Catholic Leader
P.O. Box 334
FORTITUDE VALLEY QLD 4006
Dear Sir

I was disappointed with the number of inaccuracies contained in Fr Frank Brennan's front page article in the Catholic Leader of 4 December. Despite the impression conveyed by the article, the Yarrabah Aboriginal Community in North Queensland has been extensively consulted by the Federal Government about the World Heritage nomination of the Wet Tropics of Queensland.

Fr Brennan implies that I have somehow ignored the Yarrabah community or refused to allow them to put their case. Nothing could be further from the truth. I met with the Chairman of the Yarrabah Community Council (with other Aboriginal leaders) in Cairns on 3 September 1987 and with the full Council in Canberra on 18 October 1988. I have written three letters setting out in some detail the implications of listing for the community. Officers of the Federal Government's Cairns Rainforest Unit have visited Yarrabah for consultations on 4 occasions. Another 3 meetings have been held in Cairns.

Apart from these formal meetings, there have been numerous telephone discussions between officers of the Rainforest Unit and representatives of the Yarrabah community. Other representatives of the Federal Government such as Mr John Gayler MP, Member for Leichhardt, and staff of the Minister for Local Government, Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds, have also visited Yarrabah to discuss the World Heritage nomination.

In June 1988 the Federal Government organised and paid for a visit to the Northern Territory by members of Yarrabah and other North Queensland Aboriginal communities for consultations with Aboriginals from Uluru and Kakadu National Parks. Both those national parks are inscribed on the World Heritage List. All of Uluru National Park is Aboriginal land. About one third of Kakadu National Park is Aboriginal land.
These matters have been acknowledged by the Yarrabah community. The Council Chairman wrote to me on 28 June 1988 that ``we have had continuing discussions with Commonwealth . . . officials''.

It is true that I have not been to Yarrabah itself. However, I had arranged to visit on 8 August 1988 but the visit was cancelled because members of the Council were not available to meet with me. A planned visit in July 1988 by members of my personal staff was also cancelled when my staff were advised that the Council was interested only in talking with me.

Fr Brennan is not correct in implying that the Federal Government made an error in including Yarrabah land. It is also not correct to imply that the Yarrabah Aboriginal community has been treated differently from other private landowners. It is true that I announced in November 1987 that private land within the nominated area would be kept to a minimum. However, private blocks which were essential to the integrity of the nomination had to be included. Thus, in my letter to the Yarrabah Council Chairman of 23 November 1988, I explained that it would be inappropriate to delete some of the finest and least represented rainforest (i.e. the Yarrabah rainforest) from the nomination. Exactly the same situation applies to 131 freehold blocks elsewhere in the nominated area.

Of course, there is nothing unusual about people living and working in a World Heritage Area. Apart from Uluru and Kakadu National Parks which support viable Aboriginal communities as well as a thriving tourism industry, Australians live and work on the Great Barrier Reef, the Willandra Lakes region of NSW and Lord Howe Island, all of which are on the World Heritage List. A wide range of activities are undertaken in World Heritage areas in other countries, such as the Rocky Mountains in Canada which includes towns and farming communities.
The Yarrabah Aboriginal community has been given a number of assurances about the implications of World Heritage listing. On 22 January 1988, I wrote to the Council Chairman:
``I assure all Aboriginal communities who have land included in the listing that, provided World Heritage values are not unduly compromised, there is no intention to restrict traditional activities.

In particular, the Federal Government will not limit the traditional use of or access to these forests by Aboriginal people. The use of forest resources for the manufacture of artefacts or for traditional purposes can continue. In addition, activities such as hunting and food gathering will not be stopped.
I understand that Yarrabah has a small sawmilling operation for supplying timber to the community. I wish to assure you that the activities of your mill will not be affected by the listing.

Kakadu National Park is one example where World Heritage listing has brought benefits to local aboriginal people. I believe your community will also discover that World Heritage will give you a better chance of both protecting and developing your land in accordance with the wishes of your people.

I assure you any rights that your community has so recently gained with the Queensland Government's Deed of Grant in Trust legislation will not be diminished or compromised. Indeed, World Heritage should give you even greater and more secure control over your lands.

The Federal Government hopes to develop co-operatively with the Queensland Government appropriate management for the region. This will involve certain employment initiatives and regional development proposals in keeping with the World Heritage values of the area. I would be more than willing to discuss any such proposals your community may wish to put forward in conjunction with other relevant Federal and State Departments.''

These assurances were honoured in January 1988 when regulations to prevent logging in the nominated World Heritage Area were promulgated. The regulations contained a specific provision exempting Aboriginal people. Similarly, other private landowners are permitted to continue using timber from their own land for non-commercial purposes.

I have also given assurances to the Yarrabah community that World Heritage listing will not mean control of their land passing to the Federal government. On 23 November 1988 I wrote to the Council Chairman that ``Aboriginal communities will play an important role, not only in World Heritage matters concerning their own land, but also in the management of the whole area.''

On 28 November 1988 I reiterated this assurance in another letter to the Council Chairman noting that ``the management of the Wet Tropics will continue to recognise existing authorities within the area''. I said ``As the responsible authority, the Yarrabah Community Council will continue to have prime carriage of all matters related to Yarrabah''.

The Federal Government is determined not only that Aboriginal people will have a significant role to play in the future management of the Wet Tropics but that World Heritage listing will provide increased benefits and opportunities for Aboriginals.

As a final observation, I would note that it is unfortunate the Yarrabah community has had so much blatant pressure put on it for purely political reasons by the Queensland Government to oppose World Heritage Listing.
The Federal Government's commitment to World Heritage and Aboriginal aspirations is clearly demonstrated at Kakadu and Uluru. I believe the Wet Tropics will be a similar success.
Yours sincerely
GRAHAM RICHARDSON

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE TO ADVISE ON AUSTRALIA'S IMMIGRATION POLICIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Senate was provided with a series of documents by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). These related, first, to the Government's response to the FitzGerald inquiry report, entitled Immigration-A Commitment to Australia, the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies; secondly, with a number of press releases which give further details of the Government's response to the FitzGerald inquiry; thirdly, with a table providing the outline of the Government's response to 73 recommendations of the FitzGerald inquiry; and finally, a statement on the question of criminal deportation the Government has put down relating to a number of matters affecting the way in which the Government believes matters of criminal deportation should be handled.

SPEECH.PARA: I will start my remarks by dealing with the question of criminal deportation. On behalf of the Opposition I wish to indicate simply that we understand the purpose for which the Government has made this statement. It is in order to provide a guidance to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to the Federal Court of Australia under the new provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act about the interpretations which these bodies should bring to bear in dealing with the question of potentially overturning ministerial deportation orders and the extent to which they should have greater regard to the policy determinations of the Government in criminal deportation matters. The statement primarily indicates that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court should take into account two particular matters which they may not have emphasised sufficiently in their judgments in the past. The first of these is the extent to which they should have regard to the total criminal history of the person who has been designated as the recipient of the deportation order. The second is the extent to which they should have particular regard to the importance which the Government and indeed the Opposition attach to the significance of deportation orders which involve people who have been convicted for trafficking in illicit drugs.

On behalf of the Opposition I say that we believe it is a perfectly proper practice for the Government to indicate to judicial authorities the outline of government policy which should be borne in mind when making these determinations. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, following changes made some years ago to the Acts Interpretation Act, the courts and judicial authorities are to have regard to certain government policy statements. We think this is a proper way in which the Government should go about advising the courts of its policy parameters. The Opposition certainly endorses the view that the total criminal history of people who are the subject of deportation orders ought to be borne in mind by the courts. We share the Government's view of the significance which is attached to the fight against trafficking in illicit drugs. Therefore, we have no difficulties with the statement put down by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethic Affairs dealing with the question of criminal deportation. As a result it is not my intention to spend any further time dealing with that matter.

The main thrust of Senator Ray's comments today dealt with the so-called FitzGerald report. The Opposition shares with the Minister a feeling of appreciation to Dr Stephen FitzGerald and the members of his Committee for having produced this extremely important report. The FitzGerald report has opened public debate on one of the great sacred cows of Australian politics, namely, our immigration policy. Since the end of the Second World War immigration policies have occupied a central place in public policy in Australia. However, in recent years the Australian Labor Party has undertaken a series of exercises in social engineering under the guise of changes in immigration policy which for various reasons it has sought to conceal from public debate in Australia. The important thing about the FitzGerald inquiry is that it has put back on the public agenda discussion about immigration policy. That is a very significant contribution in itself. The nature of Australian society is profoundly changed, profoundly shaped by changes in immigration policy. The people of Australia are entitled to know what the Government is doing, what the Government is seeking to achieve, and to have the opportunity to express a view as to whether they approve or disapprove of what the Government is doing. This is a very important issue for everybody in Australia.

To the extent that the FitzGerald inquiry has opened this area up for renewed public debate it has rendered a very important service to the people of Australia. It is perhaps a pity that a great deal of the subsequent public debate about the FitzGerald inquiry or its recommendations has been manifestly uninformed. I look, for example, at an article which appeared in the August-September 1988 journal Migration. It refers to comments by Mr Tony Bonnici, a member of the FitzGerald committee. At that stage Mr Bonnici was still the senior Deputy Chairman of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia. In that article he is reported as follows:
Mr Bonnici said FECCA-
that is, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia-
and the ethnic communities had failed to look at the report, and the immigration issues involved, from the wider national perspective.

That is an extremely prescient and very important comment. To a very large extent a great deal of the debate about the FitzGerald inquiry has been ill-informed and based on the prejudices of people who have not only not read the preliminary document but who have also not read the model Bill presented as volume 2 of the inquiry and the papers contained in volume 3, which are papers of a consultative nature which are very important in understanding the broad background from which the FitzGerald inquiry moved towards the production of its final report.

The next point I want to make is perhaps the most important in some respects. I believe it is a great pity that given the choice between a response which really responds to Australia's national interest, the course of action we know Senator Ray favoured, and a response based primarily upon the promotion of the Labor Party's sordid and narrow political interests, the response Dr Theophanous, the honourable member for Calwell, and the Caucus immigration committee favoured, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) decided to lend his weight to the latter. This response in fact has indicated the extent to which the Prime Minister personally has capitulated to the demands of the left wing of the Labor Party, to put section before nation, to put division before harmony, and, above all, to put party interest before principle. It is a continuing capitulation of the Prime Minister to the demands of the left wing of the Labor Party, this time in immigration, in exactly the same way as he has capitulated to the demands of the left wing in the debate on Aboriginal affairs and as he has nailed his colours to the mast of his left wing Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, rather than endorsing the rational, sensible view which spokesmen for the Labor Party such as Senator McMullan and Senator Collins might otherwise have advocated. It is above all a capitulation to the left wing of the Labor Party as part of the Prime Minister's agenda to shaft Mr Keating and to ensure that the debate within the Australian Labor Party over its leadership moves in a particular direction. It is a great shame that, just as in Aboriginal affairs, so it is in immigration: the Prime Minister has embarked upon a course of division, a course of the promotion of the Labor Party's sectional interests, and a clear determination to avoid giving a commitment which responds to the real necessity to provide a balanced policy which serves the national interest of all Australians.

I turn to the most important single statement in the matrix provide to indicate the response of the Government to the FitzGerald inquiry recommendations. The Government has decided to reject the central thrust of the FitzGerald recommendations-namely, that immigration policy and selection criteria be changed so as to reflect a great weighting upon skills and up the promotion of a skill component within the immigration intake. Regarding recommendation No. 49 in the matrix document, the Committee recommended:
That the highest weightings go to the skills and entrepreneurship factors.
The Government's response states:
Not accepted: alternative points system adopted on basis of advice of National Population Council.

The fundamental thrust of the FitzGerald inquiry, that immigration policy should be changed so as to reflect a greater priority for the introduction of skills within the migration component, has been centrally addressed and fundamentally rejected by the Australian Labor Party. That is a gross long term betrayal of the real interests of the Australian community. Nothing could be more important for Australia than the improvement of the skills of our population, whether it happens to be in the terms of the people coming here as migrants or the people who are born, educated and trained here and who will have to contend with the position that Australia finds itself in during the latter part of this century and the early part of the next.

The fundamental requirement for Australia to improve its skills, thereby improving its productivity, thereby improving its living standards, has been fundamentally addressed by the FitzGerald inquiry and has been absolutely rejected by the Australian Labor Party. That is a tragedy. It is a betrayal. It is a long term undermining of Australia's capacity to exist, to compete and to prosper in the world of the twenty-first century. This Government will stand fundamentally condemned for its failure to adopt that recommendation of the FitzGerald inquiry.

It is perhaps interesting to look now in detail at the Minister's statement, which was tabled this morning, particularly at a number of parts of that statement which essentially endorse what the Opposition has been saying about social policy and migration policy in Australia. Let me turn first to to the statement on page 4:
In terms of social goals, Australia supports the concept of the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society.

That statement is absolutely central to what Mr Howard and the Opposition have been saying in our manifesto. Future Directions. The Prime Minister, in Fremantle and elsewhere, has been making statements designed to denigrate, to debase and to debauch Mr Howard's statements about the importance of the family unit. Mr Hawke has, at every stage, attempted to ridicule Mr Howard's comments about the centrality of the family to Australian social policy. We have seen the Prime Minister on television in the West making disparaging and negative comments about the Liberal and National parties' emphasis upon the family as the central unit of Australian society and the central point of Australian social policy. Yet here we have, in Senator Ray's document, a clear and unequivocal statement that Mr Howard is absolutely correct in describing the concept of the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society.
Secondly, I turn to page 2 of Senator Ray's statement. He says:
The issue of multiculturalism was not central to the report-
that is, the FitzGerald report-
and the subsequent attention afforded to it did not add to the community's understanding of the issue and was at some cost to informed debate on the core immigration issues in the report.

That is not accepted by the Opposition as a correct statement because that is predicated upon the Government's failure to state the clear intended outcome of immigration policy in this country. We say: Multiculturalism, although not integral to the way in which one constructs an immigration or migrant selection policy, is nevertheless of vital importance because it is important to lay down what a government expects to achieve for Australian society as an outcome of its immigration policy. One cannot have a coherent immigration policy without setting out clearly the outcomes and the goals of that policy.

When the Liberal and National parties describe their immigration policy as being based on the concept of being one nation, one Australia-to use Mr Howard's phrase-that indicates precisely that we on this side of the chamber have a coherent view about the outcome of immigration policy as distinct from simply a series of disaggregated policy initiatives which this Government has pursued. The Minister, on page 2 of his statement, says:
As a quite separate domestic policy, multiculturalism seeks to ensure that those born in Australia and those who migrated to Australia are equally accorded their rights.
We make it perfectly clear in paragraph 1.3 in the preamble to the Liberal and National parties' published immigration policy:

All of the policies of the Liberal and National Parties are based upon respect for the value of each individual. We are totally committed to equal treatment and equal opportunity for all Australians regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin within the framework of a just and tolerant society.
When Mr Howard was interviewed on 26 August 1988 he said that there was no doubt:

. . . all of the policies of the Liberal and National Parties were based upon the proposition that all Australians, irrespective of ethnic, racial or cultural background were entitled to complete equality of treatment.

In that respect the statement put down today by Senator Robert Ray endorses not only Mr Howard's view about the central role of the family in Australian society but also Mr Howard's and the Opposition's view about the complete equality of treatment to be accorded to people within the wider concept of the Australian nation.
I turn to page 5 of the Minister's statement. He says:
The Government accepts the Committee's message that immigration is for all Australians and that it should be in the national interest.

We on this side of the chamber have consistently made precisely that point. Immigration policy should not be designed to favour one group, one section, or one community; it should be designed to favour all Australians, and it should be in the national interest. That is the third important element of the Opposition's immigration policy which Senator Ray's statement today clearly indicates the Government and, indeed, the community accept as entirely valid.

Within the short time which is available to us today to debate this important statement I will make only one or two other comments. The first concerns the mischievous comment made by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in his statement when he says:
It is regrettable that the Opposition sought to exploit this issue in the course of the Government's deliberations on the Committee's report.
That lie was nailed by a member of the Australian Labor Party, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, who was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 27 August 1988 as follows:

The Member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, said that he was ``disgusted'' with the way the Government had manipulated the immigration debate, and laid much of the blame on the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

Nobody has sought to exploit ethnic differences and tensions within this community more thoroughly, more comprehensively or more widely or cynically than has the Prime Minister and members of his Party. I exclude from this Senator Ray. He has attempted to get some rationality into this debate. He has at the end of the day been comprehensively rolled by Dr Theophanous and the Caucus immigration committee. His view about the balance of skill and family reunion migration, about the direction of policy, which he had put up to Cabinet, did not prevail. The reason it did not prevail in Cabinet was that the Prime Minister and his acolytes decided that the sordid misuse of immigration policy by Dr Theophanous and people who take his view of the future of Australian society should be preferred to the rational and sensible views being advanced by the Minister responsible for immigration, Senator Robert Ray.

I turn to the next part of the Minister's statement and commend him for a number of the initiatives which he has managed to get through Cabinet. I commend him for having decided to maintain the grant of resident status policy rather than subsume that within the wider immigration policy as was recommended by the FitzGerald inquiry. I congratulate him on having maintained the degree of ministerial discretion which he has sought to maintain and which we think is appropriate for a Minister to exercise on behalf of the Australian community. However, I direct a question to Senator Robert Ray which I hope that during the debate he or a spokesman for the Labor Party will seek to address. The Minister says that he will remove himself from an overview of the recommendations made under the second level appeal on immigration cases by whatever it is that is to replace the Immigration Review Panel (IRP). The Minister says in his statement:
I shall also retain a general statutory power to override any decision of the review panel which, while consistent with the regulations, acts against the interests of the applicant.

In other words, the Minister says, `If a negative decision is made by the immigration review panel in relation to any individual, I retain the right to overrule that'. I ask the Government and the Minister: If the immigration review panel agrees to permit a person to come to Australia will the Minister reserve to himself the right to overturn that recommendation in the national interest? The Minister makes it clear that if the IRP or its equivalent recommends against an individual the Minister may review that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is tabled in Parliament.

—I appreciate what Senator Schacht is saying-that the decision will be tabled in Parliament. If the immigration review panel rules in favour of an applicant, will the Minister reserve to himself the right to overturn the positive decision? In other words, will he reserve the right to say, `The panel has recommended that the individual should come to Australia. I overturn that decision because it is in the national interest to do so.'? That is simply unclear from the statement that the Minister has made. We want to know whether the Minister preserves for himself the right to overturn the decision in either direction.
—Do you think he should?

—Absolutely. We take the view that if the IRP or its equivalent has recommended that a person should come to this country and the Minister believes in the national interest that that person should not, the Minister's view under those circumstances should prevail.
—And be tabled.

—And indeed be tabled. But the Minister's statement is simply not clear on that matter and I am asking for clarification. We also express some concern about the Bureau of Immigration Research. This body is to be funded and in a full year its cost to the taxpayer will be about $4m. It will have a staff of 41. We hope that it will focus primarily upon the question of research and upon the question of commissioning research. To the extent that it may become simply a tool to promote the immigration policies of the government of the day as distinct from commissioning research and dealing with objective questions, we are concerned about it. Whether it becomes the Department's version of a National Media Liaison Service is an important question because if it fulfils the former role, that is, as a research body, it ought to be supported. If, however, it simply becomes a tool of propaganda on behalf of the specific political policies of the day, the Opposition has very considerable concerns about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is perfectly relaxed about matters such as the process of mandatory deportation in certain circumstances. It believes that that will be a significant improvement in light of the uncertainties which exist and which were drawn to the Senate's attention yesterday in the Minister's discussion of the case of Mr Kurtovik. We believe that the problems which the Minister identified yesterday need to be overcome and that the system which the Minister is proposing as far as that is concerned is perfectly acceptable.

A large number of my colleagues wish to speak on this matter, and unfortunately our time today is restricted. I make only one other point. I express some degree of disappointment that the Government has decided that the important question of the recognition of overseas qualifications should be referred to yet another committee-on this occasion the structural adjustment committee of Cabinet. In light of the fact that the Fry Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications reported in December 1982, and the Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications reported fairly recently, I think we ought to be getting some positive determinations and decisions rather than giving a reference to yet another committee to look at what is a very important question. The Fry Committee laid down a number of guidelines and made a number of recommendations, some of which have been acted upon, others of which have been reported upon by the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications. It is a pity that six or so years down the track from the Fry Committee their recommendations are being sent off to yet another committee, this time a Cabinet committee. This is an area which requires some firm determination and decision making. The Opposition believes it is a pity that it has not been addressed more comprehensively.

There are a number of other important issues which arise in the field of immigration. I just draw attention to two papers of some importance. One paper by Paolo Totaro, entitled `Prejudice and Social Cohesion' was presented to the Italians in Australia Conference in Wollongong earlier this year. The other was presented by Arlene D'Mello, Coordinator of the Victorian Cooperative on Children's Services for Ethnic Groups, entitled `Is There Something Wrong With the Australian Immigration Program? Both papers bear study by honourable senators. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table those two papers as I do not have time to discuss them.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Immigration is a critical national issue. The nature of Australian society is profoundly shaped by its immigration policies. The Opposition believes that in many respects the Government has failed in its responses to the challenges presented by the FitzGerald inquiry.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to start by congratulating the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) on his statement, which I believe strikes the correct balance between the conflicting social, economic and humanitarian pressures that everybody is under in resolving questions about immigration and ethnic affairs. I had promised my colleagues that I would be on my best behaviour today and that I would comment only on the substance of the issues and not be at all provocative. However, I do feel that I must respond to some of the things said by Senator Puplick and will try to so so in my least provocative manner. I have also indicated, in the interests of the management of the business of the Senate, that I will try to keep my remarks relatively brief.

SPEECH.PARA: The party political remarks made by Senator Puplick early in his speech reminded me of a book I once bought for my young daughter before the school holidays. It was called What to do when there's nothing to do. The first part of Senator Puplick's speech sounded like `what to say when you have nothing to say'. He really was somewhat desperate. I have known the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, a very long time and know him perhaps as well as anybody else in the Senate. I have heard the Prime Minister accused of a lot of things, some of which I have agreed with and some I have not. I have never heard him accused of being `a captive of the Left'. I actually thought I was going to be ill I was laughing so much when Senator Puplick said that. It is so hysterically wrong when people look for conspiracy theories to explain other people's actions. All it tells one is what determines their own actions.

There are three other comments that Senator Puplick made to which I wish to respond. Firstly, Senator Puplick talked about the Government attempting to conceal its actions in the area of immigration and that, therefore, it was a good thing that the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies had come down to open up the debate. It made me wonder who had initiated the FitzGerald Committee report. I had to have a rethink because I have always thought that the Government had initiated it and that we opened up the debate. I had a quick rethink, I had a look at the report, and I found that I am right and that Senator Puplick is wrong. It was just an attempt to tie in the absurd allegations of the `Back to the Future' document about social engineering, so he had to make something up to give it a link. That was also the justification for the absurd and absolutely incorrect remarks he made in relation to the statement on page 4 of the Minister's statement concerning the concept of the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society. Senator Ray's statement is correct and it is a statement shared by most people, whether they are members of such families or not. Even if they are not, they certainly accept that the majority of Australians see the family as the predominant group unit of social organisation.

Secondly, to contend that the Prime Minister in any way ridiculed that concept is either a gross misunderstanding of the English language or a deliberate attempt to mislead. What the Prime Minister was doing in the speech in Fremantle, in response to the `Back to the Future' document, was saying that the actions of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) are in direct contradiction to his advocated concerns. He pretends, feigns, concern about the living standards of ordinary Australians, but everything he says and does entirely contradicts it. It is in no way a contradiction, with concern for the family, to say that someone else who cries crocodile tears does not have that concern.

The third matter to which Senator Puplick referred, and to which I wish to respond briefly, was his breathtaking allegation that in the area of immigration the Government was concerned with division before harmony. That the Government in the political debate in Australia should be accused of engineering division in society in the area of immigration only means that Senator Puplick, in his very busy role in environment and the arts, has not had much time to examine what has been happening in Australia or even in the Liberal Party in his own State about the issues of immigration and about whom Liberal Party State members of parliament in his own State hold responsible for that division. It is certainly not the Australian Labor Party or the Prime Minister; it is the Leader of the Opposition and quite properly so.

That brings me to the last point. This is not something that Senator Puplick said; this is something that he did not say. I listened very carefully for half an hour and he said nothing about the principles of non-discrimination in immigration. I do not blame him. I am sure, in his own way, he is privately committed to the principle that immigration in Australia should remain non-discriminatory. But he has said not one word about that very important and fundamental issue because he knows that the statement of the Leader of the Opposition, from which he has refused to resile, that Asian immigration should be slowed cannot be got around. I will be interested in any comments Senator Panizza might like to make to enhance the wonderful and enlightened remarks that he made in Esperance about Asian migrants while I was, unfortunately, in Asia. My concern is that the Leader of the Opposition has said, and he has refused to resile from it, that we need to slow down Asian immigration, in either a blatant or a misconceived attempt to facilitate the excesses of those involved in the extreme debate on anti-Asian immigration in Australia. It is a tragedy that that statement goes uncorrected.

I want to come back now to the substance of the statement before us. It strikes the correct balance between the conflicting social, economic and humanitarian pressures which confront decision makers in this area. If I wanted to summarise it, it is essentially an Australian policy. It fits within the broader strategy and framework of Government economic, social and foreign policy over the next few years. It is important that it is seen within that strategic framework. It is not a statement in isolation; it is a statement within a framework of a government which has a vision of Australia towards which it is working.

I want to concentrate on three areas of the reforms outlined in the statement-those with economic implications, the administrative reforms and what I have summarised as the political and humanitarian aspects-and then reflect briefly, if time permits, on what steps might follow these reforms. Before I do so, I want to join with Senator Puplick-I have disagreed with him on a few things-in congratulating those involved in the FitzGerald Committee for the work that they did. It is a pity that it has been misunderstood, particularly with regard to multiculturalism. The Committee said correctly that the community did not understand that issue. That misunderstanding has been compounded in the debate subsequently, particularly by the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition. The Committee pointed out correctly the problems of the increasing median age of people coming to Australia, of the declining skill level and of the questions about economic focus. That has led to the broad thrust of these reforms without throwing out the benefits of the existing systems and mechanisms.

I turn, firstly, to the question of business migration. I think there is bipartisan agreement in the Parliament that business migration is beneficial. There has been some public statement-not by the Opposition, I hasten to say, and not by Senator Puplick-that the Government is planning to cut business migration. That is not the policy as outlined in this statement. There is an assessment that the likely outcome of some recent events, which I will not dwell on because they may be a bit diverting and provocative, is that the level of business migration might slow slightly. But that is not Government policy; there is no ceiling on business migration to make that happen other than the 54,000 person limit on economic migration overall. Business migration has been rising rapidly and we may have more than the 10,000 predicted. I also welcome the increased emphasis on monitoring of business migration to ensure that the mooted economic benefits do flow.

As a minor issue, but one that is to be welcomed, I note that in addition there is a recognition of concern by State and Territory governments-I do not think it will be an issue here in the Australian Capital Territory-over population distribution trends. I welcome and support the decision to give extra points to an applicant if the sponsor lives in an area consistent with State or Territory government settlement priorities. It will be principally the responsibility of the States to designate those areas. That is of proper concern to the Federal Government with the important issues of city and urban planning.

On the issue of skills, there is a broader strategy of skill development in Australia, within which the immigration matter has to be addressed. I support the priority given to the training and retraining of Australians. There is an obligation on all of us-on our education system and on Australian industry-to train more Australians. But it is necessary also to recognise that, even with the incentive, the pressure, the persuasion on Australian industry to train more Australians, about which the Government is currently involved in discussions, there will be gaps. Immigration can fill these gaps and, in so doing, create more jobs than the immigrants take. Employment remains a driving force in this Australian Labor Government's policy, and so it should be. Immigration has a substantial contribution to make in this area.

On a related issue, I want to express views essentially in support of those of Senator Puplick about the importance of prompt action on the question of assessment and recognition of overseas qualifications. I am happy that this has been referred to the structural adjustment committee of Cabinet, provided, as I expect, that the matter is dealt with promptly by it. It is important that this is seen within a broader context. That is the role of the structural adjustment committee. It is very important that this matter is not delayed. I look forward to the statement of Government policy on it and a positive Opposition response.

I turn briefly to the question of administrative reforms to comment on two relatively minor ones consistent with the FitzGerald Committee approach and which are appropriate. One is the tightening of the focus of settlement strategies, more particularly in the area of new arrivals. There is also the emphasis on the settlement problems faced by women coming to this country and an emphasis on the multilingual skills of those recruited to the Department. In supporting that, I say briefly that one of the great problems in our country is that Australians tend to be far too monolingual. I include myself in that. A very sparse knowledge of the French language learned at high school does not contribute significantly to a broader understanding. It is good that in Australian primary education attention is now being paid to issues of language education. I regard that as a very important part of a future strategy for Australian education and training.

I also support the changes to the review procedures outlined in this document. The departmental review unit should be able to provide in simple cases a prompt and efficient review to correct errors of fact or to accommodate rapid change in circumstances. But, of course, it is not enough; no-one pretends it is. Therefore, the enhanced immigration review panels, with their function of merit review and their capacity to make what are in most instances final decisions, are an appropriate format and are overdue. I support the fact that the ministerial review is reduced but retained in some important areas, and I also welcome the tabling requirements as part of the continuing process of opening up the debate in Australia on immigration.

There is a part which I welcome and which I think in a sense can be seen as very typically Robert Ray, where he talks about guaranteeing the numbers. It is an excellent concept in itself, but it is very typical of this very efficient Minister. It has nothing to do with electoral matters but it is part of the statement on page 7 where he refers to the floating pass mark, which the Committee recommended to ensure that the best people are selected and that the numbers in the overall program are not exceeded. It seems to me that the floating pass mark concept has the capacity to work as a shock absorber so that, where the inflow of migrants is greater than expected in designated areas where we might wish it to be enhanced, such as in business migration or a particular skills area, within the points system it will accommodate the priority selection process for other applicants within that broader economic category. That is a proper process for the important matter of normal government administration, which is the allocation of necessarily limited resources amongst virtually unlimited demands.

On the political, humanitarian aspect of the report, I welcome the maintenance of a commitment to refugee intake. That has been a desirable feature of the immigration policies of all parties in Australia, and I support the continuation of the Determination of Refugee Status Committee with its process for reviewing individual refugee applications. I support the rejection of coercive measures to enforce citizenship. Citizenship is very important and it is appropriate that the FitzGerald Committee gave greater emphasis to it and that the Government has responded with the Year of Citizenship, with the focused attention, publicity and priority it has been given. But I do not think we ought to be starving people into it. I support the affirmation of non-discrimination but I have dealt with that sufficiently in my previous remarks.

In relation to the Bureau of Immigration Research, I, unlike Senator Puplick, welcome this proposal wholeheartedly. The FitzGerald Committee is absolutely correct, and the Minister in adopting the proposal has acted wisely. It is very important, firstly, that the information base on this issue is broadened. I know that was not a matter about which Senator Puplick was expressing reservations but I believe that one of the great problems-there are several-in this ill-informed debate is that governments of all persuasions have not been totally discharging their obligation to establish a proper factual base.

The second problem is the lack of adequate communication of those facts which has enabled people to feed on rumour, innuendo and misunderstanding. Every senator has probably been to a public meeting where the most outrageous assertions have been made, as though they were facts, about the relative proportions of Asian and European migration, the proportion of Asians in Australia or, getting away from the racial issue, about the alleged benefits which are given to migrants on their arrival-that they all get cars, they all get jobs and they all get all sorts of wonderful assistance-which, of course, are not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them get into Parliament.

—Indeed; perhaps not enough. It is not yet compulsory, is it Senator Puplick? We have a very important role to play, as has the Bureau, in disseminating those facts. I see the question of its communications function as something similar to the proposed Canadian Race Relations Foundation which has an important job in spending the money on `race relations and cross cultural understanding, preserving heritage cultures and languages and strengthening community support and participation'. That was a quote of the Canadian Multiculturalism Minister, Garry Weiner, just prior to the last election. I am not sure whether he has been re-appointed, but the Government was re-elected.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to a point that I have been discussing over the last several months with regard to immigration, on which I wish to conclude; that is, the initiative of the Canadian Government, the Canadian House of Commons, which unanimously passed a Multiculturalism Bill on 18 July this year in the shadow of the election. Yet no politician in Canada succumbed to the temptation to take a cheap shot and exploit possible racial tensions for local domestic political benefit. The Canadian Parliament unanimously carried a resolution on the multiculturalism Bill. The Canadians amongst other things say that the Bill:
. . . reinforces the direct responsibility of all departments and institutions of the Government to implement the new multiculturalism policy.

The resolution describes multiculturalism as a `fundamental characteristic of our evolving Canadian heritage and identity'. It unanimously stresses the importance of preserving and enhancing the multicultural heritage of Canadians and, inter alia, states:
(1) It is hereby declared to be the policy of the Government of Canada to:

(b) recognize and promote the understanding that multiculturalism is a fundamental characteristic of Canadian heritage and identity and that it provides an invaluable resource in the shaping of Canada's future;
(d) recognize the existence of communities whose members share a common origin and their historic contribution to Canadian society, and enhance their development;
(h) foster the recognition and appreciation of the diverse cultures of Canadian society and promote the reflection and the evolving expressions of those cultures;
(2) It is further declared to be the policy of the Government of Canada that all federal institutions shall:
(c) promote policies, programs and practices that enhance the understanding of and respect for the diversity of the members of Canadian society;
(f) generally, carry on their activities in a manner that is sensitive and responsive to the multicultural reality of Canada.

I welcome the fact that the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia at its recent conference supported the concept of a charter of multiculturalism for Australia. I look forward to that step being taken in Australia either by way of a Bill, a charter or other statement. I welcome this ministerial statement as another major step forward. Together with the FitzGerald report it should enhance community debate on immigration, ethnic affairs and multiculturalism. I congratulate this Minister and his predecessors who have initiated and developed the report and the statement. I thank the members of the Committee for their contribution. I welcome the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan who preceded me in this immigration debate made a reference to the non-discrimination principle and took a cheap shot at Senator Puplick who led on this matter for the Opposition in that he insufficiently referred to the well-established non-discrimination principle in the Opposition parties. It is a bipartisan principle in this debate in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind Senator McMullan and those in the chamber that the Opposition parties in adopting the immigration and ethnic affairs policy some months ago reiterated a longstanding principle on immigration. They stated:

In selecting between one individual and another, immigration policy will not discriminate against applicants on the basis of their race, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, gender or religion.

It cannot be clearer than that. Those are the very words that are used by the report of the FitzGerald Commission of Inquiry to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies that is before us in this debate. They are the same words that have occurred in the last six policies of the Liberal and National parties. The non-discrimination principle is supported by the Opposition. We are glad to see that the support given to the non-discrimination principle in the FitzGerald report is expressed in precisely the same terms as our long established policies in the Opposition. I also draw attention to the Opposition's clear statement:

All of the policies of the Liberal and National Parties are based upon respect for the value of each individual. We are totally committed to equal treatment and equal opportunity for all Australians regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin within the framework of a just and tolerant society.

Indeed, it is heartening to see that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in his speech here this morning reiterated that principle himself. It is right to say that he borrowed the concept of one Australia from the clearly expressed support for the concept that we want to put up front in immigration policy debate in this country; that is, that we are one nation, we are one Australia and we want to ensure that every Australian has an equal capacity to contribute to Australia without any barrier, without there being any second class citizen. That follows through to the non-discrimination principle in selecting potential Australians in an immigration policy.

We have before us the Government's response to a most important inquiry. About 15 months ago a thorough inquiry into Australia's immigration policies was set up. The execution of that inquiry cost some millions of dollars. The Chairman of that inquiry was Dr Stephen FitzGerald, an eminent Australian and a former Ambassador of this country to China. He is a person who has the confidence of all parties in this Senate chamber. In May this year members of the Committee brought their considered conclusions and recommendations to the Government. There were some 73 recommendations. They came as a great bombshell to the Labor Government. Members of the Committee said that they had weighed the immigration policy of the Government and found it wanting.

The Australian public does not have confidence in immigration. When members of the public were asked about this in public opinion polls, the majority said that they wanted to see an end to immigration because they could not see a positive outcome in the national interest. Many of us would want to give the evidence to the Australian public, especially in the post-war migration phase of the 1950s and 1960s, and I would say right through the 1970s as well, to show the positive gains that have come to Australia, such as the development of this country; the enhancement of our population; new schools; the demand for housing and education-every manner of commodity that is required due to the increased population that has flowed from migration. We can turn to every area of Australian life and see how it has been enhanced by the waves of immigration that have occurred over the last 40 years. But because of the mishandling of immigration by the present Labor Government over the last five or six years the Australian public does not have confidence any more in immigration. So it was timely that the FitzGerald report was commissioned and that that report was placed in the Government's hands in the middle of May.

For seven months the Government has been working out how it will respond to this bombshell. This report which condemned the conduct of the immigration policies of the present Government still has to be responded to. It is a clear and well argued report. It is only today, seven months later, that the Minister, Senator Robert Ray, has given us in this ministerial statement the Government's response to that Committee inquiry. It is a most disappointing document. It misses the opportunity presented by this most important report.

In Australia today the central, overriding issue in immigration policy is to renew public confidence in immigration. After five years of confusion and poor administration, the public does not have confidence in Australia's immigration program. This was the golden opportunity. The most important and far-reaching inquiry into immigration ever undertaken in this country was in the Government's hands. The present Minister, Senator Ray, came to his job with the support of all sides of this chamber. He had a reputation for understanding matters such as those involved in this portfolio. With a fresh and renewed start for looking at the Government's record, we thought that Senator Ray would be able to take this opportunity and give Australia a new direction-give back confidence to the Australian public. The Minister has not succeeded. He has failed to take up the opportunity that was given to him.

Let me reflect for a moment on the immigration debate that occurred in August and September this year in this chamber and throughout Australia. At the end of those weeks I wrote an article for the Age newspaper in which I summarised where we had reached. The questions that were raised in that debate led to statements reaffirming important and sound principles in immigration on all sides. In the first week of the Senate's sitting the debate led Government members, Opposition members and the Australian Democrats to outbid each other in their commitment to the established non-discrimination principle, and to their total rejection of policies expressed in terms of racial targeting. All parties were underlining, and continue to underline, their absolute commitment to the equality of all Australians. All parties were emphasising the importance of accepting cultural diversity and the fact that each tradition brings an enriching contribution to one Australia. At the end of that debate all parties said that all along they have pursued the objectives of one Australia.

At the end of August the new Minister, Senator Ray, was appointed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He realised that the two-month debate had also underlined the fact that the Government was found wanting in its conduct of immigration policy. I wrote the following article in the Age newspaper very well known to you, Mr Deputy President:
It is the renewal of public confidence that matters most and this will require a new level of genuine leadership and credible explanation.

The Prime Minister seems to have accepted this point and the person he has chosen to make the new start is Senator Robert Ray. This astute and influential Victorian was sworn in to the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio on 2 September.
The ball is at his feet. He has, quite genuinely, received good wishes from all sides in Parliament.

But if he fails to renew public confidence in immigration, that same Parliament will be unforgiving. For the sake of all Australians, his task is to turn away from the Hawke Government's five years of failure.

Public confidence can only be regained by addressing the policy mistakes of the past five years. This can be achieved by openly correcting the administration of policies so that they are neither underhand nor biased, and by a factual, credible explanation of what immigration should be all about anyway.
The debate's most useful starting point is the FitzGerald report into the Hawke Government's immigration policy.

Today the moment of truth came. The ball was at the Minister's feet. He failed this chamber, and he failed Australia. There has been no positive response to this most important report. What we have as a result of the Minister's statement today is business as usual. The Labor Government, lobbied by its Caucus committee, lobbied by various factions within its lay Party around the country, has said, `Don't let us give in to the firm recommendations, the principal recommendations, of this major inquiry, the FitzGerald report. Let us accept the marginal matters in which there is some merit, but as to the mainstream of our immigration approach of the last five years we will go on undeterred'.

I am very sad for the Minister, Senator Ray. He was rolled by the Prime Minister, rolled by Cabinet and rolled by the Caucus immigration committee. Now he stands in this chamber with the same mess about him as has been accumulated in all the years of the Labor Government. Does anyone here expect the public to have renewed confidence in immigration unless we have a change of government? I do not have that confidence. I believe that the only hope of getting the positive, central recommendations of the FitzGerald report implemented is to see the election of a Liberal-National Party government.

The Liberal and National parties are convinced that immigration policy should serve all Australians, that it should be in the national interest. That is why the central element of our policy is to attract to this country a majority of immigrants who have been chosen on the basis of the skills, the education, the competence and the contribution they will add to the Australian community. They will come here and create new jobs. They will not come here and take jobs away from Australians. There is a place for family reunion. If we have here a mother and two children-refugees who have been given a place in proper compassion by the Australian people-of course we want the husband of that family to be reunited with them. All things being equal, that husband should be able to come to Australia and be permanently resident here alongside his wife and children. We give proper weight to family reunion in our immigration policy. But the business as usual approach of the Labor Government is to keep family reunion as the major element of the immigration program it is endorsing here today. It has not heeded the recommendation of the FitzGerald report that the priority thrust in immigration selection be skill, education, youth, entrepreneurship and what will be a contribution to this country in the national interest.
The press already has it right. The Advertiser this morning under the headline `Government to dump key migration proposals', states:

Many of the key recommendations of the controversial FitzGerald report on future immigration policy will be dumped by the Federal Government today in a move that will appease the country's ethnic communities. . .
Dr FitzGerald made scathing criticisms of the immigration program earlier this year and said it should be given a sharper economic focus.

Articles such as that, which appeared this morning in newspapers all around Australia, are right. The opportunity that was before this Government has been passed up and wasted. The only way that Australians will regain confidence in immigration in this country will be through the election of a Liberal-National Party government. In his statement today the Minister gave some specific figures on the shape of immigration over the next two or three years. Page 5 of his statement states:
In the meantime, the migration program for the next two to three years is to be maintained at 140,000 places, comprising three main streams:

The Government retains the 140,000 places at a time when the business community and the Liberal and National parties are calling for increased migration based upon skill and not upon those who will come here and take away the jobs of Australians. Such expansion was passed up in the announcement. If the Labor Government is retained in office, we can expect the number to remain the same as that in recent years-that is, 140,000. The statement went on to outline the three main streams. This is the important point:
71,000 in a family category, 54,000 in an economic category and 14,000 in a humanitarian category, plus a special eligibility category of 1,000 places.

The arithmetic is correct; the figures add up to 140,000. Only 54,000 are in the economic category. Let me make it quite clear that the Opposition will reverse that priority. The priority in our selection will be based on the national interest-skill and education and those who will create jobs for themselves and other Australians-rather than those who will come on an extended family or second-cousin basis but with the denial of those skills and contributions to Australia, or where there is grave doubt as to whether there would be such a contribution.

We have to remember that there are a million people around the world knocking on our doors every year seeking to immigrate to Australia. Australia is a land of settlement and has a pattern of immigration. However, we have the luxury of choosing from those one million the 140,000 or 170,000 whom we believe will be most at home in Australia and will make the greatest contribution to this country. Unashamedly, whilst reserving an appropriate number of places for family reunion and humanitarian-refugee-migration, we will give priority to the economic category, based upon those skills that we need and the potential that new Australians will offer by coming here.

I reiterate that the central thrust of the FitzGerald report has been rejected in the Minister's statement. Because of that and because of the Minister's failure to respond to the positive recommendations of the FitzGerald Committee-the Minister was rolled by the Prime Minister, Cabinet and the Caucus committee-he now stands as a continuing part of Labor's failure in immigration. I am sad for the Minister. The prospects that we had in his appointment last August have not been lived up to. Not even his perception and skill have been able to shift the Australian Labor Party from its five or six year pattern in office in failing this country.

I conclude by referring to citizenship. The findings of the FitzGerald report were flashed all around Australia in the first few days after its publication. A headline went around alerting Australians to the longstanding situation that one million permanent residents in Australia who are eligible to be citizens have not taken up citizenship. We in the Liberal and National parties who place the highest value upon citizenship as the ultimate expression of an individual's commitment to Australia were alarmed at the extent of that failure of so many living in Australia-one-sixteenth of us-not taking out that ultimate expression of commitment to Australia. So we have called for a program to encourage those one million residents to take out citizenship. The FitzGerald report made specific recommendations that would enhance that encouragement, but the Government has said `Not accepted. Not accepted. Not accepted'. That demonstrates another important failure in the Government's response today.

I remind this chamber and the Australian people that the only option left to regain a sound immigration policy and for the public to have confidence in Australia's immigration policies is the election of a Liberal and National Party government. We must remember the important contributions that were made in the Menzies period, in the post-war period, by a Liberal and National Party government and the confidence that was expressed then in immigration by the Australian people. We must remember the Fraser Government's record, the delicate, careful and secure way it handled the Indo-China refugee crisis in those years and the way in which settlement was successful during the Fraser years. Those two great Menzies and Fraser periods of Australian public confidence in immigration stand in enormous contrast to the last five and six years of failure under the Labor Government. Today's announcement makes it clear that that lamentable record will continue. The only remedy will be the election of a Liberal and National Party government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Government's response to the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, the so-called FitzGerald report, and in particular the statement by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in that regard. We are also taking note of, and as necessary debating, the Minister's statement on criminal deportations, which he incorporated in Hansard this morning. I note at the outset-I do so with regret-the absence of the Minister from the chamber. I suppose two interpretations could be placed upon that absence. The first is that it is a rather overt rudeness to Opposition speakers on this matter. I do not wish to accuse the Minister of that. I have not thought Senator Ray-I would not say this about some of his colleagues-guilty of that particular behaviour characteristic. Secondly, I can only assume that, unless the Minister is urgently engaged in some matter of vitally important government business-I suppose that is always possible-his absence from the chamber has some relationship to his wish not to be too closely associated with the statement that he had to bring down this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for his courtesy in providing me this morning with advance copies of the statements and also a number of press releases on associated topics. I must confess that I have not had time to read all of them in full as there were a great many.

I wish to support fully, on behalf of National Party senators in particular, the response to the Minister's statement which has been given this afternoon by Senator Puplick. I propose to be relatively brief, as others wish to speak and as we have the pressure of the legislative timetable. But let me take up a few points of detail. I begin, like Senator Puplick, by welcoming the Minister's statement on criminal deportation. Our courts, particularly some of our lesser courts, sometimes take a great deal upon themselves when they overturn decisions of the Minister in this area. The guidance that the Minister and the Government through him seek to give to the courts by the statement that was delivered this morning on this matter is, therefore, entirely appropriate and, for my part, fully acceptable.

As to the immigration policy more generally, while there are many aspects of the Minister's statement with which I agree, there are also major aspects which I think have to be described as disappointing. In saying that I do not so much seek to criticise the Minister himself. On the contrary, he may well turn out to be an exceedingly good-that is to say, commonsense-Minister for immigration if he is given a chance to do so by his colleagues in the Cabinet. But I criticise those Cabinet colleagues, and particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who have caused the Minister to amend in many material and important particulars the statement which he would otherwise have chosen to bring down this morning, so as to make that statement more acceptable to the left-wing of the Australian Labor Party-what one might call in this case the Theophanous wing. Just as we have been referring in the last three days or so to the Hand wing of the Labor Party and the maladministration of Aboriginal Affairs policy, so today it is appropriate to refer to what will be called, for some time to come perhaps, the malformation of immigration policy by the Theophanous wing, the same left wing of the Party.

The unfortunate result of this is that we have in this document something of a mishmash, the precise outcome of which is very difficult to foresee but which, on the face of it-as other speakers on my side of the chamber have already indicated-seems unlikely to differ markedly in terms of outcome from the present policy. That, of course, is the policy which has led, and is still leading, to the strong upsurge of unease, disquiet and opposition which is being voiced increasingly strongly. I can only say that I cannot see this revised policy changing that in any significant degree, if indeed at all. That, I think, is a matter for considerable regret. I hope that I may be proved wrong in that regard because it is clear that the outcomes which are being delivered by the present policy need to be changed in the face of that growing unease, disquiet and opposition.

It is because of the outcome of the present policy that the FitzGerald Committee was so trenchant in its criticism. I should say that it was less trenchant in its final forms of criticism than when the report was originally drafted and before it was revised at the request of the Prime Minister, just as Senator Ray's original statement has been revised at the same request. In that sense, history is repeating itself.

Immigration is an issue which, as the Minister has truly said in his statement, `touches the lives of every Australian whether born here or not'. I say amen to that. As the Minister has also said, the central message of the FitzGerald report, namely, that immigration should be for all Australians, has received wide support-and so it should. That is the very theme of the Opposition's one Australia approach to the whole question that we have been expounding over recent months. I also agree with the Minister when he says that we seek `to ensure that those born in Australia and those who migrate to Australia are equally accorded their rights'; that is, the same rights as citizens or potential citizens, once having been granted permanent residence, of one Australia.

While I do not wish this afternoon to strike an unduly partisan note on this matter, I say to the Minister that nothing has been more shameful over recent months than the actions of Ministers, from the Prime Minister down, in seeking to suggest, imply, or even overtly assert, that the Opposition's view of these matters would in some way adversely affect the rights and freedoms of our fellow Australians already resident in this country, most notably in our various ethnic communities. As Senator Puplick has said it is the Labor Party that has politicised this issue-not the Opposition.

The Minister is in error when he seeks to suggest-I think it is fair to add that he does not anywhere expressly say it-that the Government's multicultural spending programs are `quite separate from immigration policy as such'. While I have no intention-time not permitting-to debate the matter further this afternoon, the truth is that, as the FitzGerald Committee clearly found, those very multicultural expenditure programs have done as much as anything to raise antagonisms within the Australian community to immigration as a whole. Because of that they are putting in jeopardy the very maintenance of that policy on immigration to which I and every other senator on this side of the chamber-indeed, I would say, in the chamber as a whole-subscribe and which is fundamental to Australia's long term future.

Senator Puplick dealt cogently with that portion of the Minister's remarks which sought to blame the Opposition for what Senator Ray alleged to be feelings of disquiet in Asia arising out of the earlier public debate on these matters. I regard those remarks by the Minister as totally hypocritical when our Prime Minister, and particularly our pathetic Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), have been projecting themselves around Asia in a manner which could hardly be more calculated to distort the debate and to poison the wells of understanding on these matters.
Let me note also the Minister's tongue-in-cheek remarks about bipartisanship in this area of policy. I quote him:
In that context I now state that this Government believes that a return to a bipartisan policy is in the interests of all Australians.
I would agree with that. He goes on to say:

I take this opportunity to go on the record and say to the Opposition that should you accept the invitation I now extend to you to return to a bipartisan, non-discriminatory policy, the Government, for its part, will applaud and in no way seek to take political advantage of the fact that you have done so.

As I said, I regard those phrases by the Minister as utterly tongue-in-cheek. As I said by way of interpolation in quoting the Minister, I think it is important to obtain, if reasonably possible, a degree of bipartisanship in this area. It is a great and vital matter of national public importance that we are discussing this afternoon. But it takes two to tango. The Opposition has no intention at all of dancing to the tunes which successive Labor Party Ministers for immigration have been playing in this area over the past 5 1/2 years and against which an overwhelming majority of Australians is so vigorously reacting.

I remind the Minister of what I said some months ago on this aspect when I spoke in this place on the Government's urgency motion on immigration. I said then, and I repeat, that we shall have bipartisanship again in this area of policy. Let there be no doubt or disquiet about that. We shall have it when the Government, gradually no doubt, moves to pick up our policies in this, as in so many other areas. I say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we shall welcome that return to bipartisanship by the Government when it makes, gradually, the move to attain it.

I mention briefly only one other point. I refer to the Bureau of Immigration Research which the Government proposes to establish at an initial cost of some $4m a year and which will employ over 40 people. Yet, so far as one can see, this Bureau will not principally be a Bureau of Immigration Research, which its name would imply, so much as a bureau which will, as is said, commission research by others. Will it be research that is commissioned or will it be propaganda? Will it be public relations documents that are commissioned by this body? Will we see in this body another body akin to the National Media Liaison Service-the `animals'; the NMLS? Is that the body which is going to be set up by this Government with a view, as the Government would say, to promoting a better understanding of these matters within the Australian community-a better understanding or, what is sometimes known as brainwashing or social engineering?

Mr Acting Deputy President, I say to the Minister, through you, that the Opposition will be paying very great attention to the establishment of this body. We will be examining very closely, including through the relevant Estimates committee of this Senate, its activities and how in fact it spends the significant funds which the Government apparently proposes to accord it. Throughout all this our emphasis is, and will continue to be, on the one Australia to which the Minister says he too adheres-although, I think it is fair to say, he does not use that term. It is all the more a pity that, as the shadow Minister for immigration, Mr Cadman, MHR, said at a press conference earlier today:
in-fighting within the Government has produced a policy which is almost identical with the existing policy . . .
As Senator Teague said at the conclusion of his remarks, it does appear that the only way in practice in which we are going to change that situation is by changing this failed Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I will try to keep my remarks brief because of the lengthy business list of the Senate. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for the statement he made on behalf of the Government in its response to the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policy. The statement is detailed and covers a wide range of areas. It indicates-and I suggest that people read it and the FitzGerald report carefully-that there is an overwhelming acceptance by the Government of the recommendations of the FitzGerald Committee.
