SPEECH.PARA: I found it interesting to hear Senator Puplick and Senator Teague in particular comment earlier in the debate that the FitzGerald Committee recommendations have been overwhelmingly rejected by the Government. Unfortunately, some headlines appeared in the press today, before the report was released, that FitzGerald has been overwhelmingly rejected. I just want to quote to the Senate from a press release issued today by Dr FitzGerald which is headed `Dr FitzGerald Welcomes Cabinet Decision'. Amongst other things, he says:

Cabinet has adopted a set of policies which is both profoundly reformist and yet also reflects a harmony of compassionate, social and economic objectives. In a climate of emotional debate and against intense pressure to favour one special interest or another, this is an impressive achievement.

This statement issued by Dr Stephen FitzGerald on 8 December 1988 completely refutes remarks made earlier in the debate by Opposition spokespeople that the Government has rejected the FitzGerald recommendations in a major way. I will return later to Dr FitzGerald's comments on specific matters about which Opposition members have spoken.

I think the Australian people generally, and particularly those interested in the specifics of Australia's immigration policy, could do nothing but deplore the attitude of the Federal Opposition in this debate over the last six or seven months since the FitzGerald recommendations were released. We had the extraordinary performance here today of Senator Stone speaking supposedly on behalf of the Opposition, yet he is no longer on the front bench of the Opposition because his remarks could not be tolerated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). He is still Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate and speaks with that authority. But he is not a member of the front bench of the Opposition because his attitudes about immigration turned out to be contrary to what a number of other members of the Opposition stated. It is confusing because I cannot really see that there is much difference between what Senator Stone said and what John Howard said on a number of occasions in press interviews.

At least John Stone should be given the credit for belling the cat honestly about what the Opposition is really about on immigration. In a public interview earlier this year he said, `Let us not beat about the bush. The Opposition's statements and policies are about reducing Asian immigration'-full stop. When he said that there was a conflagration in the Opposition parties. Senator Baden Teague, who spoke earlier, went public condemning those remarks. A number of other Liberal senators went public condemning those remarks. In the end, even though John Howard was saying between the lines the same things, he was forced to sack Senator Stone. He could not sack him as Leader of the National Party in the Senate; he could only sack him from the front bench. We saw a rather bizarre reshuffling of the seating arrangements on the Opposition side. Senator Stone, who was sitting next to Senator Austin Lewis, went over to the second XI or, I suppose, to the sin bin at the back of the Senate. He is now sitting in a position near the Australian Democrats, who, I must say, I do not find most of Senator Stone's policies and views comfortable with anything that they stand for.

I must say that in this whole debate on matters of considerable obvious public sensitivity about immigration, the Opposition's performance over several months has been disgraceful. It has done the Opposition no good and it has affected Australia's relations overseas. It was once said that the famous first shot at Concord in the American War of Independence was heard around the world. I say that Senator Stone's remarks about reducing Asian immigration were certainly heard all through Asia and that they had a dreadful impact on our relations with Asian countries. No other remarks by an Australian politician have done Australia's reputation overseas so much damage than the remarks made by Senator Stone and Mr Howard. They deserve to be condemned for them.

The Minister's statement contains a number of highlights which I think everybody in Australia will welcome. First of all, the Minister referred to the establishment of a Bureau of Immigration Research. Senator Stone says that this is going to be the equivalent of a propaganda exercise like the National Media Liaison Service. Nothing could be further from the truth. He talks about conducting research. He asks, `What sort of research?' Obviously, in Australia's immigration and population policies consistent research will have to be conducted and commissioned by the Bureau from experts-I would suspect not only from this country but also from overseas. Not since the seminal report of the Borrie National Population Inquiry in the early 1970s have we had an opportunity in Australia to make decisions about what sort of population this country should have in the twenty-first century. There has been a range of projections from 20 million to 35 million over the next 40 or 50 years. These are fundamental issues which this country is going to have to face up to during the 1990s. The decisions we make on immigration will affect the population numbers in this country next century.

I hope that the Bureau of Immigration Research will deal specifically with ongoing research into the population numbers that this country should have and the impact that various population numbers will have on the economy and social structure of this country. That is what the Bureau of Immigration Research will have to deal with. I will be the first to join Senator Stone in condemning it if it does nothing else but send out a few press releases. But certainly it has to have the resources to publicise its research and findings as part of an informed public debate. I know that members of the Opposition do not want an informed public debate on immigration because they are appealing to base prejudice in much of the immigration policy they are putting forward to the Australian people.

The next point I wish to mention about Senator Ray's statement is something that has not been noted widely but I think it is something that Australians-Liberal, Labor, Australian Democrats or National Party-can be very proud of. In the last 40 years Australia has taken over 470,000 refugees into Australia. Since 1975 it has taken 175,000. Four hundred and seventy thousand people in 40 years is almost the population of Tasmania. It is a commendable achievement that Australia has met its obligations in the international arena in taking such a large number of refugees. Few other countries have had the courage to do so and in particular in the last 12 years in relation to Indo-Chinese refugees. It was not the Australian Labor Party's policy to intervene in the Vietnam War and prolong it and the misery that went with it. But as a consequence of that war large numbers of people were displaced and Australia accepted its responsibility, firstly under the Fraser Government and then under the Hawke Government, to accept refugees from Indo-China. If we had not done that it would have been one of the more immoral acts in our history. Despite the fact that some people in our community, aided and abetted by the Senator Stones of the world, are trying to campaign on a racial basis against immigrants from Indo-China, we ought to be very proud of the fact that we are one of the few countries that takes refugees on a humanitarian basis in such large numbers.

A further point in Senator Ray's remarks is the new system of appeals. I have been in the Senate only some 16 or 17 months. As a senator I do not get the same constituency work that most members of the House of Representatives get with a specific electorate. But I have to say that the largest amount of constituency work I get, probably like most other senators, is from people wanting to appeal to change decisions not to allow people, relatives and so on, to immigrate to Australia. They know that despite the Department rejecting people's applications to immigrate because they do not have the required number of points, and despite the fact that they may appeal to the appropriate tribunals in each of the States and be rejected further, they can still come to a politician to try to get the decision overturned by ministerial discretion. I suppose there is not a member of this Parliament who has been here for a couple of years who has not, on a number of occasions, gone directly to the Minister, whether Labor or Liberal, to get special consideration for someone to be admitted to the country despite being previously rejected.

Senator Robert Ray and the Government have proposed that that discretion by the Minister be removed. I think that is an excellent step because for every one who gets in under ministerial discretion, I suspect several thousand others do not get in who should be let in under the same criteria. Therefore, injustices are continually perpetrated against many thousands of people because a few are able to get the Minister to change the decision of the appeals tribunal or of the Department. The Minister will still hold some discretion but when the Minister uses it the information will be tabled in the Parliament so that people will be able to see that the Minister is being consistent and the special reasons why he has used his discretion. I also note in the statement that a much more rigorous set of guidelines will be laid down for the appeal procedures within the Department. That is excellent.

We have heard comments today by Senator Teague and Senator Puplick regarding the numbers and the various categories under the immigration program. We have heard that this is where the recommendations of the FitzGerald Inquiry have been totally rejected by the Government. Outlandish remarks have been made that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Ray have been rolled by the so-called Left and so on. I will quote to the Senate another aspect of what Dr Stephen FitzGerald said today publicly in a press release, which I have referred to already. The press release stated:

Referring to Cabinet's decisions on family migration and skill migration, Dr FitzGerald said that what mattered was not how one described the categories but the outcomes, and the mechanisms for producing them. ``Apart from Immediate Family, where the numbers decided by Cabinet are very close to those recommended by the Committee,'' he said, ``Cabinet has accepted the recommendation which is fundamental to selecting the young, the skilled and the entrepreneurial-the best immigrants-which is the recommendation for adoption of a principle of highest scores only or first past the post (the ``floating pass mark'')''.
``With the decision to give most points to employability factors, for both ``economic'' applicants and Extended Family applicants, the actual outcomes will be as the Committee recommended,'' he said.

I trust that further Opposition speakers in the debate will take note of what Doctor Stephen FitzGerald has said and will no longer try to put to the Senate this stereotyped view, this lie in fact, that the FitzGerald Committee of Inquiry has had its major recommendations rejected by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has had some of its major recommendations rejected.
—Dr FitzGerald in his statement makes it quite clear. To give Senator Michael Baume further information on what Dr FitzGerald said in the press release, I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Commenting on the point that the bulk of the Committee's recommendations (some 80%) had in fact been accepted by Cabinet in total or with some refinement, elaboration, or extension, Dr FitzGerald said the 73 recommendations could not have been truly effective if taken piecemeal.

That quote again makes it quite clear that Dr FitzGerald sees that the decisions of the Government in the ministerial statement laid down today by the Minister have been carried out. I trust that if Senator Baume speaks in this debate he will acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the major ones have been rejected and you know it.
—Seeing as Senator Baume consistently interjects, I seek leave of the Senate to have the press release tabled so that he can read it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A further point I wish to make regarding one of the recommendations and comments in both the ministerial report and in the FitzGerald report is on the question of Australian citizenship. The Government rejected the FitzGerald Committee recommendation that if people do not take out Australian citizenship there should be some financial penalties regarding eligibility for pensions and so on. The Government has rejected that. I do not think anybody, even those in Opposition, would cavil at that decision. If they want to have a coercive immigration policy, if they want to go around to ethnic communities saying to people, `We are going to coerce you to be an Australian citizen', I would love to see them try. That would be an attitude more equivalent to an eastern European country than to a democracy such as Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the questions dealt with by the FitzGerald Committee concerning the million people in Australia who are eligible for citizenship but who have not taken it out is the question concerning the oath of allegiance. I note that the FitzGerald Committee recommends a new form of declaration of citizenship which it says would be more meaningful. It says that the possible citizenship declaration could be as follows:
I undertake to respect the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
I will endeavour to inform myself about the principles upon which these laws, and related institutions, are based.

I undertake to accept and respect the institutions and principles of Australian society, including parliamentary democracy, the rule of law and equality before the law, freedom of the individual, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, freedom of religion, equality of women, universal education.

I undertake to accept and respect the principle of non-discrimination on grounds of race, colour, descent and national or ethnic origin which informs the laws and institutions of Australian society and the immigration policy of Australia and under which I have taken up residence in Australia and thereby become entitled to Australian citizenship.

I think that is a matter for further discussion. Certainly, the Government's response in the document is to accept it as a concept and as one for further development. Why I have raised this matter and why I am interested in raising it is because I believe one of the reasons we do not have more immigrants to Australia taking out citizenship is that many find it unnecessary that they should swear an oath of allegiance or an affirmation of allegiance which at present asks them to swear that they will bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, the Queen of Australia. Many immigrants come from countries with republican constitutions and cannot understand why they should swear allegiance to a Queen of Australia who basically resides 12,000 miles or 25,000 kilometres from Australia. The FitzGerald recommendations are an excellent way of overcoming some of the apprehensions migrants have when taking out Australian citizenship. In this debate I do not want to express my own views as a support for Australia becoming a republic in the near future. But I do believe that the recommendations made by the FitzGerald Committee on a new form of citizenship declaration is the way we should be proceeding.

The final area I wish to comment on relating specifically to the report is the question of multiculturalism. The Minister in his statement said that the FitzGerald report was not dealing specifically with the issue of multiculturalism but that it has become part of the debate. Unfortunately, part of that debate has been fanned by some of the unfortunate remarks of Opposition speakers such as Senator Stone. I would like to put on the record the excellent statement of what multiculturalism stands for as stated in the Minister's statement:

. . . we are already, in a descriptive sense, a multicultural nation. Multiculturalism is premised on an overriding and unifying commitment to Australia. It embraces basic issues of individual expression, social justice and economic efficiency. We need multicultural policies precisely in order to ensure that insecurity, disharmony, injustice and inefficiency do not disfigure our society.

I believe that that succinct description of multiculturalism is one that should be publicised widely within Australia. It will go a long way to overcoming some of the prejudiced views put forward by the Opposition. Australia is one of the very few countries in the history of the world that have been able to organise and run a successfully planned immigration policy for over 40 years. Several million people have come to this country under the planning that began in the 1940s. It has made Australia a much better country, a stronger country and a more diverse country. But above all, for people such as me, a fourth generation Australian, it has enabled Australians to start to develop and evolve an identity that is uniquely Australian. I do not consider myself a European; I consider myself an Australian. Australia is part of the Pacific Basin. We have that role to play in the world. We are not specifically part of Asia; we are part of the south-west Pacific. Our future lies in relations with Asian countries. I believe that the immigration program that has been so successful in this country and has had bipartisan support up until three months ago has been a great bipartisan support up until three months ago has been a great credit to this country. Although we have had people from over 140 countries come to this country over the last 200 years-and particularly the last 40 years-I think this country has been very successful in enabling those people to become Australians and to participate in the Australian community.

I suppose the analogy I would like to conclude with relates to how people have been successful in the past. People have often said that sporting achievements in Australia are a sign of success. In the last 40 years in sport we have seen southern Europeans, with names such as Barassi and so on, participating in the great Australian sport, Australian rules football. In the next 10 or 15 years I look forward to seeing a Test match at the Melbourne Cricket Ground starting on Boxing Day against the West Indies with the Australian batting side being opened by Nguyen van Thien, the son of a Vietnamese refugee who has come to this country, being applauded when he hits the runs to make his maiden century. I know that all Australians will applaud him as an Australian from a different background. Many of the rest of us will be applauding him as an Australian. That is part of the ongoing multicultural aspect of Australia's immigration program. It is one in which we should all be proud because it has been extremely successful. I used that analogy not as the only one because there are many others. In the years to come people from all different nationalities will play a part in ensuring that in the next century Australia stands for something distinctive, important and successful in the world. I commend the Minister for his statement to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief with my remarks. Before I start I wish to say that I am glad to see Senator McMullan has returned to the chamber because I did not think he had the intestinal fortitude, after the accusations he made earlier about what I was supposed to have said in Esperance, to come back into the chamber when I spoke. Perhaps I will give him the benefit of the doubt and not say that he called me a liar. In September in this chamber I made a personal explanation and denied the remarks that were reported by the one-sided media we have in this country about what I was supposed to have said in Esperance. Fortunately, from a remark made by Senator McKiernan some time ago, I was able to trace the source of where I was supposed to have made those remarks. I have a typewritten sheet of the audio tape of exactly what I did say in that motion in Esperance, along with a twisted press release put out by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Perth on 31 July. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
1988 State Conference-Motion No. 19
Tangney Division-Bullcreek/Bateman Branch

That the Liberal Party on return to Government replaces policies designed to foster and encourage cultural separatism with policies that assist in the rapid assimilation and integration of migrants into the Australian culture.
Speaker for the motion:
Sen. John Panizza:

Thank you Mr. Chairman, I was hoping to speak on a previous motion but this is a very similar motion so I'll speak on this one. What I would like to point out Mr. Chairman, that migration to Australia has got strongly out of balance. It seems to me and I am sure that it is, we are getting too many from one part of the world and the reason we are doing that is because this Government is being too lazy to try and attract migration from our traditional sources that we used to get them before. I am not going to say that there is too many Asians in Australia, I'm saying that we are not getting any from Europe and Southern Europe and places like that that helped build Australia up before. Mr. Chairman, Australia has got to know where it is going. I know you may call it social engineering but we want to know what sort of Australia we are going to have in ten years time and if we want to do that well we have got to look at our sources of migration right now. And another thing what Australia does need is a balanced migration to get people in that fit into the workforce that we have already or already have not got. For an example, especially the ones out here in outer areas, we've got unemployment in the cities, in fact Australia's unemployment is about 7.2% and yet there is a lot of places in the Goldfields and the Agricultural areas that cannot be filled and the traditional migrants from Europe used to fill those jobs in years gone by. I'll just give you a few figures Mr. Chairman out of the Fitzgerald Report into Migration and it makes your hair stand on end. As I said it is an enditement of this Government that we've got 7.2% unemployment, but when you look at the breakdown figures you've got overseas born in the unemployment, ranks at 8.4%, but when you break that down further, those from the United Kingdom and Ireland are 6.8%, the Italians are 3.2%, the Greek 5.6% and yet those from Vietnam is 30.5% which was at this time last year and now has risen to 42% and you've got those from Lebanon at 28.3%. In other words we are getting too many migrants that are not employable or choose to go on the unemployment list. And my final point, Mr Chairman, is that the commitment by all migrants should be that we have one Australia. We can tolerate multi-culturalism but that is something we can tolerate. We encourage it but above all there must be one Australia Mr. Chairman and that's the number one undertaking that migrants have got to do before they are admitted to Australia.
Thank you.
West Australian Liberal Senator, John Panizza, claims the majority of Asian migrants living in Australia are unemployable.
Senator Panizza told the Liberal State conference in Esperance that the FitzGerald report pointed to the need for a more balanced immigration policy.
He said eight point four percent of the nation's unemployed were migrants, and of that amount, more than 30 percent were Vietnamese.
State conference supported a resolution to limit the intake of refugees and other migrants in the humanitarian category to a maximum of 20 percent of Australia's total migrant intake.
Another more controversial resolution-to restrict Australia's migrant intake to people of European origin-was deferred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will wait until Senator McMullan reads today's Hansard to see whether he wants to call me a liar. Aside from all of that, this twisted press release has branded me as a migrant basher. I was vilified in Asia and in the Australian press. Let me tell honourable senators that, as one belonging to a migrant family, I have seen more discrimination than anyone else in this place. I have experienced as much discriminationb as any discriminated or disadvantaged group in Australia. I have seen discrimination in schools, in employment and in social life. Let no-one in this place call me a migrant basher.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall now comment on the report. Before it is suggested that our migration policy is discriminatory-of course, members of this Government claim theirs is not-let me stress that remarks made by my colleagues have been beaten up by the media and carried on by others such as Dr Theophanous, who was in Melbourne when I addressed a migrant group. He was also invited and he kicked up a fuss because the Italian community there had the audacity to invite a Liberal. He thinks that the Labor Party has a monopoly on interest in migrant groups.

I simply want to make a couple of points on naturalisation, labour skills, and business migration as they relate to the Government's response. The report correctly identified citizenship as the ultimate commitment to Australia. I am disappointed and dismayed that the Government has failed to take up this point. I do not believe that non-citizens should be denied any basic benefits and social security, especially if they have worked in Australia, or the right to work or to enjoy normal life. Of course, this was not the case with pre-1950 migration. I believe that one should hold Australian citizenship before one has the right to nominate to sponsor other migrants, other than one's spouse and dependent children.

I now turn to skills. I believe that the Government is not doing enough to attract migrants whose skills are presently in demand in Australia. The categories I know which come to mind are building construction employees, medical and paramedical personnel for remote areas, and mining personnel. At present there are vacancies in Australia for at least 4,000 bricklayers. Bricklayers are not ever defined as tradesmen by the migration authorities. The dream of owning one's own home or even living in a decent rented home will remain a dream, despite the present building boom.

Senator McMullan pointed out that the Australian Council of Trade Unions had something to say about skilled migrants. It believes the emphasis should be on teaching Australians who are here at present rather than bringing in people who already have skills. That may be so, but by the time Australians are trained the boom will be over. The boom is on now and there is a demand for bricklayers and other workers now rather than in five or six years time, when people will be trained in these skills. Australia is probably one of the best equipped countries in the world for education, whether professional, semi-professional, or skilled and semi-skilled trades. There are no better opportunities in any other country in the world. If Australians are not taking up the opportunities to become skilled, I believe we should admit people who are willing to come here and work in projects in remote areas where they are most needed. I am afraid that Australia has bred many people who would rather be handed a snake than a shovel.

There is a shortage of nurses not only in remote areas but Australia wide, and there is a shortage of doctors, but mainly in remote areas. There are South African doctors willing to come to Australia and work in those remote areas but they are not admitted. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will take their applications but that is as far as it goes. The applications simply pile up and the remote areas do not get these doctors, who are well qualified to work and are willing to come to Australia but are not admitted. Their only crime is that they are white, come from South Africa and have been educated at the University of Cape Town-where incidentally Dr Christian Barnard, who was the first person in the world to perform a heart transplant, was educated. The remote areas remain devoid of doctors while this Government carries on its prejudice against certain people wanting to migrate to Australia.

I said I would be brief. I turn now to the skilled mining personnel. Not enough of these people can be found in Australia and, once again, the skills criteria and trade union prejudice will prevent them from coming here. Worse still, as the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, would know, not only do we not have enough skilled personnel but also countries such as Canada and probably South America are taking the ones we do have. So the need to bring in others to replace those who have gone to other parts of the world is becoming greater every day. The Minister mentioned a tripartite agreement with the unions. I fear for the future because, as Senator McMullan pointed out, that is how the Government will attempt to fix the skills problem. We may teach many Australians the necessary skills but, as I have already said, we will not get them out into the remote areas.

Turning to business migration, I totally agree with the view in the report that we need to encourage business migration because of the benefits that flow to Australia. I would like to see a monitoring system put into action to ensure that those business migrants are dinkum. Temporary status could be given to such people for two years or so to allow them to prove that a business can be established and to check that the money is not remitted overseas to bring in another family. In this case I know what I am talking about because I have spoken to a bank manager in Perth. This is going on. People come in with half a million dollars. They get a passport; they return to their country of origin to carry on a business, the half million dollars is given to another family to come in, that half million dollars goes out again and so it goes on. The same half million dollars gets circulated time and time again. There are some genuine immigrants who set up businesses and family homes and who intend to remain here, but there are many who do not. It is time the Government took that into consideration.

The Government has not taken up enough of the recommendations of the FitzGerald report, despite Senator Schacht's claim. It has not taken them up because of pressures from certain minority migrant groups. It is a case of the tail wagging the dog. We should be master of our own destiny.

I appreciate what migrants have done for Australia and what Australia has done for migrants. Many migrants, especially people who arrived before 1950, have been discriminated against. They did not make too many noises about that, although I know there were riots in Kalgoorlie in 1934 and in other places. In the final analysis the migrants provide their worth to Australia and they made their contribution. And as I belong to a migrant family, I can record my appreciation of what Australia has done for migrants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Government's response to the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which was submitted to the Government some time in May. It was tabled in the House of Representatives on 3 June. It was open to pubic debate for a stated period of three months. It was subjected to workshops, public meetings and consultations between various and varied committees and groups and between lobbyists and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). It was tabled in the Senate in August and now, on 8 December, the Government has given its formal response. The Australian Democrats believe that it was proper and correct for the Government to deliberate at length on its response because it is a very important report and it is a very important issue. It is obvious from the tenor of the Government's response that it has looked at the report and has listened to the representations from various concerned community groups and individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: The FitzGerald report did not address the issues that the Government expected it to address. The Government expected that the FitzGerald Committee would change the points system so that the blow-outs which had been occurring over the last few years in immigration numbers would cease. Everyone who had the 70 points was eligible to migrate to Australia, and this was causing a blow-out in the projected numbers. In fact, the report did not address this matter specifically. This, no doubt, is why the Government raised the number of points necessary for a person to enter Australia from 70 to either 75 or 80. It did this without warning last June. This change was not debated in the Parliament; it was not required to be debated. It was made quietly and it has caused much concern to many people. It has been criticised because people who had already applied for migration and who believed they would attain the 70 points found, without warning, that they could not. I commend the Minister for stating in his speech that any changes from now on will be demonstrably open, consistent and equitable; that no more decisions will be made behind closed doors.

When tabling the Government's response the Minister said that immigration was an issue which touched the lives of every Australian, whether born here or not. That is absolutely true. The Refugee and Migrant Services group from the Australian Council of Churches, in response to the FitzGerald report, said:

. . . the lasting impression of the Report is that it has added fuel to those elements in Australian society which have opposed immigration, particularly of non-English-speaking background immigrants, and have predicted dire consequences for multicultural policy. If all of the recommendations in the FitzGerald report were to be accepted then we would have produced a meaner spirited, less fair and divisive nation. The costs in terms of community relations would be unacceptable.

That is an indictment of the basic tenor of the report. The Australian Democrats believe that that criticism is justified. On the whole, the Democrats are pleased about the way in which the Government has dealt with some of the controversial aspects of the report. I will talk initially on multiculturalism. Dr Stephen FitzGerald showed confusion and misapprehension of the whole concept of multiculturalism despite submissions which were made to the Committee. It was his confusion which led to the unfortunate public statements which were made on immigrants from Asia by parliamentary members of the Opposition. Then, of course, the debate was taken up in the community. We heard a debate which I never thought we would hear in this country in this day and age. I did not believe that we would ever be debating the possibility of discriminating against people on the basis of their racial origin.

I was very pleased to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say at the annual conference of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia that the Government is totally committed to multiculturalism. That has been emphasised again in the Minister's response to the report. I was also pleased to note that the recommendation in the FitzGerald report that the number of refugees from Indo-China should be scaled down was also quite correctly dismissed by the Government.

The Australian Democrats were also pleased to see that the FitzGerald recommendation in relation to discrimination against people who had not thought or chosen to take up citizenship has been rejected. I think the Government is taking the right path in encouraging people to take up citizenship and in proclaiming the advantages of citizenship commitment to Australia.

In the main the Government's response to the report is responsible and the Democrats are in broad agreement with many of the Government's responses to the recommendations. We are in disagreement with some. Because of the lack of time and opportunity to analyse all of the responses in detail-we are not sure of the full implications of some of them-we may have to respond to some at a later time. The Government has not complied with some of the recommendations which are based on a very dry economic rationalism which would treat prospective migrants as mere economic units. In a paper delivered to the FECCA Conference last week, Walter Lippman said that the FitzGerald recommendations `clearly denigrated important social factors including motivation for immigration'. He went on to quote Peter Robinson in the Sydney Morning Herald, who he said put it bluntly. Peter Robinson said:

If we regard immigrants as economic objects to be exploited for their money we will get economic objects who will exploit us. If we see the newcomers as valuable additions to the human wealth and cultural depth of our society, that is the kind of invaluable immigrants we may have some chance of attracting.

The Minister has also acknowledged that in the past there have been many irrational areas in immigration, that many decisions have been made behind closed doors without regard to the Parliament. Now they will be open; they will either have to be legislated for, or they depend on regulations which can be openly tabled; or the Minister will at least have to table his reasons for making decisions.

The Government has rejected one of the basic recommendations of the FitzGerald Committee, which was to divide immigrants into three categories-A, B and C. FitzGerald recommended that category A, family immigration, should remain self-determining but was likely to increase to about 40,000; that category B, refugee/humanitarian, should increase to 15,000 people; and that category C, the open category, should form the balance of around 95,000 migrants. The Government's recommendation is that those categories should be changed to a family migration intake, which would consist of immediate family of some 41,000. This would be demand driven; that is, it would be hard to put a ceiling on these numbers because the demand would come from the families in Australia. It recommends a further extended family category of some 30,000, which would be residual, to take up the remainder of the 71,000 to be allowed in under that category.

The Government's second recommendation concerns the economic migration area. Senator Panizza has already talked about the business migration program, as I have done at length in the past. I am very pleased to see that the Government will take up the FitzGerald recommendation that there should be auditing and monitoring of what happens to the money that is brought in by business migrants. Some come in as genuine business migrants, invest correctly and set up businesses, but there is no doubt-and this has been raised publicly before-that a number do not.

The other aspects of economic migration, with a total of 54,000 potential migrants, depend partially on the points test. The Government has recommended changes in the points test. It is advocating a floating total of points which can be changed as the numbers of migrants ebb and flow. This could be very difficult to administer. It needs to be looked at in further detail before pronouncements can be made. Further details need to be known about exactly how it is to work. Where there is a floating total of points we will have a queue of migrants, some of whom are not going to be sure whether or not they will get here. Even though, as the Minister has explained, they can re-enter the queue twice, this may not be a satisfactory solution.

The Government is recommending in the area of humanitarian migration that 12,500 refugees should be admitted with a contingency reserve of 1,500. A number of people, groups and community organisations that have looked at the issue of refugee migration have suggested that the number should be increased. The Democrats would certainly go along with this suggestion. Australia can afford to increase the number of refugees to the suggested target put forward by the Australian Council of Churches of 20,000. We cannot foresee what tragedies or events will take place in the world, but provision should be made within our migration scheme to play our part in taking in refugees. Other countries do it; Australia can do it too.

Another area which was looked at by the FitzGerald Committee and by the Government is the area of review. The Government has suggested a two-tier review, which certainly would be fairer than the present system. On the Government's projected two-tier review system, first reviews would be undertaken by an independent section within the Department. That would mean that if people's applications had been rejected by simple error this would be picked up immediately. If they then chose to appeal against this, they would go before the immigration review panels. The immigration review panels as they stand are not satisfactory. I spoke up against this in the debate on the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 when a fee of $240 was brought in. We found that migrants were paying a fee for a review system which was not a true review system at all. The Minister has suggested that the immigration review panels should be overhauled and that the credentials, qualifications and suitability of the members who sit on them should be looked at closely. The Democrats look forward to learning more about how the Government proposes to proceed in that area.

As far as overseas qualifications are concerned, this area has been problematical all the way along the line. There have been improvements, but there is a lot of room for further improvement in this area. Very often prospective migrants are not given correct information. They are assured that their trade and professional qualifications will be recognised and that they will find work here. They come to Australia and find that this is not the case. Others find that the process required to have their qualifications recognised is very lengthy, very protracted, very difficult and often very costly; or they find that they have to undergo further training which they had not expected to do. Many people who expect to find work in skilled and professional areas find themselves instead without work or having to accept work for which they are not suited.

The Government has suggested that there should be a Bureau of Immigration Research. A lot of decisions-and this may explain why there is a lot of confusion in the community about immigration-are made without any detailed government research having been undertaken into our immigration policies, how those policies evolve and what the outcomes are. I think it would be a step in the right direction if we became aware of what we were doing. We need to look at the total number of migrants, what happens to them and whether, as is said by the Government and the Opposition, migrants do create a higher standard of living and will continue to do so in the future. A number of concerns have been expressed by environmental groups and others that there is a limit to the numbers that this country can take. It is a big country, but there are relatively small areas where people can live with a reasonably high standard of living, to which we are now accustomed. With the soil degradation that we have engendered and the lack of plentiful water supplies, this question does need to be looked at.

We should also be looking at whether we should be bringing in migrants in a category of skills when there is an unacceptable level of unemployment. A recommendation has been made by the FitzGerald Committee, which the Government has accepted, that, in addition to importing migrants on a skills basis, we should be looking to education, training and retraining. The Democrats are not satisfied that enough is being done in that direction. All too often, government panders to business and industry which want skilled people here and now and are not prepared to play their part in the training of workers.

The Minister has said that decision making within his Department will be made by the Secretary to the Department. It is stated in one of the releases put out by the Minister that in future the Secretary to the Department will be the principal decision maker in immigration cases. The Australian Democrats are not very happy about that. We believe it is the Minister's role to be responsible for decisions and to be involved in decision making. We are pleased to see that the Minister will still retain discretion. However many rules we have, wherever we go with the points system ultimately, there will always be cases that fall outside the system and cannot be categorised so easily.

The Democrats disagree with the Government's response to recommendations 17 and 71. In recommendation 17, FitzGerald recommends legislation to ensure equal employment opportunities for migrants. We certainly endorse that; the Government does not. We also endorse FitzGerald's recommendations that fees should be waived in cases of extreme hardship. I was very disappointed to see that the Government did not endorse that recommendation either.

Let us look briefly at the fees that migrants have to pay. They are very high. On application for processing, a prospective migrant has to pay $200. Of course, the process may finish right there. If the applicant wants to apply for reconsideration of a Migration Act decision through the Immigration Review Panel, that costs another $240. An application for change of status to permanent resident costs $315. An application for a further temporary entry permit costs $50 and an application for an entry permit giving permission to engage in employment in Australia costs a further $60. Other fees that can be charged include those relating to sponsorship for entry to Australia for temporary residents, application for a resident return visa, application for a declaratory certificate of Australian citizenship, application for the registration of Australian citizenship by descent, application for the grant of Australian citizenship, application for an evidentiary certificate of Australian citizenship and application for resumption of Australian citizenship. That seems to be quite a money making area for the Government. I am not convinced that all those--

TALK.START.PARA: —It covers 46 per cent of costs. It is not compulsory to come here.

—Well, it is a lot for people without the proper means to pay. Very often, applicants are people who need work but cannot work for various reasons because they are in the process of migrating. That does seem very heavy going.

SPEECH.PARA: I have limited my remarks to the Government's response to the FitzGerald report as such. The Minister also tabled his report on deportations. I have had a quick look at it and it does seem to be a step in the right direction, but it needs to be looked at in further detail. It is quite a weighty document.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats wish to reaffirm their commitment to a non-discriminatory immigration policy. We refuse to regard people as mere economic units. We believe it is a gross error of judgment to deliberately import migrants on a skills basis while we have an unacceptable level of unemployment. We believe that, in order to encourage cohesion in our society, it is correct that a high emphasis should be placed on humanitarian and family categories of immigration. With all that has been said about the family by the Government and especially by the Opposition in recent days, I believe they would fall in with that. We cannot support any increase in the total immigration numbers because of unemployment and because of our need in Australia for sustainable economic and environmental policies.

There are details in the Minister's response which need further detailed consideration. The Australian Democrats reaffirm that we consider Australia to be one multicultural Australia, which is an example to the world of democratic pluralism in action.
Debate (on motion by Senator Walsh) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill 1988, which sets up the framework to sell off 30 per cent of a newly created subsidiary of the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) to the public. I have an amendment to the motion that this Bill be now read a second time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should sell the Australian Industry Development Corporation in its entirety to the private sector as soon as possible in view of:
(a) the fact that the Corporation operates as a commercial enterprise and furthermore that there is no essential public interest reason for maintaining Federal Government ownership; and

(b) the extremely poor record of government involvement in investment ventures as illustrated by the current financial crises enveloping the Victorian Economic Development Corporation and Rothwells merchant bank''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AIDC has a bit better record than those two.

—The Minister for Finance has interjected that the AIDC has a rather better record than those two bodies, and I agree with the Minister. Certainly, it is not an implication of the amendment that the AIDC has the sorry record of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation or the Western Australian State Government's general intervention in private enterprise matters which will cost the taxpayers of Western Australia very dearly indeed. The taxpayers of both Victoria and Western Australia have reason to regret that their governments have tried to become entrepreneurial and that will ultimately be at considerable cost to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose one should really be celebratory in speaking to this Bill. It is not really appropriate to quote the New Testament in debate in this place but it does say something about there being more joy in heaven and on earth over one sinner who repents than over 10 just men who are saved. In the case of the Government moving towards even the partial privatisation of one of its statutory bodies, I suppose we should not be churlish. We should be celebrating the change of heart that this measure represents. Therefore, to some extent I am prepared to congratulate the Government for moving at least partially down the road which has been advocated by the Opposition.

One gets a range of opinions about the AIDC. It has been described in very complimentary terms by Government Ministers when it has suited them. When the Government was engaging in anti-privatisation diatribes in about 1985-86, accusing anybody who advocated privatisation as wishing to wantonly plunder the public sector for private profit, the AIDC was mentioned in quite warm and glowing terms by a number of senior Government Ministers. For some reason there has been a change of heart on the part of at least some Ministers.

I was fascinated to read the report of 8 June of what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had to say about the AIDC. He said some things which I found slightly extraordinary, but they are worth repeating to show the diverse attitudes which have been adopted by this Government. The report states:
``Why should the funds of superannuation members, who are mostly just workers, be put across to some genius so-called in the AIDC to invest it for him? . . .

``What do you think that every investment manager out there in the AMP Society or National Mutual or the other 300,000 funds is? A lemon? . . . the funds can only be invested wisely by someone at the AIDC, which is just a government merchant bank?
By the way, it's a government merchant bank which has conned two-thirds of the party . . .
There's a whole lot of bureaucrats out there having a great time in O'Connell Street . . .
The article notes, incidentally, that the AIDC is not in O'Connell Street, it is apparently in Jamieson Street, but I am not sure. In any event, Mr Keating went on to say:
. . . pumping money into it, saying: This is good, the Labor Party likes us. We should keep pumping money into this and, as you know, we've got the Left up there barracking for more capital for us.
They're laughing all the way to their big lunch.

Mr Keating said that what the Left was saying was: ``Instead of all these super funds actually putting money where they think they can invest it best in equities, we say, `No, we've got a better solution, we'll regulate a bit of it off you and send it down to the AIDC'.''

I think these must be comments relating to the Australian Council of Trade Unions' Australia Reconstructed, which suggested that the AIDC should be some sort of permanent part of the landscape which would accept sequestered funds from the superannuation savings of the Australian work force and the AIDC would have a voice in where these funds should be invested. It might be helpful in this debate if the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) could indicate whether the Government has any intention of sequestering the funds of Australian workers and giving the AIDC a role of the sort that the ACTU has advocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the Act.

—I think we are entitled to know whether the intentions of the Government are in that direction. In any event, I do not think that the Minister should be cross at my quoting the Treasurer. After all, the Treasurer, as I understand it, is still regarded as a senior spokesman for the Government and although his leadership ambitions seem to have been pushed back a week or two, notwithstanding Senator Button's support, he still speaks for the Party and for the Government. Mr Keating stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the public-private bureaucrats down there can actually have a bigger fund to walk around doing deals, and be the big dogs on the street . . . saying, `We've got all this money here. What's your proposition? Just step this way; we'll have a look at it for you'.
Mr Kevin Heffernan from the AIDC responded:
It sounds like (Mr Keating) doesn't like us very much.

All I can say is that if the AIDC brings that same nicety and precision of judgment that Mr Heffernan brought to Mr Keating's remark, I am sure it has a very big future indeed. I remind the Senate that the whole notion of privatisation-this is, of course, partial privatisation because 30 per cent is to be floated off to the public-is something which was very severely attacked and spoken of by the Government in terms which are worth repeating because they are a reminder of how suspicious one should be when this Government is at its most emphatic. The Hon. Paul Keating, who seemed in those reported comments of this year to be a bit critical about the public interest element of the AIDC, talking back in 1985 when he was playing a very hard political game on the issue of privatisation, stated:

No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.

That is what Mr Keating was saying back in May 1985. He said that the sale of a whole series of bodies which he mentioned, including the Australian Industry Development Corporation, `is simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities'. At the same time he stated:
The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth.

One can go on and on. The Prime Minister had a few purple passages about this subject too. Again it is a reminder of how little credit we should give the statements of the present Prime Minister. The Prime Minister described privatisation as:
. . . a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. They-
that is the dreadful people from the Liberal and National parties-
would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.

I suppose Mr Hawke, in some magic way, will ensure that the AIDC is not sold to a privileged few. I ask the Minister in his response to indicate what restrictions, if any, will be placed on potential shareholders, and to ensure that this is not a transfer, in the words of his leader, `to a privileged few'. Again, I have literally dozens of similar quotes from the Prime Minister and the Hon. Bill Hayden in his then capacity as Minister for Foreign Affairs. Mr Hayden actually referred to people who wanted to sell public enterprises as economic Moonies, which again is a reminder of the colourful turn of phrase which we assume he will drop as Governor-General which will be sadly missed, I am sure, in the House of Representatives.

This attitude of the Australian Labor Party, which was even reflected in some of the statements of Senator Peter Walsh, who is normally a little more hard-headed in these matters, continued through 1985 to 1986. Indeed, the Prime Minister went back to it after he had his flirtation with a pro-privatise position when, in September 1987, he talked about it as being economic and social vandalism. Again, that is an illustration of the quite erratic approach the Government has adopted. Senator Peter Walsh, for example, in November 1985, very effectively attacked the South Australian Government which was concerned to privatise-I think my recollection is right when I say that it was concerned simply to partially privatise-some State Government assets. He talked about it in these terms:

Mr Olsen says that he will fund his tax cuts by selling assets. That is another way of saying that he will liquidate assets in order to find current expenditure. We all know where that road leads. If one keeps going down that road for long enough, one finishes up insolvent.

There was no acknowledgment from Senator Peter Walsh at that time that there could be considerable virtues-virtues for quite different reasons-in promoting private ownership of some public assets. Debt reduction is one reason. In some cases there can be an encouragement of competition. Indeed, if Senator Peter Walsh bothered to look at the documents which have been published by the Opposition with respect to privatisation, he would find a great deal of attention being given to the notion that one of the most fundamental reasons to privatise is to increase competition where that can be done. That is not the only reason. As I said before, the record of the Victorian and Western Australian Labor governments with respect to their intervention in investment decisions through State instrumentalities is a sharp reminder that the very fact of government backing can of itself be a danger. It can lead to decisions, which on the surface are normal entrepreneurial risk decisions being taken, forgetting, of course, that the people taking the decisions do not run the risk of bankruptcy, of losing their assets, which provides a controlling mechanism in terms of the investment decisions of private corporations.

I will make one further quotation from Bob Hawke and the sort of silly-effective, of course-and ultimately destructive campaign which members of the Labor Party ran principally in 1985 and 1986 and which, of course, turned around and bit them in the backside when they tried to reform their policy in this area and their Party revolted, having been suitably converted by the rhetoric of 1985 and 1986. I am glad to see Senator McKiernan smile because I am sure that he did not need the rhetoric of 1985 and 1986 to convert him. I am sure that he is solidly in favour of public ownership of these great national enterprises. I do not say that in any disparaging way. Senator McKiernan has come into this chamber with some strong political views and I am sure that that would be one of them. He can correct me if I am wrong. I am sure that he did not need the rhetoric of 1985 and 1986. It is no wonder that the Labor Party gave Mr Hawke and his Government a lot of trouble when they tried to change their privatisation policy. In January 1986, Mr Hawke stated:

Privatisation is simply a flash way of saying they would flog off the assets of the people to their rich friends in private enterprise so that a select few could make profits out of those services which are profitable and the rest of Australia could go hang . . . ideologues tucked away in a mansion in Sydney . . .

Is that not a wonderful phrase? Does it not conjure up all the prejudice which has been so vital to keeping the Labor Party together over the years-those ideologues stuck in mansions in Sydney? Mr Hawke continued:
. . . think it would be a good idea to flog off the Bank, flog off Telecom so that a few people get rich providing some services at a price and a profit which suits them.

I do not believe that there is any intellectual belief in those numerous quotations. It is a small selection, however, of the quotations available to us. I do not believe that the Ministers at the table, Senator Walsh and Senator Button, believed for a moment the nonsense that they were talking in 1985 and 1986. It was just a pathetic and negative contribution to an important public debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not walked away from anything.

—I am pleased to have a further interjection from Senator Walsh. Of the Ministers concerned he is probably the least guilty of the sort of stupidity that I have been describing. Some of his contributions to the debate in this area-
—What about me? I did not say anything in 1985-86.

—If Senator Button can claim to have said nothing, his position in this argument will be a proud one indeed. I congratulate him on it. Senator Walsh has made some sensible contributions, some of them quite recently. Indeed, I want to quote Senator Walsh shortly because I think there are things to be said in his favour. The confusion in the Labor Party since 1986 is something that again I could enjoy, but I should not take up too much of the Senate's time on that. It is splendid to see this wonderful public debate with Mr Langmore, Clyde Cameron and Gareth Evans. Gareth Evans really summed up the dilemma for the Government. This is splendid vintage Evans, which explains why the debate has been so disorderly. Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: My heart, like those in the Labor Party, continues to tug in the direction of public ownership, but my head tells me that if we sweep privatisation off the table, we may be condemning some of these enterprises to death-either instant or by slow strangulation.

That is a good Evans phrase. It sums up the problem that the Labor Party recently has tried to come to grips with. Is it going to privatise these great public enterprises by seeing them become irrelevant, by seeing them wither away, is it going to give them access to capital through the Budget, or is it going to enable them to go into the private market? Broadly they are the choices which the Government faces.

The Government has disclosed that there are massive capital requirements for Qantas, for Australian Airlines and for the Commonwealth Bank. The AIDC is a tiny drop in the ocean. It is a very small part of what is required. I congratulate Senator Button on having been able, at least, to steer this tiny element of privatisation through the Government and the Cabinet. The much larger issues, the issues of our state-owned airlines and the issue of the Commonwealth Bank, have yet to be tackled in any realistic or effective way by the Government. But I welcome the fact that we have had from the Government a number of statements which make it clear that it has come up, looked around and realised that the economic arguments are totally contrary to the sort of populist nonsense, the sort of doctrinaire rubbish, that was a feature of Government statements on this matter in 1985-86. Note the different tone in the Treasurer's comments of April 1987:

The question needs to be asked: How can the public sector serve our traditional goals of social progress and equity? . . . Some assets may be used more efficiently outside the public sector. Sales of some assets would certainly relieve the Budget of ongoing subventions and, of course, all assets (sales) produce a capital appropriation to the Budget which either retires debt or slows down the buildup of debt and hence relieves the Budget of its very high public debt instruments commitment.

So the issue of efficiency is raised. The issue of relieving the Budget of ongoing subventions is raised. The fact that debt may be reduced is raised. These are all matters which were brought forward by the Opposition and have been brought forward by the Opposition for the last five or so years. The Prime Minister underwent a similar conversion. He said:

We must, for example, examine whether the need to further reduce Budget outlays and the public sector borrowing requirement is itself constraining the ability of the Government to provide the capital which some publicly owned enterprises need to perform their tasks efficiently and effectively. Freed of these constraints, these enterprises may become more efficient and more viable-an outcome which could only benefit consumers, taxpayers and the employees of the enterprise itself.

Again, that is in sharp and quite amazing contrast with the rubbish that the Prime Minister was speaking in his earlier comments that I have quoted. I will not quote, because I would not wish to flatter the Minister at the table, Senator Walsh, who is more distinguished for his offensive remarks about individuals outside the House in the Opposition than for anything that would warrant my quoting him with approval. But Senator Walsh, in a number of speeches, made some hard points to his own constituency in the Labor Party, no doubt, about the economic reasons for wishing to privatise. One has to ask why the Government needs to be in this business at all.

What is it about the AIDC which is peculiar and which it can do only if it is partly or wholly publicly owned? The last time I had a discussion with someone from the AIDC it was a quite informal discussion with the Chairman, Sir Gordon Jackson, who still seemed to be insisting that the AIDC did things which would not be done by a private organisation. A very senior member of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation who was present during the same conversation expressed great scepticism about that. The very small projects which are undertaken by the AIDC such as the malaria matter could certainly be done by the Government without the need for this publicly owned merchant bank, as it has been described by Treasurer Keating. We should welcome not only the conversion of the Government to the notion of there being some greater private ownership but also the conversion of the AIDC itself. One finds on page 5 of the 1988 AIDC annual report these comments:

A very senior member of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation who was present during the same conversation expressed great scepticism about that. The very small projects which are undertaken by the AIDC such as the malaria matter could certainly be done by the Government without the need for this publicly owned merchant bank, as it has been described by Treasurer Keating. We should welcome not only the conversion of the Government to the notion of there being some greater private ownership but also the conversion of the AIDC itself. One finds on page 5 of the 1988 AIDC annual report these comments:

To sustain the growth of equity investment, however, the capital base of the corporation must be enlarged. To this end the corporation explored alternative sources of capital and last year recommended to the Government the raising of private capital from the market to supplement Government capital. The proposal was favourably received by our Minister, Senator the Hon John N. Button, Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. With his strong support and encouragement the Board resolved to maintain the impetus of the Corporation's investment growth for the year in anticipation of a favourable outcome. The proposal was approved by Cabinet early in August 1988 and legislation to facilitate its implementation is to be introduced during the Budget sittings of Parliament.

I draw attention to this because I also wanted to advert to the original briefing I sought from the AIDC through Sir Gordon Jackson when I was first shadowing Senator Button. For the record, the very strong objection he made to me regarding any suggestion of privatisation of the AIDC should be noted. The reason I want to put that on the record is that the very strong view he expressed was accompanied by an equally strong statement that the AIDC itself would campaign against the proposition of the privatisation and that the AIDC was extremely influential-it had influence, for example, with the education profession, particularly science teachers.

This is relevant to public debate because there is some difficulty for the operation of Government, Opposition and the sort of society we want when government-funded bodies seek to exert a political influence on matters of public policy of that sort. I have some doubt in my mind that that is an appropriate function for the AIDC. Whilst I would be quite sure that no such view would be expressed in the minutes and the records of the company, I was extremely surprised to find that view being put to me by somebody who was in the position of Sir Gordon Jackson. It demonstrates the dangers to the public of this sort of public involvement in what should be private enterprise. I note that the Minister snorts. I think that is a fair description of his non-verbal, or non-oral, interjection. I think the matter is of some importance.

To the extent to which the Government reaches into this sort of enterprise, there is a risk of a distortion of the processes of argument and debate. I am pleased that the AIDC now seems to have a quite contrary view to the view which was expressed to me, as I say, when I sought a briefing about the AIDC and its activities.

This Bill tries to get over the difficulties in which the Government finds itself because of its earlier absurd rhetoric which was, in part, built around a desire to see the Bannon Government returned and which resulted in intemperate, inaccurate and stupid attacks on the Olsen Opposition. That led to a situation which proved to be politically unmanageable for the Government when it sought to change its policy in this area. It is interesting that as recently as late October this year Senator Walsh was reported as rekindling the privatisation debate when he raised the financing problems of Qantas and Australian Airlines. In a speech to a Canberra seminar on financing government enterprise, Senator Walsh said that one option for providing private sector equity for Qantas and Australian Airlines was to set up subsidiaries. He referred to the decision, which is being implemented by this Bill, to have a subsidiary of the AIDC and to float that as something that could meet the problem.

The Government knows that it will get the support of the Opposition for measures which move down the track in the constructive way that the Opposition has been saying for some years we should move. For that reason, the amendment I have moved is not an amendment which seeks to defeat the Bill but simply to record our view that the Bill does not go far enough. I do not believe that the Minister will be able to demonstrate that there is any real reason why the 30 per cent should not be 100 per cent. I say in anticipation of what the Minister might say that the public interest assignments that might be given to the AIDC by government could be handled in a quite different way, just as the Government has now adopted the idea of privatisation with respect to defence homes, where subsidised mortgages at concessional rates, provided to ex-servicemen as part of their remuneration, effectively, to acknowledge their contribution to Australia, continue to be provided through the agency of a private bank, the mortgages having been sold off by the Commonwealth under an agreement which guarantees the continuance of the beneficial conditions that are enjoyed by those defence personnel.

That is one example of the way public purposes can be achieved by arrangements between government and the private sector. One does not need a merchant bank or a bank to achieve that. It is perhaps worthy of remark that it was not necessary for the Government to come to some arrangement with the government-owned bank-the Commonwealth Bank-to achieve its objectives. Presumably, Westpac made a better tender than the Commonwealth Bank and, therefore, got the contract. That simply demonstrates that in that and every other area one cares to nominate arrangements could be made without the need to own a bank, a merchant bank or whatever one might wish to describe the Australian Industry Development Corporation as being.

The Opposition's view is that there are no public interest reasons for maintaining government involvement in the AIDC. It acts as a commercial enterprise. It is, as the Treasurer has described it, just a government merchant bank and only a very small proportion of its funds are targeted towards development or venture capital. The Corporation has developed some expertise in manufacturing and tourism finance, but this can be and has been developed in the private sector as well in response to market demand. I believe that no serious argument can be put forward to maintain the public form of the Corporation.

The other point that is of some concern is that floating off only 30 per cent means that those people who invest in the bank will be permanent minority shareholders. Whilst it is true that legal protections are given to minority shareholders, those protections are often cumbersome and expensive if one needs to avail oneself of them. I commend the Bill for speedy passage and I commend the amendment I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My admiration is absolutely unlimited for Senator Chaney's ability to get up and fill exactly half an hour with speech irrespective of the importance or otherwise of a matter, but I cannot say the same about his reference to Senator Evans's remarks, which he repeated, in relation to privatisation. It seems quite clear to me that what Senator Evans was saying was that it was politically unwise, not economically unwise, not to go down the road of privatisation, the reason being that, the Labor Government having ensured that most of the media are now in the hands of very few individuals and those individuals are extremely powerful in the private sector, it would be unwise not to put more financial power and resources into their hands because those media outlets have the means to make or break the Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not at all impressed with Senator Chaney's disparaging remarks regarding the retention in public ownership of public assets. While he said that it is economic nonsense to retain many of these assets, he provided not one shred of evidence to support that claim. In fact, the evidence goes the other way. He posed the rhetorical question: what is there about public ownership which is not also shared with private ownership in terms of the public interest? It is precisely that. It is the public interest which is not served by private ownership. Private ownership has one motivation and that is to maximise profits to those individuals who own the shares or company. Those private companies can in no sense serve the public interest. If they do so it is by accident and not by design. The other major advantage of public ownership is that the profits from those organisations which are profitable flow back to the public and not to those few individuals who happen to be fortunate enough to own the shares.

The Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) was created in 1970. It operates principally as a provider of capital to various firms for development, particularly those with an export orientation, and for the promotion of Australian industry. The Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill seeks to flog off 30 per cent of the organisation to private interests-in other words, to gut the organisation as such, to establish a subsidiary which becomes a public company, and float off 30 per cent of the shares to private interests. When the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) introduced the Bill in the other place he said:

The establishment of the listed subsidiary should not be construed as a partial privatisation of AIDC, but rather as an opportunity for the public to share in the national development objectives of AIDC.

If anything is newspeak, that is it. That is a clear misstatement of what is going on. This is partial privatisation. I draw attention to the fact that about 7 per cent of the Australian public own shares in companies. Ninety-three per cent of the Australian population do not own shares. To talk about an opportunity for the public to share in a national development corporation is arrant nonsense. It is also being deliberately deceitful in relation to telling the Australian public what this is about. That share ownership translates through into the relative share of wealth owned by various sections of the Australian community. I remind the Senate that one per cent of Australians own 25 per cent of this country's wealth; 5 per cent own 50 per cent; and 10 per cent own 60 per cent. Of course, that means that the remaining 90 per cent of the population share but 40 per cent of the total wealth of this country. Further on in the Minister's speech in the House of Representatives we find:
No single private person or associated group will be permitted to hold more than 10 per cent of the subsidiary's voting equity.

As we are talking about $50m we are talking about one person owning $5m. I simply pose the question: How many Australians have the wherewithal to go in and buy shares to that value? What an absolute deception to say, on the one hand, that this is not partial privatisation and to claim on the other hand, that this is some sort of an opportunity by which the public can share in the national development objectives of the AIDC!
We also find on page 2 of the Minister's statement that this is a very effective and profitable organisation. The Minister says:
. . . the Corporation has experienced a period of very strong asset growth of over 250 per cent in the four years to 30 June 1987.

So we are not talking about an organisation which is in any sense a lame duck. Private interests would not be keen to take over such an organisation. We are talking about an organisation which is of considerable benefit to the Australian public because it is performing very well.

That brings me to the general proposition that there is no evidence whatsoever that, in general, public organisations work less well than private organisations. There is no evidence whatsoever that the free operation of the market serves the common good.
