The idea first floated, I think by Adam Smith, that some invisible hand would guide competitive greed towards the serving of the common good is simply an a prior assumption without basis. Moreover, if one looks at the mathematics of the so-called level playing field that the Opposition likes talking about so much-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Government that talks about the level playing field.

—Both Government and Opposition. I will come to that point in a moment, because here we have both sides in bed together on this one. The operation of a competitive market system in no sense will maintain the sort of stability in which that market can persist indefinitely, and that is readily demonstrable mathematically. The level playing field, the operation of the pure market that is talked about so often and so flippantly without any intellectual justification, is simply a very unstable situation which will, of itself, always hunt towards a monopoly position. Of course, if one looks at the operation of the market in practice, one sees that that is exactly what happens. Markets rapidly move towards monopoly positions; the very few become extremely rich and the rest go to the wall.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is no evidence whatsoever to support the assertion made by Senator Chaney that privatisation, plus the operation of the market system, will serve the common interest. I was disgusted to hear Senator Chaney quote the New Testament as a source of justification for partial privatisation. To argue that putting more wealth in the hands of the few who are already wealthy somehow has some religious basis in fact is like the sort of assertion that was made the other night by Senator Puplick when he talked about the Australian Democrats maintaining the politics of greed. I suggest that it is the Opposition and the Government that are very much the merchants of the politics of greed in serving the interests of the already wealthy.

It was said earlier this afternoon by an honourable senator in this place that it takes two to tango. Of course, what we see in this place is that the two that are tangoing are the Government and the Opposition. There is very little to choose between the New Right economics which are proposed by the Opposition and the Hawke-Keating or, indeed, the Walsh-Button economics, which are the same thing; and this is an example of that. The differences between the coalition and the Hawke-Keating Government are just differences of degree, and I think we see that in the amendment which Senator Chaney has proposed and which the Democrats will certainly reject. While the Government would privatise 30 per cent of this organisation, the Opposition would go the whole way. No doubt a few years down the track the Government would also privatise the remainder in any case.

The policies of both groups are designed to win the approval of bankers and business people. They are designed to win the approval of those who are already rich and who are already privileged. They are policies that Mr Fraser flirted with in theory but not in practice. They are economic policies based on the assumption that it is bad for a government to own public enterprises, and to regulate, spend or borrow to achieve socially desirable aims; or, conversely, that private ownership and private borrowing with little or no government regulation is automatically good. Of course, what follows from privatisation is that the more privatisation one has, the more it needs to be regulated, because it is simply profit seeking and it does not serve the common good, so we must put in place regulation. The Democrats' point is that it is far better to keep these things in public ownership.

These economic assumptions of the Opposition and the Government created the squalor, the misery and the poverty of dickensian England. While the free marketeers and the racketeers made fortunes, the rest of the population lived in poverty. That is precisely where this market-driven privatisation would eventually lead. We have a Labor Government that has deregulated financial markets. It harps about the need to reduce government borrowing; it peddles privatisation, and it reduces Government expenditure to the detriment of low income Australians so that it can achieve what it calls a balanced Budget.

In turning to the alternative approaches, one finds, on page 3 of the statement, that Mr Jones has set out the problems which were being confronted by the AIDC and the way in which those problems could be dealt with. He stated:
. . . the Government examined a number of options: firstly, to continue as at present;-
that is, to maintain the existing structure and the accumulation of assets by the process which has been going on since 1970-
Secondly, to provide a substantial capital instalment from the budget; or, thirdly, to raise equity capital from the private sector.

That is where the list finishes. Of course, the fourth alternative-and this is one of the things which neither the Government nor the Opposition is prepared to look at-is that in exactly the same way that the private banks create credit out of thin air, so the Commonwealth or the Reserve Bank of Australia could create the credit for this organisation. That is a process that has been used in the past. It has been used to support the Wheat Board with interest free credit, until the money from the harvest came in, so that farmers could receive credit, and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) may well have received some of this money himself when he was a wheat producer. In the past the Reserve Bank has also given to the States loans at a one per cent interest rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Reserve Bank used to make an advance to the Wheat Board at a concessional rate of interest-something that I always opposed. We have now got rid of that.
—I am suggesting that that creation of credit should remain in public hands and not be given over to private interest. I am surprised to hear the Minister say--

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was making the point that Senator Chaney had said that it was a Christian virtue to give more to the rich and take from the poor. I was also making the point that there was another way of raising capital for the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC)-namely, that the Government itself could create credit. When I gave several examples of how that had been done in Australia, that brought the rejoinder from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that as soon as he was able to he would stop that practice.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that there is a considerable tradition behind the Government being the sole credit creation authority. Indeed, I believe that just before the turn of the century the Australian Labor Party itself proposed the creation of the Commonwealth Bank precisely because it recognised that the Government should be the sole credit creation authority. I remember that one of the great Labor Prime Ministers of this country, Ben Chifley, also had something to say about the private banks having the sole credit creation capability. I also remember the problems which that caused for this country. One knows what happened to Ben Chifley and what the Opposition did when he came up with that proposal. It is worth while making this point because honourable senators may not understand that the banks do not lend the money that is deposited with them. In fact, they lend approximately 10 times as much money as is deposited with them. When a bank creates an overdraft for someone, it simply creates a book entry of a debt to that person and a credit to itself. Moreover, it does not create the money which will pay the interest on that overdraft, so necessarily the banks become richer and those who go into debt by way of overdraft become poorer. There is abundant evidence to support this.

I quote Professor Hotson, professor of economics at Toronto University, whose remarks bear very much on the way in which this public instrumentality, which the Australian Democrats are saying should remain a public instrumentality, should obtain its extra finance; they also bear on the position of other public utilities which this Government seeks to privatise. He said:

The first rule of public finance should be, `no government should ever borrow any money from any private bank.' It can create the needed money, interest and debt free, through its Treasury Department, or the second best solution, borrow from its publicly-owned Central Bank at say, half of one per cent.
He went on:

But would not such a policy be wildly inflationary? Absolutely not, provided at the same time as zero or low interest money is being fed into the economy, the reserve requirements on commercial banks are raised successively to prevent an explosion of bank credit.
In other words, taking away from the private banks the credit creation capacity which they now have and vesting that with a public bank. Professor Hotson continued:
For not only is bank credit the real source of all inflation in our age, it is also the source of business depressions that so mar the history of capitalism.
I now quote what Professor John Kenneth Galbraith had to say on exactly the same matter-the creation of money. Galbraith wrote a book called Money-Whence it Came, Where It Went in which he said:
The process by which banks create credit is so simple that the mind is repelled.

It seems to me a repugnant observation that this Government, supported by this Opposition, is prepared to go to the private banks and put publicly owned corporations such as the AIDC into hock to those who are already wealthy rather than use the instruments that are available to them to create that credit through bodies such as the Reserve Bank of Australia or the Commonwealth Bank, which are already owned by the Government. Indeed, we heard Senator Chaney this afternoon talk about the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. We have also heard those sorts of statements from certain Government senators. That would herald the end of a rational, sensible economic system in this country, oriented towards public benefit rather than private gain.

Other simple means are available by which this organisation can remain publicly owned and can expand its capital base for the benefit of the public and those companies for which it was set up, and moreover, without the need to go into hock to private capital. We believe that that should be done. We oppose the sale of 30 per cent of this instrumentality. We certainly oppose the Opposition's attempt to privatise the AIDC completely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, having just listened to an example of breathtaking antediluvianism, that it is rather incredible to imagine that there can be rational economic debate on a subject such as this-the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill 1988. There seem to be some who are locked in a time warp and are not prepared to face the reality of what the consequences would be if we accepted Senator Walsh's figure, that $8 billion to $10 billion could be necessary in order to provide sufficient capital even to allow for an expansion of the operation of Government business enterprises in the transport and communications sectors. One must really ask why it is that the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) is in the business that it is in. Certainly, the only conclusion I can reach is that it is a convenient vehicle for patronage on the part of the Government. It has a list of 12 worthy luminaries on its board, who no doubt get a great deal of kudos from attending board meetings and waxing lyrical about all the marvellous things they are doing, but at the end of the day they are not doing one thing that could not be done by the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice, for example, that the activities of the AIDC in recent years have been as diverse as being a major lender in the first phase of the Woodside Petroleum Ltd North West Shelf project; putting together funding for the Wesfarmers liquefied petroleum gas plant in Western Australia; putting equity and debt into the Hyatt Hotel in Melbourne; and putting equity and debt into the five star Fairmont Resort at Leura in the Blue Mountains. I do not understand why any of those activities could not have been wholly financed by the private sector. Nonetheless, it is probably illuminating to quote one of the directors of the AIDC, who said:
We need a greater equity base to support what we want to do. So far we have not been greatly constrained, but we have had a number of opportunities into which we could have put funding if we had it.

That is a classic approach to business. If one regards oneself as having an entitlement to get involved in a whole range of private sector activities, it is very difficult to imagine what other constraint there could be, apart from capital. For example, the annual report proudly boasts:
AIDC takes pride in being Australia's foremost development financier and investor. We are a government enterprise operating in a thoroughly commercial manner.
When one looks to the second reading speech of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) for a justification of the activities of the AIDC, the most one finds is this sort of pap:
AIDC's ability to provide both loan and equity capital across the spectrum of new and old industries is a key characteristic which differentiates it from other financial institutions.

It is as though the average merchant bank or investment bank is not able to provide debt or equity capital for a range of new and old industries. It is absolute nonsense. The Minister's second reading speech also contains this similar feeble effort:
Given the public interest roles expected of AIDC, which remain the raison d'etre for its continued presence in the public sector . . .

We ask: What are the public interest roles expected of the AIDC? One should bear in mind that this Bill supposedly provides amendments that take the AIDC and all its brethren into the brave new world that Senator Evans was not quite prepared to tackle. He mouthed the rhetoric and nodded in the right direction, but dropped the ball before he reached the goal line. If we take this as an example and look at these amendments and see what is left we find that the AIDC Act is still riddled with a whole range of interventionist entitlements:
Enterprises or projects in the national interest
The Minister may, from time to time . . . inform the Corporation of the policy of the Commonwealth Government.
There are requirements for reports back and forth:
the Corporation shall furnish to the Minister a report in writing in relation to the enterprise or project.
Matters to be taken into account by the Corporation

In the performance of its functions the Corporation shall have regard to the current monetary policy of the Commonwealth Government . . . in relation to trade practices, the environment, industrial relations, urban and regional development and the efficiency of industry.
(3) The Corporate shall . . . have regard to-
(a) the importance of the industry concerned to the Australian economy;

These are just words. It is nonsense. It is a generalised blueprint for providing carte blanche involvement and intervention. I cannot see that this Bill will do much in that regard. All it is really doing is providing a convenient justification for what is nothing more nor less than a charade for those in the Australian Labor Party who have not quite got the stomach to talk in terms of corporatisation, let alone privatisation.

We have had this artificial device served up of providing a separate listing vehicle that will be able to raise 30 per cent from the public. It is unwieldy, it is unnecessary, it is indirect and at the end of the day, of course, it will be underwritten directly by an explicit guarantee from the Government because all borrowings will be undertaken by the holding company, the AIDC. It is a complete and utter nonsense. It is just a fiction to disguise the inability of Senator Gareth Evans and his colleagues to persuade the majority of the troglodytes in his Party as to the virtues of privatisation, which are blindingly obvious to most of those who have turned their minds to this subject. I include in that category Senator Walsh because I was intrigued to read a recent speech of his to the Business Law Education Centre in Canberra on 24 August last. I note his conversion to Thatcherism, which is somewhat surprising in one sense given the faction to which he belongs. Nonetheless, here it is:

Until six weeks ago I had regarded the Thatcher model for the transfer to private ownership of government enterprises as a cynical attempt to raise a large amount of money to fund election winning tax cuts.

Senator Chaney said before the dinner adjournment that in November 1985 Senator Walsh was talking about going down the insolvency road. We all know that he has been down the Argentinean road and presumably as a result of this little exercise he has been down the Damascus road or perhaps even the Cyprus road because he says this:

On my way to the recent Commonwealth Finance Ministers Conference in Cyprus, I spent a few days in London where some things became clear to me. Privatisation had not been conceived as a cynical exercise to raise revenue-though no doubt it is a present objective. The original objective was to make public enterprises more efficient.

One would have thought that was an impeccable goal and an admirable objective and one that even Senator Walsh freely acknowledges, and I think to his credit has acknowledged at least for the last several years. It should be blindingly apparent that one of the great difficulties facing government business enterprises is their inability to raise sufficient capital and certainly to get the hand-outs to which they would like to become accustomed from government. It is simply far beyond the capacity of any government, even one with a $5.7 billion revenue surplus which no doubt is going to be distributed with such great profligacy on about 1 July next year. Nonetheless, if we are talking seriously about providing the funds necessary, the Government does not have the capacity to deliver. Senator Walsh acknowledges that and recognises the reality and makes it clear that privatisation makes a great deal of sense.
I must say I was quite intrigued to see him giving some very friendly advice to the Opposition. He said this, for example:
The Liberal and National party coalition in this country should bear these points in mind as they proceed with the development of their own privatisation policy.

That is very gentle and kindly stuff. It is about as close as one could get to an explicit endorsement of coalition policy in this area. He then proceeded to list all of the targets that he thought we had on the drawing board. In fact, he left off the Commonwealth Bank. Nonetheless, he proceeded to make a few pejorative comments. He did not in any way question the underlying rationale, or the need, for privatisation of any of those enterprises. At the end of the day he knows the problems he faces within his own party. That is why this unfortunate method has been adopted in this instance. Senator Walsh simply put it forward as one possible method for achieving equity from the private sector.

Indeed, it is that. It does not go far enough, as we have made very clear. In a sense it is a mirrors and beads exercise because at the end of the day partial privatisation will inevitably lead, in due course, to calls for full privatisation.

If one analyses the objectives of the AIDC, what is required in the private sector and the capacity of other investment banks to deliver the capital requirements, it will inevitably transpire that the AIDC will not need to remain in the public sector. We welcome that. We regard that as simply a realistic acknowledgment that the AIDC does not need to be in the business of picking winners, that it should take its chances out in the private sector. If it is as good as its annual report says it is, no doubt it will continue to thrive. It has been let off any dividend repayment this year because of the shortage of capital. Unless it is it will shrink in the same way that the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Airlines, for example, have been taken to the cleaners by their competitors. That is a deliberate, callous and cynical result of this Government's intransigence in the area, its refusal to face up to economic reality and its determination to provide massive tax cuts in due course in the hope that they will save its bacon at the next election. The real losers in that little exercise are a whole range of government business enterprises that have legitimate claims on capital, not necessarily in the public sector.

I welcome the Bill to the extent to which it goes. It seems to me that it still does not fundamentally address the real issue of why the AIDC needs to be in the business at all. One would hope that in due course we will not need to be having this sort of debate, despite the Australian Democrats, who no doubt will maintain their economic irrelevancy in this general area. I simply say in closing that I would like an explanation at some stage of why in this package of Bills some government business enterprises are being relieved of the immunity of the shield of the Crown and others are not. In this particular instance it would seem that the AIDC remains immune. That does not seem to make sense to me. The closer we can get to putting the AIDC into actual competition with private sector competitors the better it will be for the exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear Senator Alston go off about the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). He talked about the fact that we did not go far enough, that we should have sold out completely to private enterprise. He went on to criticise the people on the board who, I understand, come from private enterprise and who are very efficient in their job and very dedicated to assisting--
—What-Simon Crean; private enterprise, is he?

—Yes, and people like Jackson. Those people cannot borrow money in a normal banking system because they are not prepared to take the risk. Where there are some problems the AIDC has provided that capital, very successfully, to the extent that it has made a profit on almost every occasion. It does take a very businesslike approach. That is why it has been successful. There has been no shortage of private banking businesses to provide those sorts of loans but they have denied them and abdicated their responsibility in this area. If my memory is correct the Fraser Government established the AIDC. So it is rather strange to hear someone from the opposition criticise the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill 1988 provides for private equity in the AIDC which was sought by private enterprise. The Labor Government has provided that opportunity on the basis that the additional money that comes in will enlarge opportunities for companies not able to attract funds in the private banking industry. If that is a negative approach, then I am absolutely amazed. I think it is a very positive approach. The Opposition is only trying to make political capital in a very inefficient and inappropriate way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, in his rush to grab and hang on to the coat-tails of the New Right, spent a lot of time referring to the antediluvians and miscellaneous troglodytes who are still prepared to support the institution of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and, in doing so, ignored, as Senator Burns has just reminded us, a rather important piece of history; that is, that the AIDC was of course established by a conservative government. In fact, it was established in 1970 for the very purposes for which it still exists today, namely, to help finance the development and growth of Australian private enterprise in a variety of sectors, and to assist Australia in the participation and control of Australian industry. That is the objective. It was a worthy objective then and remains a worthy objective now.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for those, among other reasons, that we have of course pursued this legislation designed to further streamline and make more effective and up to date in relative and contemporary terms the organisation and activities of the AIDC. It is for those reasons that we reject the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition. As was stated in the second reading speech, the AIDC performs a unique function which differentiates it from other financial institutions. Under its charter, the AIDC has provided not only necessary finance for the restructuring and vitalisation of Australia's older industries but also the development of new high technology industries as well as again participating in things like anti-malaria vaccine research under the national interest provisions of the Australian Industry Development Commission Act.

In this role over the years AIDC has proven to be a very effective instrument of government industry policy. The decision to allow AIDC to raise private sector equity acknowledges the capital constraint that would otherwise have limited its future capacity to contribute to industry development. To sell AIDC in its entirety to the private sector, as this amendment proposes, would see the loss of an effective arm of industry policy without any assurance that the private sector has the capacity, or indeed the willingness, to pick up the activities carried out in the past by the AIDC.

I will summarise in two or three paragraphs what the effect of this legislation will be. No Commonwealth assets will be sold off. The Corporation will remain 100 per cent Commonwealth owned. The purpose is rather to enable, as I have said, AIDC, through its subsidiary, to raise additional capital necessary for it to continue meeting the Government's industry policy objectives. The Government's intention, as is evident from the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill, is to approach the external capital raising it in two steps. First, the bulk of AIDC's business excluding borrowings will be transferred to a wholly owned subsidiary company with the minimum of change or distortion, such that the business would be shown in the books of the subsidiary as being in the books of AIDC prior to the transfer taking account of the indemnity arrangements and the proposed new section 29L. The subsidiary would then become the investment joint venture between Government and public, with the public providing new capital. The AIDC, with its subsidiary, will continue to play a vital role in the ongoing development of the private sector through the provision of loan and equity finance for the development, revitalisation and restructuring of Australian industry.

After that very learned account, may I conclude by thanking honourable senators for their contributions to this debate, tendentious as it may have been on occasions. Nonetheless, I note the support that is on offer for the legislation and wish it a speedy passage accordingly.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE TO ADVISE ON AUSTRALIA'S IMMIGRATION POLICIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with several of the other speakers in the debate today, I will try to keep my remarks relatively brief in the interests of the conduct of the remainder of the Senate's legislative program.
—They all tried but none succeeded.

—I shall try, but I do not guarantee that I will succeed. I am sure that none of the participants in today's debate and this evening's debate would want any brevity on their part to be seen in any way as an indication of the lack of importance of this debate on Australia's future immigration policies. That is what we are in essence talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to join at the outset other speakers in congratulating Dr Stephen FitzGerald and the members of his Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies for the dedication and skill that they brought to their task and for the result of their labours. The result that they produced was one of the very best reports from any government established committee for many years. That does not mean that I agree with all the Committee's recommendations. In particular, I strongly disagree with the recommendations concerning our future Indo-Chinese refugee program. Overall, however, I do strongly support the Committee's recommendations.

I also welcome the statement made today by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). It has been a long time coming. I do not criticise the present Minister, Senator Ray, for that. He has held the portfolio for only a short period, and I fully recognise the requirement to give proper consideration and processing to what was a long and complex report. But neither of these factors prevent me from placing the blame for the unnecessary delay where it quite properly lies, that is, with the former Minister, Mr Holding. Mr Holding has a dreadful record in government. He was the worst Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that this country has ever had. We have now had 11 Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs. It should be 12. If the present Minister, Mr Hand, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had any respect for ministerial integrity and parliamentary responsibility, either Mr Hand would resign or he would be sacked for misleading the Parliament on at least three separate occasions in recent weeks. Mr Holding was also arguably the second worst Minister for Immigration that this nation has ever had. The first prize, of course, goes to Mr Stewart West.

TALK.START.PARA: —By a street.

—Yes, by a street. But Mr Holding runs him a very definite second. My welcoming of Senator Ray's statement does not mean, however, that I endorse it; nor, I am sure, does Senator Ray himself. It is quite clear that Senator Ray and the Prime Minister were rolled in Cabinet on several of the major proposals. The most significant was the proposal concerning skilled migrants, but there are many others too which show conclusively that the final shape of the Government's immigration proposals has essentially been determined by the left wing of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a great deal of contact with a wide range of ethnic communities, particularly in Victoria. For example, my electorate office is located in what is probably colloquially known as the ethnic centre of Australia. I have a great deal of pleasure in the contact that I have with those communities. In this capacity I have had more than my fill of listening to the Chairman of the Government's immigration and ethnic affairs committee, the honourable member for Calwell, Dr Theophanous, railing against the findings of FitzGerald in the most distorted and hysterical fashion. Therefore, when I read in the Melbourne Sun today that Dr Theophanous had said last night, `In the final analysis, I think Cabinet has taken a very wise decision', I knew that the Government had killed the recommendations of the FitzGerald report and had bowed to the agenda of left of the Labor movement and to its industrial wing, namely, the trade union movement.

In his statement today, the Minister said that the FitzGerald report `has set the broad direction for the changes I am about to announce'. The Minister must surely have had his tongue in his cheek when making that remark because nothing could be further from the truth. The truth is that the Government has rejected the main thrust of the FitzGerald Committee report. That thrust was that Australia's immigration program needs to be given a much sharper economic focus. This means a much greater emphasis on skilled migration than has occurred in recent years. The FitzGerald Committee made that abundantly clear in much of what it wrote in its report. For the Senate's benefit, I will quote two or three passages from that report. In its executive summary on page xii of the report, the Committee stated:

The sharper economic focus for which the Government has called is the most central issue in immigration reform. The composition of the immigration program, and of skill levels, are critical if immigration is to contribute to enhanced economic performance. The skills profile of some groups of immigrants has fallen. The median age is rising.
It went on to state on the same page:
To realise its potential economic benefits to Australia, the immigration program needs a high proportion of skilled, entrepreneurial and youthful immigrants . . .
Later, in chapter 3, at page 37 of the report, the Committee stated:
. . . an immigration program of the current order of magnitude and skill composition would be likely to contribute less than 0.07 per cent per annum to national per capita income growth.

A larger program would raise the contribution to growth to 0.09 per cent per annum. But a larger program of highly skilled and entrepreneurial immigrants would make a marked contribution to economic growth.
Finally, page 90 of the report states:

The Committee recommends that tripartite negotiated arrangements . . . be central to the allocation of points to different skills under the labour market skills factor. They should largely determine where the skill shortages are and which skills should receive the highest points.

It recommended that seven groups of factors should form the basis of the selection procedures, and that the first priority should be labour market skills and the second entrepreneurship and special talents. In the 5 1/2 years that the Hawke Government has been in office, the proportion of skilled migrants in our total intake has fallen from over 50 per cent to between 20 and 30 per cent. That is a massive fall. It has had a massive adverse economic impact. The FitzGerald report identified and highlighted this cost and the Committee framed its recommendations around this basic point. As I said, the Government has rejected virtually all the Committee's recommendations in this area.

I will go through three or four of the main recommendations. The first, recommendation 40, is that seven groups of factors should form the basis of the selection procedure, with labour market skills and entrepreneurship and special talents being the first two. That has not been accepted by the Government. Recommendation 41, which I have also read out, is that points should be determined largely to meet the skill shortages which might exist and that, therefore, certain skills should receive higher points. That recommendation has not been accepted, neither has recommendation 42, which reads:

. . . that the contribution of people with entrepreneurial skills to Australia's economic development be recognised by awarding a significant number of points for entrepreneurship, including a component on capital transfer insofar as it relates to a business venture.
The other main recommendation, in which the three recommendations that I have just read culminate, is recommendation 49. That is a long recommendation. The first sentence reads:
. . . the highest weightings go to the skills and entrepreneurship factors.

The Government has rejected that recommendation as well. Today the chairman of the Committee that produced the FitzGerald report, Dr Stephen FitzGerald, put out a media release in which he welcomed the Government's decisions. I understand that this statement was tabled in this chamber before dinner by Senator Schacht. Having examined the Government's statement and having outlined certain points, I find Dr FitzGerald's press release very surprising. I wonder whether he has studied the Government's decisions in detail. I wonder whether the other members of the Committee would share Dr FitzGerald's view that the Government has taken most of the thrust of the FitzGerald recommendations into account. I must say that there seem to be some errors in his press release. For example, he says:
. . . the bulk of the Committee's recommendation (some 80%) had in fact been accepted by Cabinet . . .

That figure seems to me to be extraordinarily high. I have done a count on it and my figure would come out at closer to 60 to 65 per cent, including acceptance of the motherhood recommendations of philosophy, on which there is no disagreement throughout our community. If we look at the number of recommendations for specific policy action decisions, we see that the Government has rejected well over half of the Committee's decisions and, if they are weighted out for substance, it has rejected virtually all of them. I hope that Dr FitzGerald was not leaned on too much to produce that press release today. I do not think it fully reflects the Cabinet's decision. I hope that he will have another look at that.

The Government has also decided to reduce the intake under the business migration program by 2000. It has produced a totally spurious and dishonest reason for that. The Minister said in his statement today:
The reduction reflects the expected effect of the Asian immigration debate.

That is a totally false, dishonest, wrong statement. There are mixed views in the community on this whole debate, but it cannot be asserted with any veracity that the immigration debate has had a negative effect on business migration applications. I draw the Senate's attention to one of the few objective reports I have seen on this matter, namely, a report which appeared in the Melbourne Herald of this week, 6 December, by the Herald's Hong Kong correspondent, Mark Baker. He has some interesting things to say, having researched the matter from the Hong Kong base. He says:
. . . the latest government statistics show that there has been no decline so far in business migration applications from Hong Kong and Taiwan-Australia's biggest source of investor migrants.
. . . Australian officials and leading migration consultants based in Hong Kong can produce no cases of prospective migrants who have abandoned plans to migrate because of the controversy.
At the same time an independent public opinion survey in Hong Kong last week indicated a surge in support for Australia as a potential migration destination . . .
An independent opinion poll indicated that Australia had now moved ahead of the United States and was second only to Canada as the preferred migration destination.

The report by Mark Baker cites various other statistics. It states that officials at the Australian Consulate General in Hong Kong say that their records and reports from migration consultants indicate that there is a backlog of about 1,200 prospective business migrants awaiting processing. The business migration agencies in Hong Kong have made statements to support the remarks that I have just made. For example, a Mr Bill Kuo, a consultant with the legal firm of Baker and McKenzie, said about the migration debate:

The issue has provoked a lot of discussion among our clients and a lot of people are now adopting a wait-and-see attitude, but no one has said they won't go to Australia because they think it's a racist country.

Mr Steven Yu, of Steven Yu, McCann and Associates, one of the most active consultants in Hong Kong, said that he had seen no decline in the level of interest in business migration to Australia. So much for the nonsense and dishonesty in the Government's statements, including the Minister's statement today, I am sorry to say, about this whole aspect of business migration.

Several other of the Government decisions require careful consideration before one can make a firm judgment on them. I guess that we would all want to preface our remarks on the points of detail about this report by saying that we saw the Government's statement only today. There is a great deal in it and a great deal of detail in it which will need careful consideration before one can form a firm judgment. The question of a floating points system is one that I would certainly like to think about more. Its practical application could be significant. For example, how many points will apply to an applicant if he made his initial application in, say, January of a particular year, the application was taking several months or a year to process and the points system changed along the way? How many points would the person be regarded as having? Which hurdle would he have to jump?

The weighting to be given to the various components of the points system also requires very careful consideration. We are to have dual selection procedures and a differential points test depending on the category of migration. In that context there appears to have been downgrading of the value attached to a person's proficiency in English. I am not certain of that but it is something, again, which I would want to examine much more closely. If there has been a significant further downgrading-that would be difficult to do considering what the Government has done over recent years; it has slashed dramatically the English proficiency element-it is a very bad move.

There is also an argument that, for the first time in our history, the Government, with its decision today, has created two classes of citizen. A migrant being sponsored by an Australian citizen will score a different number of points depending on whether the sponsor has been a citizen for less than five years or more than five years. A very important point of principle needs consideration. Have we not, in fact, created two classes of citizen? Why should an Australian citizen be considered differently if he has been a citizen for four years rather than six years?

As I understand the proposed points allocation system, if a person has been unemployed for less than one month he can receive 10 points, but if he has been unemployed for more than one month-for example, one month and a day-regardless of the reason of the unemployment, he gets no points at all. That is also a matter that requires further consideration. I do not profess to give a final judgment on it. These are all matters of significance that need to be looked at.

The decision to abolish the self-supporting retirees category is an important one. As elected members of Parliament, immigration cases come to us and we see some very worthwhile self-supporting retiree cases. It appears that that category will no longer exist. However, curiously, retirees will be able to come here on what is called a temporary stay, on an extended basis. What does that mean? How will it work out in practice? For example, what happens if a retiree gets sick while he is here? That is another matter that needs very careful consideration.

I regret that the Government, again, has been tardy beyond any reasonableness in terms of looking at overseas qualifications, which is a very important area. As Senator Puplick said today, there have been reports over many years-the report of the Fry Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications and others-and still the Government has not moved in that area. My guess is that one of the reasons the Government has been so tardy in moving on the recognition of overseas qualifications is the pressure that is being exerted on it by the trade union movement. That has been one of the major hassles in recent years and there seems to be no reason why that will change.

On the face of it, the establishment of the Bureau of Immigration Research is perhaps a reasonable proposition, but it is a very expensive one. It will cost $4m a year and will employ a staff of 41, despite the fact that most of the research work that that Bureau will do will be commissioned out. There is every indication that there will be a duplication of the work of the Bureau by existing bodies. I think that the role of the Bureau needs to be spelled out much more clearly.

I believe that the whole question of the Minister's decision making powers needs to be considered further. My own view on that is that the Minister's statement goes along the right lines but, as I think was also pointed out by Senator Puplick and perhaps Senator Stone today, the Minister's retaining the general statutory power to override any decision of the revamped review panel system which, consistent with the regulations acts against the interests of the applicant, may well be a reasonable proposition. But it appears that the Minister would not have the power to reverse a decision by the review panel which had been in favour of the applicant if we, for good and valid reasons, wanted to refuse that person entry to Australia. Again, I believe that that is another matter that requires consideration.

There are some aspects of the report that I welcome, for example, the continued commitment to our refugee and humanitarian program and the maintenance of the family reunion program, although again I think that the fine details there need careful examination. Those decisions are fully in line with the policies of the Liberal and National parties. Regrettably though, other key elements of the coalition's migration policy-elements which reflect very much the views of the FitzGerald report-have been rejected by the Government. For example, reading from the executive summary of the immigration and ethnic affairs policy of the Liberal and National parties we see that we, as a coalition, have committed ourselves to increase Australia's migration intake. The figures that we have in mind, although they cannot be determined too far in advance, would be much more in line with the recommendations and views in the FitzGerald report than with what the Government announced in its statement today.

As I have said, we would `place greater emphasis on the recognition of skills and qualifications of settlers'. The Government has greatly downgraded the recommendations of the FitzGerald Committee in that regard. A related point in our policy is to `assess the individual's suitability as a migrant according to the contribution that person can make to the current and future needs of Australia'. Again, I believe that the Government has downgraded the importance of that point.

I welcome the recognition that the Minister has given in his statement to the key tenet of the coalition's immigration philosophy, namely, to use the Minister's words, `that immigration should be for all Australians', and that, `those born in Australia and those who migrate to Australia are equally accorded their rights'. Again, to quote the Minister, migrants should `bring a commitment to Australia and to its basic values and institutions which attracted them to migrate'. To give just one more quote from the Minister's statement, he speaks of `an overriding and unifying commitment to Australia'.

The Minister has used the term `multiculturalism' to describe these fundamental issues and commitments. Regrettably, not everyone shares that definition of the word. The FitzGerald report made that clear and so has the coalition. The coalition would go further, though, and say that this Government has pursued its concept of multiculturalism in a way that has not unified; rather, it has divided the nation. In essence, that is what this debate on so-called multiculturalism has been all about. Tonight is not the occasion to go into a debate on that. But the essence of that debate rests on the policies of this Government and the application of those policies, including, for example, the use of grants of money to buy the votes of different ethnic communities in a way that is divisive amongst those communities and within those communities. In my view that is a disgrace and one of the great blots on this Government's policy in the immigration area.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question; it is grubby Labor Party politicking.

—That is absolutely right, Senator Stone. In essence, the fine words of the Minister today amounted to a ringing endorsement of what the coalition and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) have been saying about the ideal of one Australia. It amazes me that the Government appears not to be able to see that what it is saying, as distinct from what it is doing, is absolutely in line with the philosophy of one Australia, as outlined by the official policy documents of the coalition and by Mr Howard. I quote from our policy:

SPEECH.PARA: The next Liberal National Party Government will foster the ideal of One Australia where loyalty to Australia, our institutions and our values transcends loyalty to any other sets of values anywhere in the world.

All the policies of the Liberal and National Parties are based upon respect for the value of each individual. We are totally committed to equal treatment and equal opportunity for all Australians regardless of race, colour, creed or country of origin within the framework of a just and tolerant society.

That is exactly what we are on about when we look at the future of our country. That is very much in line with what the Government seems to be saying. I urge the Government to look at the pursuit of its policies in a way that will accord with that, rather than continue with its present practice of following policies which have, in effect, the opposite result.

In summary, the Opposition is deeply disappointed with the Government's response to the FitzGerald report. The Government has walked away from the major recommendations of the report, which stated that Australia needs an immigration program based on skilled and investing migrants. As the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Alan Cadman, said in a press release today:
The statement today by the Minister does not allay concern but increases the uncertainty for the Australian community and for sponsors and relatives trying to establish how the system will work.
He went on to say-and this is probably the most important point of all:
In-fighting within the Government produced a policy which is almost identical with the existing policy . . .

We all know the problems that the existing policy is causing. The Government has shown today that it lacks the commitment to solve the problems confronting it and Australia in this area. As a result Australia will be the poorer and both intending and existing migrants will continue to lack the confidence and certainty which they rightly deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to make only a few points in this debate. In my view, the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies is very substantial and has added to the store of knowledge for people concerned about immigration to this country. The Government response is very clear and lights the path for the immediate future in that regard. My understanding of the way in which we view immigration in this country-and, of course there are now many earlier migrants who are part of that group in this country which has a view on this matter-is that we share this country with others who are less fortunate than ourselves and that there are those who wish to come to Australia, be part of it and contribute to our society, of which we can all be justly proud. We welcome these people to our hearts.

SPEECH.PARA: Listening to Senator Puplick, I was very concerned to hear him comment on what he saw as the contribution of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to escalating division between Australian nationals and migrants and increasing racial tension in this country. I remind him and other senators that the Prime Minister responded to the FitzGerald report in a way that comforted and gave a guarantee to people of all races in this country that they had a right to be here, that we could all live together peacefully and could all contribute to the future of this country for the sake of our children and their children.

Senator Short said that business migration had not been affected by the so-called debate about restricting the level of Asian migration. I was interested to hear him refer to someone in Hong Kong who is making a lot of money by recommending certain business migrants. I agreed wholeheartedly with this recommendation in the FitzGerald report:
That for business immigrants the grant of Australian citizenship be contingent on provision of proof of a business venture having been set up.

My view is that enough people in this country exploit workers without our inviting people with even more expertise in this area to do so. However, I am not suggesting that we should not have any business migrants.

Recently I visited South East Asia as a member of a parliamentary delegation comprising politicians from different political parties. I felt very keenly the resentment of people in those countries to the sort of comments made by John Stone and John Howard on behalf of the Opposition, which denigrate the position of Asians and their right to migrate to this country. Indeed, that question was raised by a number of Filipino senators, including the Vice-President. My response was that the Prime Minister has said very clearly in a public statement that never again should any person be judged, for immigration purposes, by the colour of his skin or his country of origin. Afterwards, in private discussions, several of those people thanked me for making that statement. I suggested that Bob Hawke's stature in those countries and in this country is high, compared to that of the Liberal Party and its leader.
We hear a lot of talk about skilled migrants. The response tabled by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) stated:
These economic migrants, through the skills, capital and expertise they bring, actually create more jobs than they take and make a very positive contribution to our economic development.

The fifth page of the original text of the response refers to a figure of 71,000 in the family category and 54,000 in the economic category. My experience, which is based on discussions with people, not on research published in books, is that while many migrants are skilled, there has been a lot of training of Australian workers. How many of those people are using those skills today? The figure, at best, is probably 66 per cent. There is no shortage of skilled people in this country, but skilled people are not prepared to work in those skilled positions because of the lousy pay, based on the suppression of wages over many years by Liberal-National Party governments.

It used to be said that we needed skilled migrants because we could not train our workers quickly enough. That was being said in 1950, in 1955 and in 1960. It has been said for years and years that we need skilled migrants, but what have we done about training our workers in this country? What have we done to provide the necessary level of reward for those people so that they stay in their jobs? I assure the Senate that not very much has been done.

In recent times some obstacles have been removed. Employers and trade unions are now looking at ways in which people can have a career path. No longer does a young person have to serve an apprenticeship or be a trainee. No longer does a person miss out if he does not undertake such training. Now we are looking at situations where all sorts skilled and unskilled people can be trained to obtain higher skills. What we need to do is to train the people who are already in this country. Many of those people are migrants and the sons and daughters of migrants. That is why the decision to allow a larger intake in respect of family reunions is correct.

Maybe some of those people who do not have the skills we need will be trained and become skilled in this country. That is why I believe that the response of the Minister is correct. We need to go down that path and train the people we have here. After all, we still have hundreds of thousands of unemployed people even though this Government has provided more than a million jobs. This is something that the previous Liberal-National Party Government could not do. In fact, prior to its dismissal from office it was responsible for the loss of some 200,000 jobs. What we need to do is train people in this country to undertake jobs and make our society even richer and better than it is now. People are welcome to come here and make a contribution. They will enrich this society in a way that people who enter this country only because they have skills will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concern which has been expressed about families by both Government and Opposition senators and, specifically, by Senator Puplick, would ring rather more true if yesterday, when the Australian Democrats had sought to remove the taxes on soya milk and computers for handicapped children, the Government and Opposition had voted not to retain those taxes. If they had seen that these were genuine attempts to improve the lot of families who were in some difficulty, we would take their crocodile tears over the family rather more seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made the point before that one of the reasons that the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies and what has flowed from it fails and will continue to fail, is that before one can properly decide on an immigration policy one has to decide on a population policy. A population policy is fundamental to a country. Once one has determined a population policy, one then determines to what extent one wants that population filled by one's own people by natural procreative activity and to what extent one wants it filled by immigration. Australia has developed no population policy whatsoever and it is about time that it did.

Before I was elected to this place and the inquiry into immigration was first mooted, I wrote to both the Minister responsible for immigration and the Minister responsible for the environment, pointing out that it was fundamental to a consideration of the immigration question that population be a matter for consideration and that a proper person to consider the relationship between a population and its environment-and that is what we are talking about in the long term in Australia-would be a biologist. I suggested that a biologist, a person who knows about the relationship between populations and the environment, should be a member of that Committee. I also suggested that a demographer should be on that Committee. I would have thought that it was absolutely essential that a demographer be on a committee that was looking at immigration.

Not only did I get a negative response from both of those Ministers, but they said that it was not necessary to have such people on that Committee. A point that I have made in other debates in relation to science education and funding in this country is appropriate in this instance-that is, that this Government is so ignorant on these matters that it does not know when it requires help and where to get it. In respect of the biological inadequacy of the FitzGerald report, point 9 (iii) in the matrix presented to us today states:
Immigration policies will be determined by Australia's national interests . . . and strategies for Australia's social, economic and cultural development.

There is no mention of the relationship between the population and the ability of the Australian environment to support that population. A Mr Chris Watson, who comes from the city and is very concerned about these matters of population, wrote to Dr Theophanous drawing to his attention the excellent recent publication How Many Australians?. This is a source book containing a number of essays which deal with the relationship between a population and the ability of the environment to continue supporting that population in the long run. Dr Theophanous wrote back to Mr Chris Watson pointing out what he thought of this book. He said:
. . . I consider that work to be entirely erroneous and in some cases missing the whole point of what is possible in Australia.
He totally rejected consideration of those matters. He used the smear tactic which has been used so often when one has attempted to raise this debate. In his final paragraph Dr Theophanous said:

While I am sure that you put forward your arguments in good faith, you should be aware that these kinds of arguments are being misused by people whose motives in opposition to immigration, are extremely dubious.

That is perfectly true. There are people who are using these arguments for dubious purposes but that should not be a reason why these matters of population and the ability of the country to maintain a population in the long run should not be raised. For the edification of Dr Theophanous and the edification of other senators in relation to what the population in this country has done to this country in 200 short years, I point out that 19 vertebrate species are extinct; 74 other vertebrate species are endangered; 10 per cent of the plants of this whole continent are endangered-that is, 2,200 species-and 78 species of plants have become extinct. We have lost half of the topsoil of this country, two-thirds of our temperate forest has gone, and a study on land degradation which has been referred to repeatedly in this place shows that over 60 per cent of the land area in Australia is in need of some restorative work at a cost in 1984 dollars of $1.6 billion. Yet we can find only $122m per year to spend on that work. It is quite clear that the population that we already have in this country, given the way it is using the environment, is seriously degrading the ability of that environment to go on supporting that population in the long run.

Many people are bemused-`bemused' is the appropriate word-when they look at a map of Australia and say that it is a large country. Only about 10 per cent of the Australian landscape is arable land. That is the land in which people want to live; the land in which we support people by growing crops and producing food. Australia is quite a small country when one looks at its resource base. As I have already indicated, we have seriously depleted that resource base already.

It follows that the Democrats would support a much reduced immigration policy, and I want to develop that line. Having said that, I want to make it quite clear-I was apparently misunderstood by Senator Harradine when I developed these arguments earlier-that the selection of migrants who come to this country would be, in our policy, on a totally non-racist and non-ethnic basis. There would be no selection on criteria of race or ethnic origin. In relation to race I point out that the cover of the booklet tabled today entitled Information: The Department of Immigration has at the top right hand corner the phrase `200 years of immigration'. I would simply like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the immigration policy in this country is a continuation of the process of disruption and dispossession of the Aboriginal people of this country.

Several weeks ago I asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) whether the Aboriginal people of Australia had ever been asked whether they supported an immigration policy for Australia. The answer was, `Well, the Aboriginal people could have come to the FitzGerald inquiry and given evidence'. Anybody who knows anything about Aboriginal people knows that it is extremely difficult for them to do that. Those Aboriginal people I have asked about our immigration policy have made it quite clear that they do not support an immigration policy in Australia. They see migrants coming in as being a very advantaged group with respect to what they get in support. If one looks through the program which is outlined before us, one sees that extra help is given in skill training, extra help is given with the English language and so on and so forth. Bearing in mind that in this country we have some of the most disadvantaged people in the world, namely our own Aboriginal people, it is help we should be directing more properly towards those people who occupied this country for some 40,000 years.

In that connection I was interested to pick up the Brisbane Courier-Mail today. The heading on the front page reads, `Cook may have made a right royal mistake, says Judge'. Mr Denis Walker, before a court in Brisbane, pleaded that Cook overstepped the charter given to him by King George III in taking possession of the continent without the consent of the Aboriginal people. As we all know, the assumption on which this country has operated for the last 200 years is one of terra nullius; that is, the country was unoccupied. I guess on that basis we can continue to bring in migrants. But I suggest that if the Government is at all serious about recognising Aboriginal land rights-it was the first motion it put through in the Senate when we moved into this new chamber and recognised prior Aboriginal occupation and ownership of Australia and dispossession without compensation-logically it follows that if we are to have an immigration program at all, we should be going to the Aboriginal people and asking them whether they want more people to come in and further dispossess them of further land and advantages.

I do not think it is generally recognised by the community that although Australia's natural rate of reproduction has fallen below one-that is, below replacement; for a family that rate is 1.87 which is a little bit less than two-the population rate will not fall. There is a long lag built into population shifts. Without any immigration whatsoever the population of this country will go on increasing, and will increase by about another 3.1 million by the year 2,030. If the net reproduction rate continued to be below replacement then it would go into slow decline but would not fall back to 16 million people until about 100 years from now. So the claim that we need immigration to occupy this land is simply without foundation. That is something that any demographer could have told FitzGerald or anybody else who is commenting on it.

Another matter which has often been asserted-I think it was mentioned this afternoon or in this evening's debate-is that migrants somehow help the ageing of the population. The dependency rate has shifted by only about two percentage points because of immigration. I noticed that Senator Baume mentioned the importation of skills. I find it remarkable that we have had an immigration program since 1947 and some people can still claim that we need to bring in more people because we lack skills. That is a very serious indictment of the educational process of this country. It is a serious indictment of those industries, which are supported by members of the Opposition, which have failed to train adequately the people needed in those industries. If the best argument we can bring for an immigration program is that we need more skills, people should be getting off their backsides and ensuring that we have a much better education and training program.

The history of immigration in this country has been one in which we have brought people in not for their benefit but ours. One has only to go back to those early years, from 1947 through the 1950s, to remember the `populate or perish' argument and the threat of the yellow hordes coming down to take over this country. We did not bring people into this country for their benefit; we brought people in because we thought we needed numbers for the defence of the country. We also wanted people to be labourers. I remember people who later on became my university colleagues and who came out with medical degrees who were working as fettlers on the transcontinental railway line. Women with science degrees were washing factory floors. So let us not kid ourselves that we have a good record with respect to benefiting migrants; we do not have a very good record at all. We should be doing more to help those migrants who have come into the country. The emphasis should be on helping them rather than on the way in which they can help us. That also comes out of a smaller, more humanitarian targeted program.

One of the other things that has to be said is that 80 per cent of the population increase in Australia since the early years of migration has accrued to capital cities. That includes both the natural increase and the increase brought about by migration. During that time the population in all the capital cities has at least doubled. Some have gone up by 2 1/2 times. The projected rate of population growth dependent upon the immigration targets which are mentioned in the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies and in the statement that is before us-there is not much difference between the figures; only about 10,000-would see all Australian cities double in size again by some time in the 2020s. Several people have remarked that surveys of the Australian population indicate that the majority of Australians are either opposed totally to a migration program or are opposed to an increased migration program and favour a much smaller program. I think their perceptions are correct. They see cities becoming larger, more inhuman, more polluted, and dirtier. They see people having to travel further to work and having to spend more on houses because population pressure impacts on the cost of housing. Their perception is that the migration program is making them worse off. I think that perception is real. Unless this Federal Government does something to help the States address the problem of infrastructure costs, the quality of life in our cities will simply deteriorate. That is quite clear.

The South Australian Government, in its submission to the FitzGerald inquiry, said that in the five years between 1985 and 1990 the maintenance of infrastructure in Adelaide would cost $800m. In the five years, 1995 to 2000, only 10 years further on, it said that the infrastructure costs will be $3 billion. That will be the total amount of money needed for the maintenance of infrastructure in Adelaide-leaving no money whatsoever for the expansion of infrastructure which will be required if we continue to pursue population increase as a policy. It follows, quite clearly, that the quality of life in our cities will deteriorate if we continue down this road.

To simply take some vague economic target and say that that is going to be achieved by more people coming in is simply a falsity. There is no evidence whatsoever that migration has improved the economic lot of Australia. There are a number of countries with both small and large populations, but with relatively stable populations that have done economically much better than Australia. That is not to deny that the cultural life of Australia has been enriched, but that is a different argument.

In relation to refugees, the Democrats believe that they should be dealt with as a separate category, which is not included in the immigration program. Refugees are not necessarily immigrants. They are very often people who are seeking asylum from political and other persecution. Some of them may eventually settle; some may want temporary asylum and then want to go back to their own country. The Democrats believe, as Senator Jenkins said earlier, that Australia could substantially increase its refugees intake bearing that in mind. The Democrats believe that that should be done for humanitarian reasons.

Turning now to the business migration program, one need only reflect on the fact that those with half a million dollars who are leaving their own country have no great commitment to the country in which they made that half a million dollars. To those who say that if our business migration program is not freed up those people will go to Canada, South America, Germany or somewhere else, I simply say that if their commitment to Australia is so strong that they will simply take their money somewhere else, are they the sort of people one wants in this country? I am reminded of a program I saw several years ago on Argentina, which had attracted a large number of immigrants from Europe in the 1920s. Those people had settled; they had never become Argentineans; they still regarded themselves as Germans, Italians or whatever; they were third generation people, still intending to go back and still repatriating money back. One need only look at the economic plight of Argentina and reflect on whether in the long run those people have been beneficial to the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They built the country up. What are you talking about? Otherwise they would have been back to where they were long before that.

—It has already been said today that roughly one million people who have come into this country have not become Australian citizens. That is a cause for concern that the Opposition has highlighted. I would express that concern as well. The Government has also drawn attention to that.

SPEECH.PARA: To reflect briefly on the plight of two of the capital cities-because I think it is worth running through these figures-Adelaide is pressing very hard against one vital resource and that is water. In recent weeks a plan has been put forward by the Minister for Water Resources in Western Australia that a pipeline be built from the Ord Dam in the extreme north-east corner of Western Australia all the way down to Adelaide and Perth to maintain a growing population. The figures that have been mooted for that pipeline are $8 billion capital cost. One need only do back of envelope calculations on the interest and amortisation of $8 billion to work out that it would cost some $4,000 per family per year simply to maintain the pipeline before any water was even pumped through it to realise how ridiculous that is. Yet that is the sort of scheme that is being looked at due to the fact that the population is being pushed up against a limited resource base.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do when you run out of water in the south-west and south of Australia?

—Our population should not go on increasing. That is what should be done. The population should be brought into balance with the ability of the environment to continue endlessly supporting that population. That is what we do. That does not mean a very large migration program, the economic benefits of which have never been established. I stress that one of the reasons why FitzGerald laid emphasis on the business migration program is that, unless one has a large business migration program-in other words, unless the predominance of migrants who come in are wealthy-there is no economic benefit at all from migration.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, if one goes down the line which the Government is going, there will be a net loss from that migration program. Bearing that in mind, I suggest that we should have a smaller migration program and that it should be targeted towards humanitarian needs. We should separate off the refugees. We should have a larger refugee component and I stress again that it should be on a non-racist, non-ethnic selection basis. That is the basic difference between the Australian Democrats' approach to this question and the approach which the Government and the Opposition are taking. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 December, on motion by Senator Foreman:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. As a member of that Committee who wrote a dissenting report, it is worth my going through some of the evidence given and the reasons for that dissenting report. The report is entitled The Adequacy of International Terminal and Aircraft Handling Facilities at Sydney Airport. It is important to realise that the reason for the reference was the known congestion at Sydney which was forecast to become much worse. That is the reason the Standing Committee took on this reference. Anyone who goes through that airport, as I do twice a week, will know that it is unusual to get a straight run into Sydney. Those of us who come from the north have a very clear knowledge of the area around the Hunter Valley because that is where we circle for up to half an hour simply coming into Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact of life that Sydney is the gateway to Australia; the majority of tourists wish to enter or exit through Sydney. People from other States may question why tourists want to do that, but it is a fact. To a tourist Sydney is to Australia what we perceive London to be to the United Kingdom, Rome to Italy or Paris to France. Hence the vast majority of tourists at some time or another want to go through Sydney. To add to the congestion, Sydney is the domestic hub for air traffic around Australia. Therefore, congestion at Sydney is not only a big threat to the growth of tourism but can and does seriously dislocate domestic airlines all around Australia. In fact, the hold-ups that occur fairly regularly at Sydney between 6 and 8 a.m. have a ripple effect on every schedule right around the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is worse on a wet day.

—Yes, it is much worse on a wet day, but I am talking about normal congestion even in good times. Someone said to me the other day, `I cannot believe it. I got on a plane at Cairns and I was told that the reason we were delayed was congestion at Sydney Airport'. The pilot told all the passengers, as pilots do interminably, whether we are coming into Sydney or leaving Sydney, that the congestion at Sydney Airport was causing lots of problems. The delay at Cairns was caused by the early congestion in Sydney in the peak period between 6 a.m. and 8 a.m. There are two major problems. One is the lack of runway capacity, which adversely affects both international and domestic flights. The second problem is that the international terminal itself has had a major effect on the international flights and, hence, tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: International passenger movements between 1977 and 1987-just 10 years-have increased, including the transit passengers, from 2.3 million to 4.4 million people, just through the international terminal. It is estimated by various authorities that by 1995 the number of international passenger movements through Sydney will be between 6 million and 8 million-depending on the sort of forecast that has been made and who did it. It is generally conceded that those figures may be too low and that the figure may be between 7 million and 10 million.

As I mentioned earlier, Sydney is also the hub for domestic flights and, because of the decentralised nature of New South Wales, is a major commuter centre. It currently has about 30,000 commuter movements in and out of Kingsford-Smith Airport--

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty thousand what?
—Thirty thousand passengers.
—Over what time period?

—Twelve months. In fact, it is 30,000 `commuter movements'; not passengers.
