Everyone on the Committee, from the extensive evidence given, would agree with this summary which is documented in a more detailed fashion in the report. I do not intend to go into those details. We all know the problem. The question is: Which is the most sensible decision? Which is the most sensible solution? That is what our job should be. That is the reason for these standing committees; that is the reason we look at references. We are not supposed to go in there with preconceived ideas. We are supposed to go in, listen to the evidence, and make a reasoned judgment at the end, and not make a judgment which is based on some political decision. I make that point because I believe that the majority report is not based on the evidence. Submissions made were varied from one extreme to the other: from the total closure of Kingsford-Smith Airport to the immediate construction of Badgerys Creek. I wonder whether those people on the other side, including Minister Evans, before they decided to go ahead with this, discussed it with Senator Walsh. Did they ask Senator Walsh whether he would commit, in today's dollars, some $2 billion? No matter how we lag it, that is the sort of figure we are looking at if we start to move to Badgerys Creek.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the submissions made varied from one extreme to the other. One was the total closure of Kingsford-Smith Airport by members of a particular action group who had purchased their homes under a flight path. They were hoping that if Kingsford-Smith Airport were moved they would have some very valuable real estate. I can understand their thinking, but they did, after all, purchase under a flight path. Neither the Committee nor, I understand, this Government would contemplate the closure of Kingsford-Smith Airport. That is quite clear. In fact, from some of the evidence given, the Botany Council did not suggest the closure of Kingsford-Smith Airport. I make this very clear because the politics of it are such that there are some who would go around badgering local areas saying, `What we want to do is close Kingsford-Smith Airport and if you don't, we will use our political pull to make sure that you have difficulties in the next election, whether it be State or Federal'. But even the Botany Council said, `We have no intention of closing. We don't want you to close Kingsford-Smith Airport'. The reason it does not want it to be closed is that most people who live there either work in the airport or in some area associated with the airport.

The majority recommendation in principle on the airport is reflected in paragraph 6.7 and paragraph 6.8. I will read these paragraphs out because they explain the reason the majority came to that conclusion. It had nothing to do with the evidence. Paragraph 6.7 states:

The then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator the Honourable Gareth Evans, QC, on 19 August 1988, announced a commitment to proceed with a second airport for Sydney located at Badgerys Creek. In addition, the Public Works Committee also recommended extensive improvements to Sydney Airport totalling $214m in cost be undertaken. These initiatives prompt the Committee-
I am talking about the majority of the Committee, who were all Labor senators-
to conclude that a decision to have concurrently built an additional runway would have been premature and not cost effective.
Having said that, the next paragraph, paragraph 6.8, states-and how woolly can one get?:

However in reaching that conclusion it is not the Committee's intention to dismiss the additional runway option for all time. It may well be that after the planned arrangements and developments at Sydney Airport are in place and the airport at Badgerys Creek is operational, air traffic could reach such levels that it will be necessary to again assess the need for an additional runway at Sydney Airport.

This recommendation is the reason for our dissenting report. In this case, the majority has put the cart in front of the horse. It makes sense to everyone, on the evidence given to us, that step one is to start looking at the construction of a third runway parallel with the existing runway into Botany Bay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Immediately.

—I will come to that. We believe that the cost of construction of Badgerys Creek, bearing in mind all the infrastructure associated with it, whether it be freeways, fast trains or whatever, would have to be in excess of $2 billion in today's dollar terms. To then state that it is not the Committee's intention to dismiss the additional runway is, as I said earlier, putting the cart before the horse.

SPEECH.PARA: Sydney Airport is in crisis. Already delays are directly costing the airlines, and thus the passengers, a figure estimated to be in excess of $20m a year. I believe that that is a conservative figure. The figure given to us by Australian Airlines alone in direct costs-fuel being used while planes circle in patterns waiting to land and so on-was about $8.5m. So a conservative estimate would be about $20m a year. The indirect cost in delays and missed connecting flights is anybody's guess. This is a serious matter and a serious decision has to be made by this Government. It is time to stop playing politics and start playing government.

Our conclusions are, firstly, that notwithstanding improvements to the international terminal, an additional new terminal will be required. The user airline indicated in evidence its interest in building and operating such a new terminal. It should be given the opportunity to do so. Secondly, a third medium-spaced 2,000 metre runway should be constructed, located approximately 1.050 metres east of the main north-south runway into Botany Bay. This would take aircraft of up to Boeing 737 size and is estimated to increase Sydney's traffic handling capacity by 40 per cent. It would be expected to take all the commuter and general aviation aircraft. It should also be borne in mind that it would reduce the environmental effects on the people in the area. That has been forgotten. A third runway would halve the noise problems of people living in the area because, in the main, aircraft would take off and land over Botany Bay.

I have said that this third runway must be started, and it must be started immediately. Time should be the essence of the contract. Figures have been given which I disagree with, on the basis of my experience in construction. I do not believe in the time factor. I would be absolutely surprised if a third runway parallel to the existing one into Botany Bay could not be completed in two years. In regard to planning, I suppose that consideration of Badgerys Creek as a site for a second airport should continue. However, one should always bear in mind that the forecasts which we are making today, which I believe are conservative, are only forecasts and that things change; technology changes.

It is worth drawing honourable senators' attention to an advertisement placed in last Saturday's Australian by a group of people calling themselves the KSA Task Force. I do not know them; I have had no contact with them. The headline of their full page advertisement read, in part, `You won't mind paying $120 for a taxi'. If the Government decides to go ahead at Badgerys Creek without taking the option of immediately building a third runway at the existing airport, that is what people will be paying. Experts in this field had no hesitation in telling the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in private discussions that to go ahead at this stage with Badgerys Creek would be a disaster. Their reason was that until there is a full-blown airport and internationals can be hooked up with domestics and commuters, there will be absolute chaos. A person flying from Brisbane to Sydney or from Melbourne to Sydney to hook up with an international flight would end up paying $150 to get from Kingsford-Smith to the international airport or vice versa. An article entitled `Abusive Pilots ``Risk to Safety'' ' on the front page of yesterday's Sydney Daily Telegraph supports the evidence which the Committee received and the conclusions it has come to. The article states:
The frustrated pilots often have to circle Sydney for more than an hour waiting for permission to land.
Sydney is the gateway to Australia. It continues:
With congestion at Sydney Airport getting worse, aviation authorities fear flight controllers could crack under the strain.

So it goes on. Pilots get frustrated, abuse the air traffic controllers and try to jump their slot in the queue. That sort of thing is inevitable. It is my sincere belief that, if all members of the Committee had based their final recommendation on the evidence given, every single one would have supported the minority report. Unfortunately, politics are involved. Labor senators were concerned that if they came down with such a report it would somehow affect their chances in the next election, either Federal or State. I can accept that in a democracy those sorts of things must be taken on board but, frankly, I could not see the political backlash because everyone would be in agreement with it. Decisions have to be made. As I said earlier, it is about time, on such an important decision, that this Government started to play at government rather than at politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I must do in speaking to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled The Adequacy of International Terminal and Aircraft Handling Facilities at Sydney Airport is to stress the present state of affairs at that airport. There are huge inefficiencies there and they are important not solely to Sydney, and least of all to New South Wales; they are of national importance. As Senator Parer said, the cost of this has not been measured but it is probably well in excess of $20m a year. A point to make about that is that this matter has not arisen in the last 12 months or two years: the cost of the airport to the Australian economy has been building up year after year for at least a decade.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point to make is that the majority report is a very poor report. It is one of the worst Senate reports I have ever seen. It is lightweight and inconsequential. The report of the minority is a good report. It adopts a commonsense approach to the problem, but it suffers from the general deficiencies that went into the main report. The main report is just a hand-wringing exercise. On every page the report acknowledges the problem, but it is devoid of any analysis in depth as to how the problem arose. It is quite devoid of any creative thought as to how it should be addressed and there are almost no conclusions or recommendations in the majority report. It does recommend that a monitoring system be put in place so that we know how bad things are-that in itself will not solve the problem. It does recommend proceeding with the terminal, and that is already in train. And it does comes down quite strongly in favour of the new airport. While Sydney must have another primary airport, a new airport is the lesser priority at present. As Senator Parer said, it is back to front. Basically, the majority of members on that Committee did not grasp the nettle. My argument is that the problem has to be attacked; we cannot pretend that it does not exist.

What are the causes of the problem? The problem is in two forms: first of all, there are considerable and significant delays to aircraft using Sydney Airport; and, secondly, the international terminal lacks space and capacity for the crowds that are going through it. The consequences of these are also twofold: firstly, there is the economic cost; and, secondly, there is the emotional cost. We are trying to build up a tourist industry in this country. Apart from international tourists we have a great number of Australian travellers going through Sydney. The emotional trauma of the delays of the international and other traffic coming through the terminal is a very bad advertisement for Australia. Those delays in themselves have an economic cost.

Most members of this Parliament fly through Sydney twice a week and we know very well what problems are being experienced. For years now, coming down from Brisbane on the first flight in the morning, there has been a standard 20-minute hold at the back of Newcastle before entry into Sydney Airport. Two weeks ago when I was coming down the delay was in excess of one hour. It is almost unbelievable. We were actually longer in the holding pattern than it took us on block time from Brisbane to Sydney. That sort of nonsense simply cannot be tolerated because it is costing the person who buys the ticket a fortune. It means that those aircraft holding for 20 minutes or an hour on entry are burning a lot more fuel than they should burn on the sector. There is the dead time on the air frame and the engines because those components are lifed and their period in service is on a number of flying hours; there is dead time just holding in a pattern; and there is the dead time of the crew just holding in the orbit.

The estimate that Australian Airlines gave this Committee was that it was costing it $8.5m a year, and I believe that to be a conservative estimate. I believe that the same figure would be borne by Ansett Airlines of Australia. With secondary costs arising from this, a figure of $20m to $30m a year is not an unreal estimate of what it is costing Australian travellers. I emphasise that that $20m or $30m is a straight transfer to the cost of an airline ticket in Australia. It is not transferred to the Government; it is not transferred to anyone else; it must be a cost borne by the airlines and, as they must make a profit, that cost is transferred on to the travellers. That is only one reason air fares in Australia are so high.

The bad feature of this is that Sydney happens to be the main entry point for overseas traffic into Australia. For internal traffic-there is really no logic for this-nearly all Australian domestic services hub through Sydney; in other words, nearly all the trunk routes land and take off from Sydney. Whether one is going from Perth to Cairns or from Brisbane to Adelaide the services go through Sydney. There are very few direct flights.

What are the causes of these delays? First of all, the runway system is inadequate. We simply do not have enough runways. There must be a third minor runway to take the commuter traffic and the smaller, regular public transport aircraft. The point that is not appreciated by the protesters around Sydney Airport is that, by putting in a third runway to take the lighter traffic, this will not mean an increase in the traffic per day. It will mean that there is more traffic coming in per hour, but the number of movements per day, and therefore the amount of noise generated, will not be any greater. In fact it may well be that the noise intensity will be dispersed in so far as the approach and departure paths for the third runway will be a different pattern from those of the runways presently in use.

We also need to look at the air traffic control procedures at Sydney airport. This report gives a maximum movement figure for Sydney airport of 54 movements per hour. That means that there is more one minute separation of traffic arriving and departing. That is a very generous standard, as I am sure Senator Sanders will agree, having been an air traffic controller. In good weather it is quite possible to close up those standards, bearing in mind that there are two runways that can be used, and still maintain safety. A couple of weekends ago I was talking to a friend of mine from New South Wales who had been flying in the United States a few months back. He was flying a Cessna 140, a very old and slow aeroplane, into Sacramento Airport. Sacramento is the capital of California and its airport is quite large. I have flown into that airport and I would say it is probably comparable with Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in terms of the traffic going through it. The control tower told my friend that he had three miles to run, which meant that he was three miles from the threshold on his approach and that he was number 13 to land. I emphasise that he was number 13 with three miles to run. In Australia there would be no one ahead of him if he had three miles to run to the threshold. I believe that the air traffic control procedures that we operate at Sydney airport are, in most cases, too generous and that they could be closed up without compromising safety in any way at all.

Certainly, an improvement might be needed in radar and navigational aids at Sydney Airport. One of the great disabilities from which Sydney suffers is the maintainability of instrument landing systems (ILS) in bad weather. I came through Sydney earlier this year and I think that only one ILS was working. That puts an enormous brake on traffic. There is no excuse for that. The maintenance of the Civil Aviation Authority, as it was at that time, was not good enough to maintain all the navigation aids in an operable state. We cannot tolerate that sort of thing. Sydney is a first class airport and the air traffic control procedures must be good enough to maintain full serviceability, whatever the weather.

A short while ago Senator Hamer asked what should be done about all those small aeroplanes-the single-engined aircraft and the commuters-using Sydney Airport. One of the things we could do is to follow the American pattern and hold those aircraft over the field. That is the safest place in the air traffic pattern because almost no-one overflies an airport such as Sydney (Kingsford-Smith). Aircraft are either landing or taking off and if light twin-engined aircraft and single-engined aircraft were held in a stack directly over the field in good weather-and this could be done with perfect safety-it would be preferable to bringing them in from a stack 30 miles out when they would have to come in at low speed and fit in with high speed jet traffic. This means that separation has need to be very much greater. If the simple exercise were taken of holding those aircraft directly overhead, they could be slotted in when breaks arose in the heavier traffic, provided wake turbulence was not a problem at the time.

I suggest that a major onslaught needs to be made on scheduling at Sydney Airport. International traffic should be moved away from its heavy dependence on Sydney as an entry point to Australia. Indeed, it is not at all logical for traffic coming from the north Pacific, the United States, Asia and Europe. The obvious point of entry is Perth in the west and Brisbane on the east coast. In Brisbane we have an excellent air field which, in many ways, is better than Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) and an increasing number of tourists want to go to places such as the Great Barrier Reef, north Queensland and Ayers Rock. Positive efforts should be made to encourage the asset which the Australian taxpayers have created in the form of the new Brisbane Airport and to use that as a point of entry.

One thing that should be done is to reschedule an increasing number of direct flights between Brisbane and Adelaide, Melbourne and Brisbane, and from Perth to other centres, so that every flight is not automatically directed through Sydney. The second thing that needs to be done, apart from rescheduling, is to provide a third runway, and do so expeditiously. There is no reason why that could not be finished in about 18 months or two years. The third thing we need to do is to attend to those air traffic control problems, and increase the flow rate through the airfield. That is possible, given a bit of intelligent planning.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the rub.

—As Senator Sanders said, it might be quite beyond the Civil Aviation Authority to do some intelligent planning. The final thing we ought to do is to plan for an alternative airport for Sydney. Probably, `alternative' is the wrong word. We need a supplementary primary airport. I do not know the area terribly well, but I do not see why Hoxton Park could not be developed as the alternative airport site. It seems to me that the planners, the bureaucracy, always want to develop virgin fields which have no houses. The fact is that it costs a great deal of money to build a major airport. If one has to spend a few more tens of millions of dollars in buying some houses in an area-provided that they are not houses like those in Bellevue Hill and Double Bay in Sydney-that is a cost that one must consider paying.

SPEECH.PARA: I am told that the taxi fare at present to Badgerys Creek is about $120. Probably, by the time the airport is built, if it goes ahead in 10 to 15 years time, the fare would be $300 or $400. It is quite impractical for an airport to be so far out of town. It should be closer to the city. It is a matter of utility. Human beings use these facilities. They will not spend an hour in a plane, travelling from Melbourne or Brisbane to Sydney, and then two or three hours in a car, trying to get into the city. I am very much in favour of looking at an alternative site to Badgerys Creek. The Government should be prepared to pay money to resume houses and, having resumed those houses, it should place a corridor around the area and limit development purely to industrial development, so that there is not a repeat of the situation at Tullamarine in Melbourne. Residential accommodation is that suburb has been built close to the airport. It is creating a problem in an area which formerly consisted of green fields.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The all-too-obvious unwillingness of the Hawke Labor Government to tackle the capacity crisis and its associated problems at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport indicates quite clearly, even to the most casual observer, that this Government is utterly out of touch with the operations of the country's aviation industry. One of the more debilitating features of this Government's modus operandi in recent times has been its total lack of enthusiasm actually to make a decision about the disgraceful situation currently being experienced at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Kingsford-Smith Airport is a jumbled mess that currently masquerades as this country's premier international airport. People queue from the moment they arrive. Some even unluckier passenger queue before they arrive; it is known as a holding pattern.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport has now been tabled, along with the minority report by Senator Parer, Senator Boswell and me. The majority report simply reflects the unwillingness of the Australian Labor Party to take the required action. It mirrors the report of the joint Commonwealth-New South Wales Government task force released some weeks ago which, despite the strong support from the New South Wales Government for a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport, prefers the option of the development of a second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek. This is Labor's idea of Future Directions-100 kilometres west of Sydney.

These reports demonstrate that the Labor Party has false priorities. The construction of a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport should be an urgent priority. That is the conclusion of our minority report. It is based firmly on the evidence presented to the Committee and contained in the majority report. It is an urgent priority. But what is an urgent priority to this Government? It means no action and no decision. Instead, the Government ignores the advice of its own experts in both the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. The majority report of the Government members of the Committee ignores the weight of evidence we received.

How much longer can the Hawke Labor Government sit on the fence and ponder its collective navel while the air transport and tourism industries languish in a curry of chaos? The only logical option is to optimise Sydney Airport now, not in 15 years-the time we are told it will take to complete an airport at Badgerys Creek-but now, in Sydney at Kingsford-Smith Airport, where almost three-quarters of domestic flights are late, where Qantas Airways Ltd admits that nine-tenths of its flights are late due to an environment of controlled chaos.

By building a third runway, which could probably be built for $250m in three years-I notice that my colleague Senator Parer believes it could be built more cheaply and speedily than that-40 per cent would be added to the airport's current capacity. This move would significantly reduce delays which are now so common and so pronounced. It is a great shame that the future development of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, the hub of Australia's airline network, will suffer because yet again the Hawke Labor Government gives its management of the political agenda much greater priority than the real needs of Australians. Politics, we have found, comes before sound economic management. Now politics comes before a more efficient air transport system. There will be no runway. So much for this Government's oft boasted claim that it is prepared to take the hard unpopular decisions in the nation's interest.

We are witnessing Australia's premier gateway being constrained by the desire of the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) to keep his seat, which just happens to encroach on the environs of Sydney Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely right.

—Senator Baume would know that area very well too. We all know that Mr Punch has a marginal seat but he is sacrificing the future development of the airport and of Australia's transport and tourist industries so that he can remain a member of parliament. What sacrifice! What gall! If honourable senators ask me, the best way to eliminate offensive noise in Barton would be to eliminate Mr Punch. The electors of Barton will recognise that at the next election. They will reject Labor's shortsighted political expediency. Voters Australia-wide will reject this Government, which is more concerned about political expediency and holding seats than with the future of tourism and air transport in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue clearly demonstrates the gulf between the Labor Government and the coalition. On the one hand, we have the political expediency of the Labor Party desperately clinging to marginal seats. On the other hand, despite the obvious advantage to the coalition of winning those same marginal seats, the coalition takes a rational and principled stand. It is rational because it is based on overwhelming evidence. It is principled because it places the needs of the nation above political expediency. That is that stand which Senator Parer, Senator Boswell and I have taken in our minority report.

The Hawke Government ruthlessly dismisses the evidence that a parallel runway should be constructed in a politically motivated decision. It is nothing more than that. It is well accepted throughout the industry that the major constraint on the growth of international and domestic tourism is our Australian transport system. As many of us surely know, Sydney Airport and its facilities are so congested that saturation point is rapidly being reached. A third runway is not a luxury. It is not a little something to sweeten the pot but an urgent necessity. The rejection of this by the majority report is completely without substance and reason.

Airline passengers, both domestic and international, among others have long paid the price for years of this Government's procrastination flowing from a supreme lack of political will. The current mess is damning evidence of incompetence and demonstrates a total lack of foresight and planning in the control of Australia's major airport. The domino theory is alive and well and living at Sydney Airport. Delays in Sydney are transmitted like a social disease right across the country. Like any social disease, the treatment can become expensive. Delays disrupt business life and operations. This in turn adds to costs. They inconvenience holiday-makers, who represent some 40 per cent of domestic travellers. Tourists are upset. It is a great job we do for our international guests too when we stick them in a holding pattern. It is a great way to see the country! It is a miserable way of greeting visitors after both this Government and numerous businesses spend millions of dollars in promoting this country and attracting tourists.

But it does not stop with the holding patterns. Once these visitors actually set foot in our overburdened international terminal, there are a lot more queues in store for them. This Government has an inexhaust- ible supply of such jollies up its sleeve for the unsuspecting international visitor. Airline passengers, both domestic and international, have carried the excess baggage of political ineptitude for far too long. The Government's fragmented approach demonstrates the confusion of having no realistic policy. The airport's operational capacity has not kept pace with the needs of a broad range of industry users. So many unrealistic and inappropriate solutions have been proposed by this Government.

It is no secret that the poor capabilities of Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport did not happen overnight. It has a history, like most things. The inadequacies relate to runway capacity and to the international passenger terminal. That terminal was opened 18 years ago. The newer wide-bodied aircraft, capable of carrying increased numbers of passengers, were introduced while it was nearing completion. It was almost obsolete by opening day. It was immediately unable to cope with the 747s which were bringing greater numbers of tourists to this country. In the last two years that congestion has reached critical proportions. Together with political buck-passing and an exponential growth in tourists to Australia, Sydney Airport is quite clearly, like this Hawke Labor Government-beyond coping. Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport handles 58 per cent of all visitors to Australia. Last year over 3 1/2 million passengers arrived or departed through the airport. It is the preferred entry point for the vast majority of our overseas visitors. Combined with its focus as the prime destination for overseas visitors to Australia, a worldwide leap in passenger movements and air transport has seen Sydney Airport struggle unsuccessfully in coping with this sudden upturn in tourist traffic. Whilst high speed taxiways and the changes made to curfew hours will assist in easing the congestion in Sydney, a third runway is undoubtedly the next step in improving its overall efficiency.

Between January and September this year worldwide airline traffic was 9 per cent higher than in 1987. The International Air Transport Association has forecast a further 5 to 6 per cent annual increase. In simple terms that means that airline traffic will double to 2 billion passenger journeys per year by the year 2000. That is only 11 years away. The Hawke Labor Government wants Australia to wait a further 15 years, from whenever it gets around to building a second airport. In the meantime, the buck never stops and the patching here and there gains momentum until Kingsford-Smith Airport is positively bursting at the seams with aircraft and passengers. To meet this colossal upsurge in tourists and passenger traffic, our national airline, Qantas Airways Ltd, is spending $5 billion to buy 28 aircraft and double the size of its current fleet. Nearly every international airline is doing the same. This year Boeing has orders for 500 jets worth over $25 billion, an absolute all-time high. Airlines around the world will need to expand their fleets by 58 per cent just to cope with this demand. That means that some 11,000 large jet transports will be flying about the skyways.

How will Australia's premier international airport-the gateway to Australia-cope if the majority report is accepted, reinforcing Government inaction? How will it cope not in 11 years but in just four years when in 1992 saturation point is reached? The situation has become ludicrous. It has long been evident that Sydney Airport is a major problem just waiting for a solution. International economic prosperity of recent years has generated more discretionary income for people overseas, including dollars for travel, while an overall decline in air fares has provided a further stimulus to ticket sales.

The number of substantial new airports planned across the globe is only five. That includes the proposed Badgerys Creek airport. A host of massive new airports on greenfield sites, which can be expanded as and when required, free from environmental restrictions, will not happen. It must be accepted that most airports, including Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will require continual improvement. Aircraft production lines are working flat out to meet constant demand for new planes. That is a fact and nothing will change it. What is the point in having a very expensive half-baked airport which cannot be used to its optimum because the Hawke Labor Government is having a relaxing time in the sun, pondering over what decision it might make? It is not the answer to Sydney's problems to build a second airport some time in the future, somewhere out in the countryside, while refusing to build another runway at Sydney Airport to alleviate worsening congestion while that other airport is being built.

Badgerys Creek is another of Labor's world firsts: it is the only airport in the world where one can get a meal and an in-flight movie on one's way to the airport. The fundamental problem has always been the procrastination of this Hawke Government and its inability to decide whether or not a second airport should be built and, if so, where to build it. Delays are costing the two domestic airlines upwards of $15m per year. How many millions must this Government throw away before it makes a decision on this airport? Seventy-seven aircraft arrive or land daily in Sydney. Almost three-quarters are regularly late. Almost one-third are late by more than 10 minutes. And still this Government cannot decide. It wants more time to sit and ponder the issue. Just how much time does it think it has? How much time does it think this country has to respond to an overburdening demand?

Ninety per cent of both major domestic airlines' aircraft pass through Sydney at least once a day. This being the case, can any honourable senators remember the last time the aircraft on which they were travelling arrived or departed from Sydney on time? Such congestion is frightening and diabolical. The Federal Government has contributed to this shameful situation by allowing airline services to expand at the airport, while rejecting extra capacity by refusing to allow another runway. For instance, this year there was a 20 per cent increase. Just where is this to be absorbed?

It is the Government's intention to sit by idly and watch the collapse of the airline system at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The airport's paralysis is wreaking havoc on airlines and, as well, damaging the reputation of our international carrier-Qantas Airways Ltd. The Government also seems content to cost itself and the Australian taxpayers millions of dollars in lost revenue. It is clear that neither airlines, passengers, nor businesses associated with the airport will ever experience modern, decent, efficient facilities at this airport under this Hawke Labor Government.
The minority report on Sydney Airport prepared by Senators Parer and Boswell and me recommends the immediate construction of a third runway at Sydney Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—As Senator Baume interjects, that it is very necessary. This runway should be commenced without delay, and time should be the essence of the contract. This runway could be up and running while the Federal Government is still haggling about where and when to build a second airport for Sydney. The most important justification for a parallel runway is the dramatic improvement it would provide in bad weather. It would also halve the number of noise affected residents. It is time for a sensible decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The minority report reflects the only decision worth making-that is, an immediate start on a parallel runway at Sydney Airport. It is this option which solves the problem in the shortest time span and with the least inconvenience to travellers, now and in the future. It is the decision which must be taken. The previous Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, has already announced a commitment to proceed with a second airport for Sydney located at Badgerys Creek. He has said that the first stage for general aviation would be complete by 1993. A promise is about all this Government can offer. This should be a nice little revenue raiser for the Government. It could charge a $20 departure fee when one leaves Sydney and a $5 arrival tax when one finally gets to Badgerys Creek.

Senator Evans stated in this place on 28 November that the Federal Airports Corporation will totally finance the $214m being spent on extensive improvements at Sydney's international terminal. He claims that these improvements will `meet Sydney's needs into the next decade'. I thought an airport's primary function was to operate efficiently and in the best manner possible, and to serve the needs of all its clients. Senator Evans must be unaware of this fact because the $214m being spent now at the international terminal and associated facilities, plus the yet to be built airport at Badgerys Creek, will not remove the great discomfort and delay for many years to come. All this because the Hawke Labor Government could not and would not do the job and make a decision. It could not and would not for years and years. Now that same Government is making Australians pay in comfort, time and financial cost, while its power brokers dither over essential decisions concerning this country's air transport future.

The majority report of this Committee is an extremely disappointing document. It is the recommendations of the minority report which ought to be adopted, but it seems that that will have to await the election of a coalition government, which certainly is not very far away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the minority view in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.
—Thank you.

—I acknowledge the honourable senator's thanks, but it is the only commonsense solution. We have seen around the world programs to put major, primary airports in the green fields outside major metropolitan centres. I note that in Los Angeles an airport was proposed at Palmdale, which is some 90 miles outside Los Angeles, because of the congestion at Los Angeles International Airport. In fact, it would have been easier to put it there than it would be to put an airport at Badgerys Creek because the runways already existed at Palmdale, Lockheed having quite a facility there. However, it was not economically viable even though the runways were in. The transportation difficulties to and from the existing Los Angeles International Airport and the metropolitan centre were too great. So Los Angeles International was redeveloped instead. That airport now has five parallel runways and handles an immense amount of traffic.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard an idea tonight which I had not really thought about. Senator MacGibbon came up with the proposition that perhaps Australia's major international airport should be at Brisbane. I think that makes infinite good sense. Brisbane has a wonderful terminal and it would make a good first destination point and a fine departure point. It would certainly relieve some of the congestion at Sydney. I think 11 per cent of the aircraft movements at Brisbane Airport are international. The report brings up some interesting points. I fully concur with the testimony of United Airlines. On page 25 the report states:

A number of witnesses commented on entry and exit documents. United Airlines, for example, felt that Customs formalities for outbound passengers ought to be replaced with `a system similar to the US approach that requires no paperwork from outbound residents and the surrender of the second segment, of the arrival card by departing foreigners to the airline agent'. Their contention was that the `validity of the current card' and the need for the information it requested was questionable.

As a relatively frequent traveller to the United States I note the efficiency of its system. It does work. It certainly relieves the sort of congestion which is experienced at Australian airports. I move on to air traffic control, which was touched upon by Senator MacGibbon, whose comments I fully concur with. On page 26 of the report Captain A. S. King, who represented the General Aviation Association, is quoted as having said:

We need new taxiways, runways, and above all we need a new approach, a new system of air traffic control thinking, because if we do build another runway there is no guarantee that under our present system they will utilise it. . . . We also need revised thinking from our air traffic control colleagues to use that resource to its fullest, as it would be used in any part of the world.

As Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, the air traffic control system used-the spacings, the philosophy used in Australian airspace, not only at Kingsford-Smith-is completely incompatible with safe and efficient aircraft movement. The system simply would not work if--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition has just voted in favour of the adjournment at 10.30 p.m., but I want it to be known that there were circumstances in which the Opposition was happy to agree to extend briefly. We would have given up half an hour on reports and we would have completed debate on the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill tonight, which we regarded as a reasonable extension of sitting hours. What has been put to us-that we complete the present debate on Sydney Airport, that we debate papers for half an hour and then proceed to complete the second reading of Orders of the Day Nos 3 and 4, that is, the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988, the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988, the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill 1988, the Satellite Communications Amendment Bill 1988, the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1988, the Postal Services Amendment Bill 1988, the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill 1988 and the Superannuation Amendment Bill 1988, is totally unreasonable in view of the fact that only today we have had put before us a proposition to sit until 21 December. For the Senate to sit from now until 21 December, until 10.30 each night-probably extending on some of those nights to about 2 a.m. as will probably be the case tonight, thanks to the Australian Democrats agreeing to this-is unreasonable and beyond what is ordinarily expected of people who are trying to do the job of serving their constituencies in the Senate and doing the electorate work that goes with the job. I just want it placed on the record that we were prepared to extend the sitting for a reasonable length of time, but not that which has been put before us, which is regarded as totally unreasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We are reasonable on this side. We have listened to Senator Reid. But one would have to say that the progress of legislation in the spring session has been slower than ever before. We had seven matters of public importance in the first seven days of sitting; we have had numerous disallowance motions; and we have had very long lists of speakers. The Government has sought to shorten this process by withdrawing speakers from Bills. We then get the accusation from the other side that we are not interested in the subject, which is pretty much crocodile tears. Those opposite know why we withdraw speakers from the list; it is to try to get the legislation through. We have endeavoured to get cooperation from all parties in this matter. I cannot say that the cooperation has been denied. I could also say that I do not think it has been entirely to the point where we can move this program along. It is within our hands as to whether we get up next Thursday night. I think we can if we put our minds to it.
—No way.

—Senator Stone says no way. It is not as though in this particular session we did not have the legislation ready. We had legislation programmed for week two that is still sitting on the Notice Paper. It is not as though all the legislation has come in late.
—We cannot help it if you do not manage the program.

—Senator Knowles says that those opposite cannot help it if we do not manage the program. Give me 39 votes and I will manage the program. One day those opposite might be sitting on this side of the Senate and wondering why they are not getting the necessary cooperation for their program. This is a legislative body. We must try to get some of this legislation through. I have already thrown 35 Bills off the list.
—You sound like Don Grimes.

—I take it as a compliment whether I sound like Don Grimes or not. The reality is that we have some responsibility to try to move the legislation along. Maybe at the start of next week we can sit down and try to get some agreed proposals. At the start of this week we tried to circulate a program that we thought was feasible right up until next Thursday and get up next Thursday. At one stage we were three days behind on that proposal. It may be that the role of the Opposition is to say, `All right, we will stall as much as possible and put as much pressure on', and that will make us dump legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —For those catcalling on the other side, I have not complained that they have taken up time this week on matters regarding Gerry Hand. We have not complained; I am not complaining now, but there must also be a will on the other side to cooperate on some of the second reading speeches which tend to get very repetitive over half an hour. One can only draw the conclusion that in actual fact whilst not being a filibuster it is certainly not showing self-discipline so that we can get this program through.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point-I know that we will have a protracted debate on this-is that people have criticised me for bringing down the immigration statement. I could have quite easily waited until this Parliament got up and announced it. We could have done that but we believed that it should have been debated in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of weeks ago.

—The ex-shadow Minister for whatever says `A couple of weeks ago'. I ask him to try to get together a response like that in 13 weeks as I have had to do. It is not easy. But leaving all that aside, with cooperation we can get this program through. The cooperation involves all parties here getting together and trying to work out some agreement as to the length of the speakers list and the length of time that they will speak. It will not be an abrogation of rights. This side of the chamber has given up a lot of debating time.
—And so have we.
—Senator Baume says, `So have we'. We have had less time-I have taken the figures out; I can produce them-on legislation in this session than any time since I have been in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For some time now it has been evident that we face a very difficult if not impossible legislative program within the time that was originally established for the sittings. The Government has already extended the sittings by a week and has today indicated that it may seek to extend the sittings beyond next week. The reality is that the initial part of this session was, I believe, unusually slow for two reasons: firstly, there was a referendum campaign and that led to a great deal of debate on matters related to the referendums. Secondly, there was then a State election and, as is always the case in the Federal Parliament, the advent of a State election means that a little more time than is usual is taken up on general debate which has no direct relevance to this Parliament but which is of a broader political significance. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that since that time on five broadcast days the Opposition brought forward no matter of public importance. In a number of ways we have sought to accommodate the genuine difficulty which exists for the Government with respect to the legislative program.
—And we have given up time for committee reports on Wednesdays several times.
—I am reminded by the Whip that several times we have given up time for committee reports on Wednesdays. We have given up the Thursday lunchtime debates to expedite legislation.
—And we have rescheduled Bills for your convenience all over the place.

—Bills have been rescheduled. I think it is important to get those matters on the record at this time. The Australian Democrats have, in proportionate terms, in my view taken up far more of the time of this chamber. For example, last week they put on a couple of matters of public importance. Again, that is their right.
—Much more meaningful than the drivel you put up.

—I do wish one could speak without the Democrats sounding like a chook yard. It is unnecessary to have that sort of caterwauling. I am simply making the point that the Democrats brought forward several matters of public importance. I am not sure for what reason, but that is their right. If one examines the debating record over recent times one finds that the minority in the Senate have had certainly more than their share of debating time. They have taken advantage of the Standing Orders. That is their right. I am pleased that the Minister has not sought to make a point of the debate this week. If one examines the media one finds widespread comment that the situation of Minister Hand is one where he should have resigned. That is not the view being put forward by the Opposition. The view we are putting forward is the view which has been widely supported in the community and among those who comment on politics. The Opposition makes absolutely no apology for the time which has been spent in dealing with that matter. Our only regret is that it has not been spent fruitfully in terms of achieving what we believe to be the proper constitutional outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: At lunchtime today a number of Opposition speakers took themselves off the list of speakers for the matter of public interest discussion. Senator Colston, as is his right, chose to speak. Senator McLean, as is his right, chose to speak. But that ate into the time that the Opposition sought to make available for the conduct of Government Business.

A quite unreasonable regime of sittings is being imposed upon the Senate. The Opposition has already opposed the negativing of the adjournment on the basis that the sitting program makes it unreasonable that we should sit very late as well as sitting these lengthy and additional hours. I hope that the Government will see the folly of pursuing the course the Minister gave notice of today. I do not think that is worthwhile.

The Government has chosen to say that the Senate should not come back until 28 February. That is a very late start. It is the latest start I have known in the time that I have been in this Parliament, which will be 15 years next year. The Government has chosen to have an extraordinarily uneven pattern of sittings this year. It is within the Government's province to sit in an orderly way for a longer period of the year. That, I believe, is the appropriate response to the legislative log jam which has developed. I say to the Minister that the imposition of lengthy periods of extended sittings and late night sittings is not in the interests of the Parliament and is certainly not in the interests of the orderly consideration of legislation.

The Opposition has always cooperated with the Government in terms of sitting when the Government requires, but I give the Government notice that we do not believe that the sort of extended sittings which are now proposed are in the interests of the Parliament or in the interests of the community. We might, therefore, choose to resist the additional sittings promoted by the Government in the notice of motion given today. I do not think the Senate wants to hear any more of me. I am sure that it would like to go back to the debates which, we are told, will run on well into the evening--
Government senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not say `Hear, hear!' too loudly; it might discourage me from sitting down.
—It is all negotiable.
—I trust that in my absence on Monday the Minister will negotiate some sensible arrangements with Senator Lewis.

—by leave-I ask the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) to confirm a rumour I have just heard: that what is being sought is to conclude the debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, to have half an hour on papers and then to go to the second reading of the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill and the Satellite Communications Amendment Bill package and then the Telecommunications Amendment Bill, the Postal Services Amendment Bill and the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill package. What does the Government desire to achieve tonight? When does the Government expect we will conclude that?
—Senator Harradine, I cannot answer for the Minister.

—by leave-Unlike Senator Harradine I do not seek to elicit information but to transmit it to the Government. We are good sons of the soil. We are prepared to follow the plough not only to Christmas Day but also to New Year's Day if need be. I invite the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) to reflect on the great disasters that befell the Whitlam Government in the Senate. It always came unstuck when it sat alone without the protection of the House of Representatives. If the Government chooses to sit here for three to four weeks, it is welcome to all that is going to fall on it.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator SANDERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had many quorums called on me but this is the first time I have had a division and a full debate called on me in the midst of a presentation.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walters-Where is your Leader?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator SANDERS

TALK.START.PARA: —The rubberneck over there interjects. I hope that all assembled members, including Senator Walters, will listen with great attention to my speech on the report on Sydney Airport. Before the division was called I was pointing out that the air traffic control system in Australia is simply not adequate for a modern country. Certainly, it would not work in any country which has high aircraft densities. It only works here at all because we do not have a lot of aeroplanes in our airspace. As anyone who flies on commercial airlines knows, it does not work very well here because of the delays which have been mentioned by previous speakers. One of the difficulties is that the authorities insist on maintaining IFR spacing-that is, instrument flight rules spacing for aircraft flying in instrument conditions-in visual conditions when the aircraft crews can see each other. When the cloud cover is such that the visibility is good, IFR spacing is still maintained. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out, with three miles to run to a runway, aircraft in Australia would have absolutely no other aircraft in the airspace. In the United States, Europe and Japan a number of other aircraft could be lined up on their final approach. That is the way aircraft are moved.

INTERJECT.PARA: Another very odd thing that happens in Australia and which accounts for a great deal of congestion at Kingsford-Smith-I have observed it myself-is that Australian authorities still have not recognised the vertical take-off and landing capabilities of helicopters. They force helicopters to follow the same procedures as fixed-wing aircraft.
Senator MacGibbon-Absolutely absurd.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator SANDERS

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator MacGibbon says, it is absurd. They force helicopters to hover along a taxiway-of course, helicopters cannot taxi-to the active runway and then take off on the heading of that runway and depart. Every other place in the world that I have seen recognises that helicopters have unique flight characteristics and they are operated away from fixed wing aircraft. Here in Australia we compound our already congested traffic control systems in the vicinity of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport by making helicopters operate in the same manner as fixed wing aircraft, thus clogging up the system. The helicopter operators do not like it, the fixed wing operators do not like it, yet the Government still seems unable to change its system.

INTERJECT.PARA: In respect of evidence given by the Australian International Pilots Association (AIPA), the Committee states at page 26 of its report:
Essentially we are talking about World War II or Korean war equipment . . . the radarscopes are big round screens, as you would expect, with big square blobs on them and no other information.

What is being referred to is the fact that the electronic equipment at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is very outmoded. This is another misuse of the Government's priorities. The Government simply cannot invest in the most modern equipment or, if it does, the procedures are so slow that, by the time the equipment is actually brought in through the door, it is already outmoded. This is what happened in Melbourne, where the equipment was eight years out of date by the time it was finally installed. The report goes on to state on page 27:

The Civil Aviation Authority responded to some of these criticisms in a supplementary submission to the Committee. The CAA claimed that it was currently implementing an air traffic control re-equipment program and a new radar system would be commissioned at Sydney in 1992.
Is that not wonderful-four years down the track? The report continues:

However, the CAA stated that whilst the new system would ease the workload on controllers during peak traffic periods, it was not expected to produce a significant change in the traffic handling rate.

Why not, and if it does not produce a significant change, why bother to put it in? The fact is that the problem is probably not with the radar itself and it may not be entirely due to runways-once again it is with the procedures. There are also traffic delays in Melbourne. These delays cannot be due to a lack of runways because Tullamarine Airport has adequate runways. No one has ever criticised the lack of runways at Tullamarine. But what is criticisable is the procedures used by the controllers themselves and, apparently, the computer software in their radar equipment. It does not seem as though the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) can get its act together. It cannot run a complicated system which is necessary for the late twentieth century. The report continues:

The CAA further argued that it was misleading to suggest that Australia's air traffic congestion problems were caused by its air traffic control systems, and that other major aviation countries were free of such problems. According to the CAA, there was no simple indicator of the efficiency of air traffic control systems and no simple means of comparing efficiency of the ATC system at Sydney with those of other airports.
What utter rubbish! Ask any Qantas Airways Ltd captain to compare the systems. When I go overseas I generally fly Qantas and, when I do, I wander up front and talk to the skippers.
Senator Crichton-Browne-I bet they are pleased about that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator SANDERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually, they are. Does the honourable senator know what they want to talk about? They want to talk about superannuation. But, after they have finished talking about superannuation, they talk about air traffic control systems and they unanimously say that the systems in Australia are the worst they encounter anywhere in the world; they are the least efficient of any systems in the world. I would suggest that, if the CAA really wanted to know what other pilots thought about its system, it would get a panel of Qantas pilots-retired Qantas pilots perhaps-to advise it on what is wrong with its system. If the CAA will not listen to me, Senator MacGibbon, the general aviation people or the AIPA, perhaps it will listen to Qantas pilots.

INTERJECT.PARA: There are many concrete criticisms of the system. If these criticisms were met and listened to in a fair manner by the CAA, the system could be improved very cheaply indeed. Basically, the solution is flexibility. Our system has no flexibility and I suppose that this is a result of the bureaucratic control which has been exerted over it. In many countries, including the United States of America, there is far more flexibility. On one occasion, when flying at night from Santa Barbara Airport to Los Angeles in a single engined aircraft, I overflew Los Angeles International Airport in a visual flight rules lane which meant that I was not under direct control. I was able to move in this lane above the airport-as Senator MacGibbon has said, the place above an airport is the safest place to go-and, as a courtesy to the approach controller, I simply mentioned that I was transiting his area. He asked me where I was going and I said I was going to Hawthorn Airport, five miles away. I volunteered the information that I was coming back to a conference at Los Angeles International Airport. That air traffic controller invited me to land at Los Angeles International. That would be unheard of in Australia. He invited me to land at that airport because he was the northern sector controller; he controlled two 8,000-foot runways which were closed to jet traffic but open to reciprocating engine traffic. The flexibility was in the system and he allowed me to use that facility. That flexibility does not exist in Australia and that is one of our major problems.

What about the runways? What about the problems of congestion? There are problems of congestion outside the air traffic control system at Sydney Airport. I believe that Senator MacGibbon has come up with the answer. I had already thought that his suggestion would be a good idea, but he beat me to the punch with his speech. Basically, what he suggests is not a major 3,000-metre, 747-standard runway, but a runway-or, perhaps, runways-for general aviation and commuter aircraft of 5,700 kilogram gross weight. This runway does not need to be much longer than, say, 1,000 metres. It does not need to support the massive weights of jet aircraft. It could be built very quickly and very cheaply. Basically, it could be built to the standard of a country road because that is the sort of runway that light aircraft use. They do not need a heavy runway. It could be in place very quickly indeed and it would take some 47 per cent of the traffic at Kingsford-Smith. That is the amount of traffic involving aircraft of less than 5,700 kilograms. If those aircraft could use this runway it would relieve the jet congestion on the major runways and it would be a quick, cheap solution to the problem.

There probably will be further problems and in the future there will probably be a need for a jet-standard runway. But at the moment there is an immediate need to alleviate the terrible congestion problems, and this is one way of doing that. I note that page 57 of the report says:

The FAC indicated that an additional runway involved `a lot of money' and that its first priority was to fix the international terminal. The FAC pointed out that it must remain free to explore all options for increasing runway capacity at the airport.

The suggested option is one which I have not seen mentioned by the FAC. I wish that it would study it. It certainly works at Los Angeles International Airport where there are four major jet runways and a parallel 3,000-foot commuter strip. It also works at other airports around the world and there is no reason to believe that it would not work in Sydney. I thoroughly reject the contention of the report and of the Government that a second airport should be built at Badgerys Creek. It is obvious that the most economical and best way to serve both Sydney and Australia is to put in a third runway at Sydney Airport.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
