DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Drugs in Sport Inquiry: Report on the Harassment of a Witness.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report results from an incident occurring during the conduct of the Committee's current inquiry into the use of drugs in sport. In brief, it concerns a witness, Ms Sue Howland, who was issued with a formal summons from the Committee to appear before the Committee and produce relevant papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Immediately following her appearance before the Committee, Ms Howland was told to leave the house in which she has been living and find other accommodation. The wording of the note received by Ms Howland telling her to look for new accommodation, together with other information provided to the Committee by Ms Howland, and detailed in the report, leads the Committee to believe that the eviction of Ms Howland was a direct consequence of her giving evidence to the Committee. It is, in the Committee's view, a clear case of a witness suffering harassment as a result of giving evidence to a parliamentary committee. The Committee believes that it should be treated by the Senate with the utmost seriousness and that prompt action is required if the progress of the Committee's inquiry into drugs in sport is not to be impeded. I say, in emphasising the seriousness with which the Committee views this matter, that other witnesses who have appeared before the Committee have expressed concern that they may suffer intimidation as a result of the evidence they have given.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Black wrote to me this morning, pursuant to the procedures laid down by the Senate on 25 February 1988 for raising matters of privilege, formally raising the matter which is the subject of this report, the alleged harassment of a witness because of her evidence before the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I am required to determine whether a motion relating to the matter should have precedence, having regard to the criteria laid down by the Senate's resolutions of 25 February. The criteria and the manner in which I have applied them will now be well known to the Senate because of a number of cases which have arisen since the resolutions were passed.

INTERJECT.PARA: The matter raised by Senator Black and referred to in the Standing Committee's report is clearly one which is capable of being regarded by the Senate as meeting the specified criteria, that is, as a matter of an alleged improper act involving potential substantial obstruction, which may require the use of the Senate's powers to provide reasonable protection for the Standing Committee in conducting its inquiry. I have therefore determined that a motion relating to the matter should have precedence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following question be referred to the Committee of Privileges: whether there was any improper interference with a witness who gave evidence the Senate Standing Committee on En- vironment, Recreation and the Arts in relation to that Committee's inquiry into the use of drugs in sport.

(2) That, in inquiring into this matter, the Committee of Privileges have regard to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in relation to the harassment of a witness.
(3) That the provisions of the resolution of 3 November 1988 relating to the powers of the Committee apply in relation to the Committee's inquiry into the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not propose to reflect upon the facts that have been outlined by Senator Black, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I speak essentially for myself and not for the Committee. A number of sportspeople-witnesses-of world ranking have expressed real fear for their careers. I have no doubt that there are sports officials and administrators in this country who have not only condoned the use of drugs in sport but have actively encouraged their use in the pursuit of better results. The Committee has already been required to subpoena witnesses. I have no doubt that in the future a number of young sportspeople will also have to be subpoenaed, not because they wish not to cooperate with the Committee, but because they have a genuine fear and belief that, in the event that they are required to give evidence of drug use in sport, they will find themselves denied funding and facilities, find themselves dropped from national teams and, ultimately, denied the prospect of a world ranking and perhaps a record. In other words, the price of truth, they fear, is to have their careers dashed and the prospects of a future ranking dashed also.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure we all recognise the enormous sacrifice that these athletes make in the pursuit of their endeavours. If witnesses are persuaded not to give evidence before the Committee, the work of the Committee will be very much frustrated and interfered with. If, at this early stage of the Committee's inquiries, it is derailed by the blackmail and/or intimidation of witnesses, the facts and truth will remain hidden. On the basis of the public evidence so far given, that would be a tragic circumstance for the health, welfare and future of Australian sportspeople and Australian sports in general.

It has been necessary for the Chairman on a number of occasions to reassure witnesses that they are protected by the provisions of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. Perhaps for the record it is worthwhile that I repeat the provisions of section 12 of that Act. It says:
Protection of witnesses

12. (1) A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force or threat, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit, or by other improper means, influence another person in respect of any evidence given or to be given before a House or a committee, or induce another person to refrain from giving any such evidence.
Penalty:
(a) in the case of a natural person, $5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months; or
(b) in the case of a corporation, $25,000.

I have no doubt that if there is the slightest shred of evidence that any witness who gives evidence before the Committee believes that he is being intimidated, is likely to be intimidated or harassed, or has reason to believe that the evidence he or she gives will be detrimental to him or her, the Committee will refer it to the Senate and the Privileges Committee. I have no doubt that the Privileges Committee, recognising the significance and importance of this inquiry and its implication and ramifications for the sports people of Australia, will act in a way to ensure that the witnesses before the Committee can in the future feel perfectly safe in giving the evidence they wish to give and which the Committee desires of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise to indicate to the Government that, given the seriousness of the matter that has been raised, if Senator Black cares to have this matter voted on forthwith, so that the reference can proceed without further delay, the Opposition will be happy to facilitate whatever the necessary procedures of the Senate are to achieve that end.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Black)-by leave-agreed to:

(1) That the following question be referred to the Committee of Privileges: whether there was any improper interference with a witness who gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in relation to that Committee's inquiry into the use of drugs in sport.

(2) That, in inquiring into this matter, the Committee of Privileges have regard to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts relating to the harassment of a witness.
(3) That the provisions of the resolution of 3 November 1988 relating to the powers of the Committee apply in relation to the Committee's inquiry into the matter.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —When speaking on the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988 earlier today I stated that I wanted to raise some inconsistencies in the Government's efforts to improve conditions for our service personnel. I point out that the specific exclusion of all enlistees to the armed forces since 14 May 1985 is not justified if we wish to see some improvement in the morale of those we ask to serve this country. This exclusion of young sailors, soldiers and airmen from the defence service home loans scheme is in direct contradiction to the bipartisan Cross report on Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force and its recommendation 33. Significantly, all service personnel have to complete six years service before becoming eligible. So it is not until 1991 that this exclusion will start to bite. This unjustifiable policy only serves to create two classes of service personnel-those who enlisted before 14 May 1985 and those who joined after that date.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area where the Government has created divisions in the ranks of service personnel is on the subject of portability. My concern is that those who borrow after December 1987 have fully portable loans whereas borrowers before that date do not. Where is the justice in this? This action introduces yet another element of division between two groups of service personnel. The need for portability for older defence home loan borrowers is important because in many cases it would assist them to go into retirement housing as they become older.

I would also like to raise the issue of the size of the loan, which is $25,000. The loan was lifted to this amount by the coalition Government in October 1980. That was eight years ago. Since then, as we have all experienced in our various capital cities and States, there has been an increase in housing prices. Honourable senators should look at Sydney where the price of established dwellings has risen by 84 per cent in that time. The price has risen by 131 per cent in Melbourne and by 104 per cent in Adelaide. As all of us are only too well aware, this loan will barely give those eligible service men and women a start along the path to owning their own homes. It behoves all of us to address this matter as soon as possible to try to give a more realistic appraisal of those few benefits we grant to service men and women.

While I commend the Government on at least trying to get the matter corrected it saddens me that once again in this matter the Government has shown its total arrogance for the Parliament and the citizens of this country. I want to point out to honourable senators that they have been pre-empted in respect of the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. What do I mean by this? What has been going on before this legislation has even been passed by the Senate? I will tell honourable senators what has happened. The Government said, `Don't wait for Parliament; don't wait for the debates in the Senate or the House of Representatives. Let's have some letters sent out to thousands of defence service home loan holders under the official heading of the Defence Service Homes Corporation even before the Bill has been passed through the Parliament'. The Government said, `Let the letter to all those service men and women and their families say in the most offhand manner, ``Just be advised that Westpac is taking over the scheme. A letter is enclosed from Westpac with some of the arrangements associated with this matter'' '.

The Government has totally pre-empted the will of Parliament in an arrogant and out of touch manner. It is this out of touch manner, in total disregard for others, on which I want to make one or two points. Recently I asked Senator Richardson a question in this chamber in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I asked him when the Government would take action to correct some of the deplorable living conditions for military personnel. I cited in particular housing at the army base at Enoggera in Brisbane in my own State. That housing is in a state of shocking disrepair and not fit for human habitation. Ninety-eight per cent of the houses inspected had poor linoleum floor coverings, sagging ceilings, inadequate kitchens with little shelving and expensive to run stoves. Many of the laundries inspected were outside the house and infected with cockroaches. This is a dreadful situation when we consider that these conditions have not occurred overnight and have been developing during the past few years.

In light of the record number of service men and women leaving the defence forces because of poor working conditions the Government should consider improving these living conditions as a top priority. I want to point out to the Senate this evening that it is about time the Government admitted to itself the total contempt and disregard it has shown to the Services by its failure to redress many of these inadequate conditions. It is no wonder that the Government is experiencing a serious defence morale problem when it expects our service men and women to live in deplorable housing or fails to grant them reasonable means to provide that housing for themselves. It only further aggravates that morale problem which it is finally admitting exists and is likely to continue for many years to come. It is time this Government stopped talking and proceeded, as a matter of urgency, to improve the conditions of service for those soldiers, sailors and airmen currently serving and those who have retired after many years of commitment to this country. We owe them that much at least.

I support the amendments that have been moved by Senator Newman on behalf of the Opposition. I would like to add that Senator Newman, in describing the Opposition amendment to be moved in the Committee stage, stated that it was the same amendment moved by the shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) in the other place. As she has leave this evening she has asked me to draw to the Senate's attention that it is a similar amendment with some slight technical differences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a most instructive debate which I am sure has held the interest of all honourable senators, who naturally have the interest of service men and women at heart and wish to provide the best possible living conditions for those who serve our country in the armed forces. Nevertheless, I have not been persuaded, even by the eloquence of Senator Bjelke-Petersen, that the amendment moved by Senator Newman is worthy of support at this stage. Therefore, I indicate that the Government will be voting against this amendment. I seek the support of the chamber for the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 2, after clause 4 (a), insert the following new paragraph:
``(ab) by inserting, in the definition of `Australian Soldier', after `means':
`a person who during the First World War or the Second World War was a member of the naval, military or air forces of Australia enlisted or appointed for or employed on, service in Australia or'.''.

The purpose of the Australian Democrats proposing the insertion of the new paragraph is to broaden the definition of `Australian Soldier' so that women receive precisely the same entitlement as males. Honourable senators will notice that the amendment refers to `a person who during the First World War or the Second World War was a member of the naval, military or air forces of Australia enlisted or appointed for or employed on, service in Australia'. In other words, it draws into the net of entitlement those few women who have been excluded by the previous definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean's amendment may intend to do that but it does a great deal more. As it is worded, it would bring into the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill all the servicemen who did not have operational service. I think perhaps hundreds of thousands, certainly very substantial numbers, of people would suddenly become entitled. We should not do that, even as a request, by an amendment on the run. There have been arguments over the years that these people should be entitled to defence service homes; governments have not previously granted it. I am sure that if Senator McLean looks carefully at the effect of his amendment he will see that it eliminates the present requirement that World War I and World War II servicemen should have operational service, usually overseas but in certain circumstances in the northern part of Australia, because this covers them all. I do not think the Committee could accept that on the run at this stage. It is a very substantial amendment. I imagine-perhaps the Minister has some costings-that it would be a very expensive commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been able to get it costed, but it vastly expands the coverage of the concessional loan. Somebody said that it was extended to `chocolate soldiers'. I am not sure whether Senator Hamer used that term, but for the reasons Senator Hamer stated, the Government, of course, will not accept this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Request negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 5 (Regular Serviceman)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Page 4, at end of clause 5, add the following new subclauses:

``(2) On and after 15 May 1991, the words added to section 4aaa of the Principal Act by subsection (1) are omitted from that subsection and, subject to subsection (3), the Principal Act has effect as if subsection (1) had not been enacted.

``(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (2), the Secretary shall not issue a certificate of entitlement in relation to an advance to a person whose first service in the Defence Force began after 14 May 1985, and no such person may exercise any right under that subsection, unless and until a new or amended agreement, concerning these persons, is executed, and its execution on behalf of the Commonwealth approved by Parliament.
``(4) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, the agreement shall not be terminated by reason only that this section:
(a) is not in the form in which it appeared in the draft Bill referred to in subclause 6.1 of the agreement; or
(b) has an effect of a kind described in paragraphs 6.1 (a) to (e), inclusive, of the agreement.''.

The purpose of this amendment is to deal with a problem which the Government has handled very badly. In the Cross report, the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled `Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force', a very significant recommendation was made, recommendation 33, in which the Committee unanimously recommended that post-May 1985 enlistees should have eligibility for defence service home loans. This Bill does not meet that requirement. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) promised in the House of Representatives debate to look at the implications of recommendation 33. This is simply not good enough. We all know that this Government is one of disposable promises. I do not have time to go through all the disposable promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for instance. However, we must make it clear in this Parliament to those servicemen that this Parliament is determined that the Government will honour its promises.

The structure of this Bill, based on the agreement with Westpac, puts the Parliament in an almost impossible position, because we cannot amend it without forcing renegotiations with Westpac. What we are saying with our amendment is that if the Government has not met its promises by 15 May 1991, the post-May 1985 enlistees automatically become eligible for home loans, and the Government will be forced to renegotiate an agreement with Westpac or a successor. It is a very sad day when this Bill is presented in this form, based on an agreement with Westpac and Parliament, in effect, is told by the Government, `You must not amend this Bill to overcome a clear anomaly because if you do amend it Westpac has the right to cancel the agreement'.

I have, therefore, moved the amendment in the confident expectation that the Government will have no option but to support it. After all, one of the Government senators, Senator Maguire, is a member of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee when it unanimously recommended that this should be done. The amendment must command the support of the Democrats, because we are seeking, in the felicitous phrase of their founding leader, is `to keep the bastards honest'. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, we cannot support this amendment because it does more than keep the bastards honest; it actually serves the needs of another group, Westpac, because it inadvertently hands an additional prize to Westpac for which it would not pay and for which it did not bid. The legal advice I have is that the effect of this amendment is to grant to Westpac the privileges of the post-1985 borrowers whose needs certainly have to be addressed. We certainly concur with recommendation 33 of the Cross report. We certainly accept the fact that this anomaly is a contributor to low morale and probably, therefore, to the wastage of service people. However, we cannot condone the fact that Westpac came to the table and negotiated a deal. As a result of that deal, the Bill which is now before us was drafted to provide Westpac with an escape clause under which it can, if it so wishes, escape from any amendments which are made. The Democrats cannot go along with that rationale and, in addition, automatically provide to Westpac gratis, without a dollar going into the public purse, the bonus of the harvest of the post-1985 borrowers. We confidently believe that the Minister will address this anomaly very soon. We believe that it will be resolved in the interests of the post-1985 borrowers, but we cannot accept that in that process Westpac will get an enormous additional bonus to its harvest for which it paid $100m. It was a pretty good buy at that price, but it is completely unacceptable that this additional bonus should be thrown in without the taxpayer receiving some benefit from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean has given some of the reasons, which the Government shares, why this amendment should not be accepted. Perhaps I should give some of the background. Westpac has paid a face value premium of $100m for the portfolio debt outstanding. In terms of present values, this premium is worth around $85m. It is a very substantial premium because it attracts additional business to Westpac which made a commercial judgment that it was worth that much money.

SPEECH.PARA: If the amendment that Senator Hamer has moved were to be carried, the effect would be to deliver post-May 1985 enlistees as captive clients of Westpac. While this is impossible to quantify, there is no reasonable doubt that that gift to Westpac would run into tens of millions of dollars. Whether it is $20m, $40m or $50m is very much conjecture. But there is no doubt that it would deliver to Westpac a very substantial gift. Westpac indicated to the task force which negotiated this sale that, of the $100m face value premium that the bank offered, some $50m was the value assessed by Westpac of having additional clients automatically flowing through to the bank-not just for the Government subsidised portion of the loan but for any additional loan.

As I am sure Senator Hamer knows, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, issued a press statement two or three weeks ago committing the Government to the introduction of a scheme for those post-1985 enlistees.

TALK.START.PARA: —She also said that in the House of Representatives.

—I am sorry, I did not know that. There will be a scheme for post-1985 enlistees. I am in no position to state what that scheme will be, but I think it highly likely that it would provide either a lump sum or a subsidised interest loan with the individual having the option as to which one he takes. At that time-and again this is not settled Government policy but is something that is likely to happen, I suggest-the Government is likely to call tenders or expressions of interest from financial institutions for the administration of a loan scheme only, or the option of a loan scheme or a lump sum. Whether it be a loan scheme or even an optional scheme, the Government would once again expect to get a very substantial premium from the financial institution with which it entered into an agreement to pay the subsidy.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 6 agreed to.
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Page 5, clause 7, after proposed section 4b, insert the following new sections:
Review of operations

``4ba. (1) On or after 9 November 1990, but not later than the first day of sitting of each House of the Parliament in 1991, the Minister shall lay before each House a report on the operation of this Act relating to the provision of financial assistance to members of the Defence Force and others to acquire homes.
``(2) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), the report shall examine, in particular, the effects of the agreement on the provision of financial assistance.
Agreement not to terminate
``4bb. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, the agreement shall not be terminated by reason only that the provisions of this Act:
(a) differ in any respect from the provisions in the draft Bill referred to in subclause 6.1 of the agreement; or
(b) have an effect of a kind described in paragraphs 6.1 (a) to (e), inclusive, of the agreement.''.

The purpose of this amendment is to ensure a review of the new program after a period of two years. We do not think it is reasonable that Westpac Banking Corporation should undertake the program at a reasonable price-obviously it has done its sums and knows it is worth it-and yet at no period subsequent to its undertaking the program be it called upon to account to those it is serving for the fact that it is rendering good service. We believe it is reasonable that at the end of two years an independent assessment and evaluation of the program be undertaken and its continuation be dependent upon the outcome of that evaluation. That is the purpose of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under clause 50b of the legislation, the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs is required to provide an annual report on the administration and operation of the Defence Service Homes Act and the Minister shall cause a copy of that report to be tabled in each House within 15 sitting days. That procedure will enable Parliament to consider the operation of the Act without the proposed amendment. The Government does not accept this amendment on two grounds. Firstly, we believe it is redundant. Secondly, should Westpac Banking Corporation have second thoughts about whether it has made a sound commercial judgment in offering that premium of $100m face value or $85m at present values, there is a possibility-these amendments came in very late and we have not had an opportunity to get expert legal advice on it-that any amendment to this provision would provide an opportunity to Westpac to get out of the agreement made, should it revise its opinion and decide to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: So, firstly, we believe the amendment is redundant as the situation is effectively covered by an existing clause. Secondly, it opens up the risk-I do not want to put any more strongly than that because I have not had an expert legal opinion-Westpac could get out of the agreement if it revised its opinion of the value of it from its perspective.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not accept that there is sufficient strength in the clause which provides for the evaluation process as written; nor do we accept the fact that we should bow down to the escape clause. With the support of Opposition speakers at the second reading stage of this debate, we drew attention to the fact that the escape clause drafted into this document is in fact quite offensive to the process of this Committee. To be threatened by it is unacceptable to the Committee and its process. Therefore, we do not accept the second of the Minister's points. We simply do not find that acceptable and we reserve the right to move amendments. If they are passed, I think we have to live with the consequences. We argue that they are worthy amendments and we simply believe that the whole concept of bringing legislation here which has escape clauses that provide we cannot amend them is totally unacceptable. We believe that this amendment stands in its own right and insist upon the right to put it.

—When I spoke before, I was addressing only proposed new section 4ba, or subsection (1), I suppose one could say, of the amendment that Senator McLean has moved. The agreement not to terminate-that is, proposed new section 4bb-raises far more serious legal considerations. Again I say that we have not had time to get expert legal opinion on this matter, but the preliminary advice that I have had is that there is not just a risk but a near certainty that if that part of the amendment were to be passed, then Westpac Banking Corporation would be able to walk away from the agreement if it wished to do so. Also, it opens up questions of constitutional law, so I am advised-although I stress that this advice is tentative because it was given on the run-as to whether the Parliament can put a provision into an Act which would effectively negate a private agreement or a contractual obligation into which the Government has entered.
—Ha, Ha!
—The honourable senator probably knows more law than I do, but that is the advice that I have been given. That vastly strengthens the Government's opposition to this particular amendment.

—I have two points. If Westpac really is frightened away from this proposition by virtue of the fact that it may be evaluated at the end of two years, and if it is frightened by the concept and the process of accountability, then frankly I question its bona fides in this exercise. For the Minister to say that it raises constitutional questions as to whether it is legitimate for it to draft a document which negates an agreement between the Executive and another party, I suggest that it is even more constitutionally questionable whether it is legitimate for this House to have to bow down to a clause which negates its very constitutional process; that is, the right to review and the right to amend, and that is the process that we are now applying. I think that if there are two constitutional questions, frankly to me the latter is by far the more profound.

—Various speakers for the Opposition have made the point that the structure of this Bill is very unsatisfactory and it has been much criticised both in the House of Representatives debate and in this chamber. The problem is, in our view, that there is considerable urgency in getting this Bill through for the benefit of servicemen. To undertake the sort of structural change in approach which is proposed by Senator McLean with the problem of throwing into doubt what is achieved, we frankly do not think is worthwhile. That will apply to some other amendments that the Australian Democrats are moving with which we have sympathy. We do not want to hold this legislation up while anything is renegotiated or redrafted. The Bill is imperfect. We think that it is in a very unsatisfactory state, as we have said several times; nevertheless it is a great deal better than nothing and we think we should have it.

—I just wanted to ask the Minister a question seeing that he has raised this question of constitutional law which I accept is not on the basis of proper advice received on either side. When the Minister was speaking he said that there was a problem about the alleged interference in what he described as a `private agreement'. My question to him is simply this: If one of the parties to this agreement is the Commonwealth of Australia, how is it a private agreement?

—It would be more accurate, I think, to describe it as a legal agreement. I am not sure whether `constitutional law' was the right term to use, either. The point I was making, acting on the advice that I had been given on the run, concerned the constitutionality, I suppose, of a provision being written into an Act of Parliament which serves notice that a legal agreement may, a couple of years down the track, be broken because that provision is in that Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister says that the Government has not had sufficient time to deliberate over these amendments. That is not quite so. I had discussions with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, and, through her, with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, a couple of weeks ago-it would certainly be in the order of 10 days. I put the outline of these amendments to the two relevant Ministers in writing. They responded in writing. We advised them that we would proceed with the amendments. They were drafted and circulated more than 24 hours ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address the comments made by Senator Hamer. The Bill in its present form delivers almost nothing. For $100m it delivers very little to borrowers. The only thing it ensures is that defence personnel will not have to wait a qualifying period of 10 months. We said earlier that if they get their act together and organise their personal finances for the serious business of procuring real estate, that period of 10 months is of little consequence. The Bill does not deliver portability. It does not deliver any significant change to the favoured sum borrowed-we are proposing an increase from $25,000 to $45,000. It does not deliver to the post-1985 borrowers. It delivers virtually nothing. And the Government tells us that we cannot amend it in a manner that will rectify its inadequacies and in a manner that has been requested by the associations that represent the potential borrowers.

For us to pass the Bill in its present form is to do little more than to deliver to Westpac an absolute gift in exchange for very little into the public purse. I believe that we have not only an obligation to amend the legislation and to render it effective but also the right to do so. We should not back away from that because we are being threatened that Westpac will withdraw from a deal which gives it everything, which gives the potential consumer virtually nothing, and which also gives it the opportunity to do what it is already doing, which is to canvass its broader banking services. Honourable senators may have read the letters that were prematurely sent by the Defence Services Homes Corporation and by Westpac to present borrowers which, in paragraph 3, started promoting the broader banking services that would be available. I suggest to honourable senators that not only are we entitled but also we are absolutely obliged to serve those whom we say we are serving by this legislation. The Government says that. The Opposition says that. We say that the need is there. So let us produce legislation which delivers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is quite a lot in what Senator McLean says. As one of his former profession, a general, once said, war is an option of difficulty and so is politics. In this case we are confronted, as members of the Senate, with a Bill that has been described several times as being in a thoroughly unsatisfactory state. It has taken the Government 3 1/2 years to produce it. Frankly, we do not want to spend 3 1/2 years going through the consequences of renegotiating as a result of amendments made here. The benefits are more than Senator McLean has itemised. I do not think now is the appropriate time to go through the benefits of the Bill as a whole. That time was the second reading debate. I do not propose to repeat those benefits. Nevertheless, there are substantial benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is not in an ideal form. The form in which it is brought before the Parliament is very unsatisfactory. I agree entirely with what Senator McLean said about the standover tactic that we cannot amend it because it will affect the negotiations with Westpac. However, that is not our decision. We are confronted with legislation in this form. I think that it has substantial benefits for servicemen. I believe that if we make significant alterations it would very much delay its implementation. For that reason we are prepared to see it go through in its present form with all the warnings of what is needed to be done to make it better legislation in the future. We will endeavour to hold the Government to the undertakings it has given to improve it.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 8 and 9-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 10 (Resignation of officers).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 11, clause 10, proposed subsection 19 (2), line 34, after ``granted'', insert ``before or''.
(4) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 14, clause 10, proposed paragraph 25 (1) (a), line 38, leave out ``$25,000'', insert ``$45,000''.
(5) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 15, clause 10, proposed paragraph 25 (1) (b), line 1, leave out ``$25,000'', insert ``$45,000''.
(6) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 15, clause 10, proposed paragraph 25 (1) (d), line 18, leave out ``$25,000'', insert ``$45,000''.
(7) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 15, clause 10, proposed subsection 25 (2), line 28, leave out ``$25,000'', insert ``$45,000''.

We are pursuing the point of amending this Bill so that it has some guts; so that it is not utterly empty; so that it provides to service people what they require to stay in the service; so that it provides some incentive for people to join the Services; and so that it delivers what was promised by the Government and the Opposition. The purpose of the first amendment is to grant portability of the loan. By virtue of their frequent postings, service people more often incur the need to sell. The privilege of portability of this loan from one property to another is denied to a considerable proportion of borrowers at the moment. The purpose of the amendment is simply to extend portability to all borrowers under the Act.

The second amendment is to acknowledge the fact that at the time the figure of $25,000 was set it was meaningful. We believe that it now must be revised upwards to a more realistic figure of $45,000. This will mean that when a `privileged loan' is offered to service people at `privileged rates' there will be some substance to that claim. The amendment will ensure the amount is equal in real terms to what it was worth when this concept was first introduced. Despite the escape clause and despite the attempt by the drafters of this Bill to deny us the right to amend the legislation, because service people require it and because the Opposition says it supports the concept, we are moving these amendments. In the Opposition's own second reading attachment amendment it said it supported all these amendments. The Australian Democrats also approved them yet now the Opposition is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get so excited.

—If the honourable senator does not know what he is doing then he should be ashamed of himself. The Australian Democrats are proposing in the committee stage exactly what the Opposition proposed at the second reading stage. Yet the Opposition now refuses to deliver.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in this debate I was asked to perform the honourable role of `keeping the bastards honest' and that is exactly what I am doing now, I can see by the looks on the faces of senators on the Opposition benches that they do not realise what is happening now-that in the committee stage we are asking them to do what they said they believed in at the second reading stage. Those are the realities of the situation, despite Senator McGauran's interjections.
Friday, 9 December 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees with the purpose of Senator McLean's amendments. They are desirable-we said so both during the second reading stage and in the amendment to the second reading motion in which we moved for more portability and for an increase in the maximum amount of the loan from $25,000, which we said was too low. Whether the figure should be $45,000 is a matter for argument. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended a figure of $35,000. Both figures represent very substantial changes.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate what I said earlier in this debate. The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill is far from perfect, but its advantages are substantially more than Senator McLean has admitted. If we make these changes to it we will delay its implementation for a very long time, we fear. It has taken 3 1/2 years to get to this stage. We think it is substantially better than the present situation. While criticising this legislation as being inadequate, poorly structured and in some ways an insult to the Parliament in that it has come to us in this form, nevertheless we think that to adopt it is better than to attempt to amend it and cause substantial further delays.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Hamer's comments I accept that his criticism has some validity. It took very much longer to negotiate this agreement than I had expected. It is not quite right to say that it has taken 3 1/2 years because the legislation was not quite the same proposition 3 1/2 years ago. However Senator Hamer is right in saying that it has taken 3 1/2 years to get the legislation to the stage that it is now at.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall speak firstly to Senator McLean's amendment No. 3, which seeks to make portable loans granted before 9 December 1987. For technical reasons, however, the amendment does not do that-or it does it only to a limited extent. It does not address clause 19 (2) of the Bill, which excludes portability on all loans with a term greater than 25 years. In other words, it would apply only to loans granted before that date for a term of less than 25 years, of which there are very few. Furthermore, it also raises the question as to whether anyone who had ever had a defence service home loan would gain access to portability. If so, the cost would escalate enormously, as up to 280,000 persons who had previously had a loan but who had discharged their loan would become eligible for further assistance, which would almost double the current eligibility pool.

In regard to the other four amendments, numbered (4) to (7), which Senator McLean has moved, I can find no reference in the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading to increasing the amount of the loan, let alone increasing it to $45,000, which is the purpose of Senator McLean's amendments. If this were to happen-this is not a hard figure, because an assumption is built into it about the prevailing level of interest rates and, therefore, the size of the interest subsidy-based on interest rates being at about their present level, the total cost of accepting that amendment over a five-year period would be about $230m. So it is an extremely expensive proposition. Those people who have already taken out loans, with otherwise identical qualifications would have a $25,000 loan. Future applicants, with otherwise identical qualifications with respect to the duration of the service and also the time at which the service was performed, could receive a significantly enhanced loan compared with those who received a loan previously. I do not think that is very equitable. For those reasons, the Government will not accept the amendments.
Question put:
That the requests (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has attacked the credentials of my Party, especially its Liberal credentials, in answers to several questions he has given recently. I do not contest his right to do so or to be as vigorous as he likes in answering questions. For example, on 30 September in answer to a question Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: Not even the Liberal Party of Australia, with the possible exception of the very recent period, ever actually made a virtue of ignorance.
I deny that the Party has ever made a virtue of ignorance and I would like to explain that in a moment. On 12 October Senator Walsh in answering another question said:
. . . I suppose from the exposure of their intellectual sloth and moral humbug . . .

He went on about that. I deny the charges of sloth or moral humbug as well. Finally, Senator Walsh, in objecting to our stand on a particular piece of legislation talked about the Liberal Party pandering to people, saying that we took our political positions for reasons which were not admirable. I do not accept his criticism of the Party. I do not accept his criticism of our more conservative colleagues within the Party. I certainly do not accept his criticisms that there is intellectual sloth in the Party.

I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate a quite outstanding address given by one of my friends, the Hon. Ian Macphee. It was the farewell address of the patron of the Victorian Young Liberal Movement given to that movement on 27 November 1988. The address actually contained a couple of infringements against standing order 418. I have taken the liberty of editing those out. I seek leave to table the speech which Mr Macphee made.
Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) At what level is the counselling program conducted by senior officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs now being conducted through the Returned Services League Clubs throughout the nation.
(2) Is there a need to upgrade this program as veterans, though declining in numbers, are obviously increasing in age.
(3) Has the Government any estimate of the success rate of the program over the years it has been conducted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The counselling program conducted by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) is known as the ``country visits'' program. This program is carried out by experienced and knowledgeable officers of that Department.
The program of country visits for each State is calculated to reach as many entitled and potential beneficiaries as possible.

Centres which have a high concentration of veterans are visited on two or more occasions each year, having regard to the response to and claims on the time of the visiting officers on their previous visit.

When the program is developed for each State, arrangements are put in place to ensure that local RSL and other ex-service organisations are informed of the program and advertising is placed in the local press. Local members of both the Commonwealth and State Parliaments are, in most cases, informed when DVA officers are visiting their electorates.
The visits are generally held in the RSL clubs or, if this is not possible, in the local community facility.

(2) Because the Department is very much aware of the increasing age of its clientele, the country visits program has been expanded to include visits to retirement villages and nursing homes. This expansion will continue and include other venues when required.
In this regard the Department is currently undertaking a review of the program with the aim of further extending its facilities to accommodate the special needs of clients.
(3) No, but it is a very successful program which has always been regarded as successful by both the ex-service community and the Department.
